https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*pkKxC6w_zeerF3UD 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*pkKxC6w_zeerF3UD 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2160/0*pkKxC6w_zeerF3UD 1080w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2700/0*pkKxC6w_zeerF3UD 1350w, https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*pkKxC6w_zeerF3UD 1600w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n           </noscript>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </figure>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"b75a\">\n          In the first two parts of our overview of the How of XAI, we looked into\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://medium.com/@bahador.khaleghi/the-how-of-explainable-ai-pre-modelling-explainability-699150495fe4\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           pre-modelling explainability\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://medium.com/@bahador.khaleghi/the-how-of-explainable-ai-explainable-modelling-55c8c43d7bed?sk=998bbb1d6d73722fd0d633a3cbc86b53\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explainable modelling\n          </a>\n          methodologies, which focus on explainability at the dataset stage and during model development. Yet these are relatively minor areas of interest compared with explainability after the fact, and post-modelling explainability is where the majority of XAI scientists have focused their attention and research.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ie\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"ik r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*Q5z9AdNTtRagYMM5 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             The three stages of AI explainability: Pre-modelling explainability, Explainable modelling and post-modelling explainability.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"82fd\">\n          Post-modelling explainability\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"c1ae\">\n          Currently AI models are often developed with only predictive performance in mind. Thus, the majority of the XAI literature is dedicated to explaining pre-developed models. This bias of focus along with the recent popularity of XAI research has resulted in development of numerous and diverse post-hoc explainability methods.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"a78f\">\n          It\u2019s challenging to understand this vast body of literature because of the numerous approaches to XAI. In order to make sense of the post-hoc explainability methods, we propose a taxonomy or a way of breaking down these methods that shows their common structure, organized around four key aspects: the target, what is to be explained about the model; the drivers, what is causing the thing you want explained; the explanation family, how the explanation information about the drivers causing the target is communicated to the user; and the estimator, the computational process of actually obtaining the explanation.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"43cf\">\n          For instance, the popular\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME)\n          </a>\n          approach provides explanation for an instance prediction of a model, the target, in terms of input features, the drivers, using importance scores, the explanation family, computed through local perturbations of the model input, the estimator.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ie\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"ji r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"747\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"747\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"747\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             The proposed taxonomy of the post-hoc explainability methods including the four aspects of target, drivers, explanation family, and estimator.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"03fe\">\n          In the following sections we will discuss this\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Four-Aspect Taxonomy of post-hoc Explainability\n          </strong>\n          (\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           FATE\n          </strong>\n          ) in detail. Moreover, we provide examples of related methodologies to review the literature work.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jj is dt ar aq it jk jl jm jn jo jp jq jr js jt ju\" id=\"75a8\">\n          Explanation targets\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"c8b8\">\n          The target specifies the object of an explainability method, which makes it the most important aspect of the FATE taxonomy. Targets can vary in terms of their type, scope, and complexity. We will present an overview of each of these three sources of target variation.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"792d\">\n          An AI ecosystem includes users with various roles. The type of explanation target is often determined according to the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.07552.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           role-specific goals of end users\n          </a>\n          . In general, there are two types of targets:\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.06560.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           inside vs. outside\n          </a>\n          , which can also be understood as\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://www.heatmapping.org/slides/2018_CVPR_1.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           mechanistic vs. functional\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"7f5f\">\n          AI experts often require a mechanistic explanation of some component inside a model. For instance, model creators might require to understand\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1610.01644.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           how layers of a deep network respond to input data\n          </a>\n          in order to debug or validate the model. In contrast, non-experts often require a functional explanation to understand how some output outside a model is produced. For instance, model examiners might require an understanding of\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           how input data is used by a model to make a prediction\n          </a>\n          in order to ensure the model is trustworthy, is not biased, or is compliant with regulation.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"9514\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            The type of explanation target is often determined according to the role-specific goals of end users.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh kh hj ki hl kj hn kk hp kl hr dl\" id=\"d36d\">\n          In addition, targets can vary in their scope. The outside-type targets are typically some form of model prediction. Their scope can be an instance prediction (aka local explanations), e.g.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explaining prediction for an instance of a class\n          </a>\n          , or all model predictions (aka global explanations), e.g.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.11279.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explaining predictions for all instances of a class\n          </a>\n          . The inside-type targets also vary depending on the architecture of the underlying model. The model architecture of interest in the XAI literature is often some neural network architecture. Accordingly, the scope of inside targets can be a\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/6519-synthesizing-the-preferred-inputs-for-neurons-in-neural-networks-via-deep-generator-networks.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           single neuron\n          </a>\n          , or\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1610.01644.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           layers\n          </a>\n          in a neural network.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ie\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"km r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"745\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"745\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"745\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             Explaining function of a given neuron, as target, by synthesizing an image that maximizes its activation, aka\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/6519-synthesizing-the-preferred-inputs-for-neurons-in-neural-networks-via-deep-generator-networks.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n              Activativation Maximization (AM)\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             : the hidden code input (red bar) of a deep image generator network is optimized to produce an image that highly activates the candle class output neuron. This optimization relies on gradient information (dashed blue line) flowing from the layer containing the target neuron al the way back to the input code layer.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"2127\">\n          Lastly, targets can vary in their complexity. They can be a single numerical or categorical output, e.g.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explaining predictions of a classifier\n          </a>\n          , or a sequence of words, e.g.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01943.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explaining prediction of a sequence-to-sequence model\n          </a>\n          . The complexity of a target has a significant influence on the choice of the explanation family as discussed later on in this section.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jj is dt ar aq it jk jl jm jn jo jp jq jr js jt ju\" id=\"230f\">\n          Explanation drivers\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"a1dc\">\n          Explanation targets can be caused by a wide variety of factors. The FATE taxonomy defines drivers as specific set of causal factors whose impact on a target is described by an explanation. The most common type of drivers are input features to an AI model. For instance, explanations that specify relative contribution of each input pixel to predictions of an image classifier are commonly studied in the XAI community.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"1c67\">\n          The raw features of an AI model are not always the best choice of explanation drivers. For instance, explaining an image classifier predictions in terms of individual input pixels can result in explanations that are too noisy, too expensive to compute, and more importantly, difficult to interpret. Alternatively, we can rely on a more interpretable representation of input features, e.g. a\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           contiguous patch of similar pixels (aka super-pixels)\n          </a>\n          in the case of image classifier prediction. Identifying appropriate explanation drivers is related to the explainable feature engineering discussion presented earlier in the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://medium.com/@bahador.khaleghi/the-how-of-explainable-ai-pre-modelling-explainability-699150495fe4?sk=2b46ff2038a0830c5c391dd54d7a92dd\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           pre-modelling explainability\n          </a>\n          section.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"21bb\">\n          Input features are not the only choice of explanation drivers. All factors that have an impact on the development of an AI model could be explanation drivers. Those factors include (but are not limited to)\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.04730.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           training samples\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://proceedings.mlr.press/v37/maclaurin15.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           hyperparameter settings\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1611.03530.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           choice of optimization algorithm\n          </a>\n          , or even the choice of model architecture.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"8c29\">\n          In particular, Koh and Liang proposed an approach to\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.04730.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explain instance predictions of AI models in terms of training samples\n          </a>\n          that are harmful or hurtful. Their solution is based on a classic technique from robust statistics called Influence Functions. For a given instance prediction, the Influence Functions provides an efficient way to estimate the impact of upweighting each training sample on model\u2019s loss function. Accordingly, training samples whose upweighting causes the loss function to worsen (increase) are considered harmful and vice versa.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"f84c\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            All factors that have an impact on the development of an AI model could be explanation drivers.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh kh hj ki hl kj hn kk hp kl hr dl\" id=\"96f2\">\n          Some research work explores allowing drivers to be an\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n          </strong>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.11279.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           arbitrary concept\n          </a>\n          as long as it can be defined by a set of examples. For instance, this allows examining whether the concept of \u201cstriped textures\u201d is contributing to predicting zebras for an image classifier. The idea to first compute the concept activation vector (CAV) for a given concept. The CAV is obtained by training a linear classifier that separates positive and negative examples of given concept using their representation yielded by a hidden layer of a neural network. The final step is estimating the derivative of given class prediction loss, e.g. class Zebra, in the direction of a given CAV, e.g. \u201cstriped texture\u201d.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ie\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"kn r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"550\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"550\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"550\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             Explaining predictions of the zebra class instances in terms of the \u201cstriped textures\u201d concept as drivers using the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.11279.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n              Testing with Concept Activation Vectors (TCAV)\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             method. The CAV is the vector orthogonal to the boundary of a linear classifier that separates given network layer activations for concept and non-concept examples. The TCAV then uses directional derivative of given class logit to measure model prediction sensitivity to changes in input towards the direction of the given concept.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <h2 class=\"jj is dt ar aq it jk jl jm jn jo jp jq jr js jt ju\" id=\"ecd8\">\n          Explanation families\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"2622\">\n          A post-hoc explanation aims at communicating some information about how a target is caused by drivers for a given AI model. The explanation family aspect of the FATE taxonomy determines the form of this information. Crucially, an explanation family must be chosen such that its information content is easily understandable (aka interpretable) by the user, which is usually a human. In addition, it should be chosen to enable generating explanations that are as faithful to the complexity of the model as possible (aka complete). Often there is a tradeoff involved in\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.00069.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           choosing an explanation family to ensure both interpretability and completeness\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"73b0\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Importance scores\n          </strong>\n          (aka saliency heatmaps) are perhaps the most common type of explanation families. The individual importance scores are meant to communicate the relative contribution made by each explanation driver to a given target; in other words, the higher the score, the more impactful the driver. For instance, Lundberg and Lee proposed\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations)\n          </a>\n          , a unified framework for generating post-hoc local explanations in the form of additive feature attribution. The framework uses Shapley values to estimate the importance of each input feature for a given instance prediction. Shapley values is a classic approach from cooperative game theory for estimating marginal contribution of players in an alliance. The marginal\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"/one-feature-attribution-method-to-supposedly-rule-them-all-shapley-values-f3e04534983d\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           contributions are obtained by averaging over every possible sequence\n          </a>\n          in which the players could have been added to the game.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"c2d2\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            Often there is a tradeoff involved in choosing an explanation family to ensure both interpretability and completeness.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh kh hj ki hl kj hn kk hp kl hr dl\" id=\"6457\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Decision rules\n          </strong>\n          are another common explanation family. Each decision rule is generally of the form \u201c\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           if condition then outcome\n          </em>\n          \u201d, where outcome represents prediction of an AI model and condition is a simple function defined over input features.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.01933.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Decision rules can be an ordered list, aka\n           <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n            decision list\n           </strong>\n           , or an unordered set, aka\n           <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n            decision set\n           </strong>\n          </a>\n          . For instance, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/299696\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           KT method\n          </a>\n          extracts a set of rules to describe a neural network model in its entirety. However, such global rule-based explanations are often too costly computationally and unable to fully capture the complexity of modern deep networks. To alleviate these shortcomings, Ribeiro et al. propose the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~marcotcr/aaai18.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Anchors method\n          </a>\n          to extract local rules that explain instance predictions of any black-box model.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"84bc\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Decision trees\n          </strong>\n          are an explanation family similar to decision rules, and can even be\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.ijcai.org/Proceedings/87-1/Papers/063.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           linearized into a set of decision rules\n          </a>\n          . Unlike decision rules, they are structured as a graph where internal nodes represent conditional tests on input features and leaf nodes represent model outcomes. In addition, in contrast to decision rules, in a decision tree each input example can satisfy only one path from the root node to a leaf node. The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-46307-0_29\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           DeepRED method\n          </a>\n          provides a solution for extracting a decision tree to approximate a given deep neural network model. Decision trees generated using the DeepRED method are shown to be of high quality. However,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.00069.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           they can be quite large\n          </a>\n          , hence difficult to interpret, as well as expensive to obtain.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"2669\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Dependency plots\n          </strong>\n          are another family of explanations. They aim at communicating how a target\u2019s value varies as a given explanation drivers\u2019 value varies, in other words, how a target\u2019s value depends on a driver\u2019s value. The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/pdp.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           partial dependence plot (PDP)\n          </a>\n          is an example of this family of explanations. The PDP shows the expected model prediction as a function of a given features\u2019 values. The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/ice.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           individual conditional expectation (ICE)\n          </a>\n          is another example of this family of explanations. For a given instance, the ICE shows the expected model prediction as a function of a given features\u2019 values.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"0882\">\n          The common explanation families discussed above often assume a target to be a simple numerical or categorical variable. They might be inadequate when a target is more complex and has some form of structure. For instance, importance score explanations cannot properly describe predictions of a language translation model where a sequence of input words are translated into a sequence of output words. Alvarez-Melis and Jaakkola proposed the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01943.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Structured-Output Causal RATionalizer (SOCRAT)\n          </a>\n          approach for extracting explanations of\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           bipartite-graph\n          </strong>\n          form for such a model. The first set of nodes represent input words to the model while the second set of nodes represent the model output words. The edges represent the estimated influence of each input word on each output word.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ie\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"kp r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"404\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"404\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"404\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             Explaining complex predictions of a sequence-to-sequence model, e.g. language translator, using a bi-partite graph as explanation family and the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01943.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n              SOCRAT\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             approach: first a perturbation model is used to obtain perturbed versions of the input sequence. Next, associations between input and predicted sequence are inferred using a causal inference model. Finally, the obtained associations are partitioned and the most relevant sets are selected.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"3843\">\n          When explaining the inner workings of a model, explanation families are often some type of\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           custom visualizations\n          </strong>\n          tailored to the target model\u2019s architecture. For instance, Strobelt et al. developed\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.07461.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LSTMViz\n          </a>\n          , a tool to understand the inner workings of special families of neural networks called long short-term memory (LSTM) designed for learning from sequential data. At its core, LSTMViz provides a solution to visualize the progression of so-called hidden states of an LSTM network as it processes a sequence of input data. The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://minsuk.com/research/papers/kahng-ganlab-vast2018.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           GAN Lab\n          </a>\n          interactive visualization tool is another example. It enables non-experts to better understand the intricacies of training a generative adversarial network (GAN) model by visualizing the intermediate results produced during this process.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"e1b4\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Verbal explanations\n          </strong>\n          are perhaps the most user-friendly explanation family as they are usually provided in natural language form similar to human explanations. Early works in this area were mainly\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://fileadmin.cs.lth.se/ai/Proceedings/aaai06/17/AAAI06-293.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           template-based\n          </a>\n          and thus rather restricted. More recent methods based on deep learning are capable of generating\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.mpi-inf.mpg.de/fileadmin/inf/d2/akata/generating-visual-explanations.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           natural language text\n          </a>\n          as justifications or even multi-modal, namely,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.08129.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           textual augmented with visual justifications\n          </a>\n          . Although appealing at first, such explanations have two main limitations. First, they are (at best) an indirect explanation of model\u2019s internal logic. Second, they have little utility when it comes to an understanding of model prediction errors.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"000b\">\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           Counterfactual\n          </strong>\n          explanations describe the smallest change to explanation drivers required to change a target to a predefined outcome. They are an increasingly important family of explanations. Often, explanation drivers are input features and the target is a model prediction. Consider a model used for loans and customer lending that is rejecting an application. A counterfactual explanation of this rejection decision could be, \u201cIf the applicant had a $10,000 higher annual income, the application would have been accepted.\u201d There are usually\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/counterfactual.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           multiple counterfactual explanation for a given target\n          </a>\n          . This issue can be alleviated by selecting the best explanation based on the number of features that must be changed, as well as whether such feature changes would indeed be actionable. To generate counterfactual explanations we can define a loss function that favours the smallest change to as few input features as possible required to make model prediction as close as possible to the desired outcome. This loss function can then be optimized either\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.00399.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           directly\n          </a>\n          or using the so-called\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1712.08443.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Growing Spheres algorithm\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"c711\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            Counterfactual explanations describe the smallest change to explanation drivers required to change a target to a predefined outcome.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <h2 class=\"jj is dt ar aq it jk kq jm kr jo ks jq kt js ku ju\" id=\"6e3f\">\n          Explanation estimation methods\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"4c35\">\n          The FATE taxonomy refers to the computational process used to obtain explanations as the estimator aspect. Explanation estimation methods are quite broad, yet they mainly vary in terms of their model applicability, and underlying mechanism. We will present an overview of explanation estimation methods according to these two sources of variation.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"579d\">\n          Some estimation methods are model-agnostic and can be applied to any black-box model, whereas others are developed for a specific model architecture only. For instance, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04938\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME method\n          </a>\n          discussed earlier can, in theory, be applied to any model as long as we can construct meaningful perturbations of input and observe the corresponding model outputs. This does not mean the explanations generated with LIME, or any model-agnostic estimator, are always informative. For example, the local perturbation mechanism used by LIME must be\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01943.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           extended to enable explaining models with complex outputs\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"f1ed\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            Explanation estimation methods are quite broad, yet they mainly vary in terms of their model applicability, and underlying mechanism.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh kh hj ki hl kj hn kk hp kl hr dl\" id=\"a229\">\n          Model-specific methods are usually targeted towards deep neural networks as they are both popular and difficult to understand. For instance, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1610.02391.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM)\n          </a>\n          approach is developed for producing visual explanations specifically for convolutional neural networks. It takes a feature map of the final convolutional layer and then weights every channel in that feature map based on the gradient of the target class with respect to the channel. Next, global average pooling across two dimensions of the class gradients followed by the RELU activation are applied to obtain the visual explanation.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"5e21\">\n          Explanation estimation methods can be examined according to their underlying mechanism\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           .\n          </strong>\n          We have identified four major mechanisms for estimating explanations, namely, perturbation, backward propagation, proxy, and activation optimization.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"701e\">\n          Some post-hoc explainability methods are based on\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           perturbation\n          </strong>\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           mechanisms\n          </strong>\n          . The idea is to generate perturbations of desired explanation drivers, analyze their impact on the given target, and summarize it all using an importance score family of explanation. For example, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04938\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME method\n          </a>\n          , discussed earlier, extracts local explanations of an instance prediction in terms of input features by generating local perturbations of those features and capturing their impact using a linear model. Similarly, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.04730.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Influence Functions\n          </a>\n          approach generates explanations of an instance prediction in terms of training samples by perturbing their weight and estimating its impact on model parameters, and eventually model loss, for a given instance prediction.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"0d59\">\n          The perturbation mechanism methods have two main advantages: they are typically easy to implement, and they are not limited to a specific model architecture. They have shortcomings, as well: they are relatively computationally expensive as they require running a sizeable number of perturbed inputs through a model to generate an explanation. This is particularly a\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.06104.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           challenge for models with high-dimensional input\n          </a>\n          as the number of required perturbations grows rapidly with the number of features. Moreover, the perturbation mechanism could\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.02685.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           underestimate the importance of features that have saturated their contribution\n          </a>\n          as perturbing them will no longer yield an impact. Lastly, constructing meaningful perturbations of drivers can be a challenge. For example, each feature is often perturbed by replacing it by an uninformative value with maximum impact. Relying on heuristics or ad-hoc choices for the uninformative reference value could lead to unreliable explanations. In particular, to ensure consistency of explanations with distribution of training data, the reference values must be chosen from\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://openreview.net/pdf?id=B1MXz20cYQ\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           plausible alternative values\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"2106\">\n          The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"/one-feature-attribution-method-to-supposedly-rule-them-all-shapley-values-f3e04534983d\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Shapley Values\n          </a>\n          framework can be considered as a particular case of the perturbation mechanism. The key intuition behind this framework is that because of the interaction among explanation drivers, the contribution of each driver to a given target can vary based on other drivers that are already inputted to a given model. Accordingly, the marginal contribution of each driver, aka Shapley value, is computed by examining all possible perturbations of inputting other drivers. The well-known\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP method\n          </a>\n          , discussed earlier, relies on this framework to extract local explanations of model instance predictions. Computing exact Shapley values\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/shapley.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           can be expensive\n          </a>\n          . Accordingly, a number of efficient Shapley value estimation methods have been proposed for specific model architectures such as\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1802.03888.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           tree ensembles\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1903.10992.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           deep networks\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"167b\">\n          The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.andrew.cmu.edu/user/danupam/datta-sen-zick-oakland16.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Quantitative Input Influence (QII)\n          </a>\n          measures are a family of measures to capture the influence degrees of a model inputs on its outputs. They construct a hypothetical input distribution, through intervention, and then quantify the resultant difference in a quantity of interest, which could be an instance or a set of model outputs. In principle, they can be categorized as a specific type of perturbation mechanism that can estimate the influence of an individual or a set of input features on an instance or a set of model outputs. Importantly, the QII measures carefully account for the input feature correlations when estimating their influence.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"3e57\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            The Shapley Values framework can be considered as a particular case of the perturbation mechanism.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh kh hj ki hl kj hn kk hp kl hr dl\" id=\"1cea\">\n          The\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           backward propagation mechanism\n          </strong>\n          is commonly used to generate post-hoc explanations for deep network models.\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n          </strong>\n          The resultant explanations are often importance scores in terms of input features of the model. To obtain these scores the backward propagation mechanism starts with the layer that is producing the given target, e.g. certain class logit, and estimates the contribution of neurons in the layer previous to that target. This process is repeated layer by layer until the contributions of input layer features are obtained. There are several backward propagation-based explainability methods. Some of the most notable examples include\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0130140\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP)\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1704.02685.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           DeepLIFT\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1412.6806.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Guided Backprop (GB)\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03825\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SmoothGrad\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1611.02639.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Integrated Gradients (IG)\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"32ae\">\n          These methods differ mainly in terms of how they estimate contributions of the previous layer. In particular, contributions can be estimated based on partial gradients of a target neuron activation with respect to previous layer neurons (aka sensitivity analysis) as in the GB and SmoothGrad methods. Alternatively, they can be estimated by decomposing a target neuron activation value into its constituent values coming from previous layer (aka decomposition approach) as in the LRP and DeepLIFT methods. Contributions estimated using sensitivity analysis\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1051200417302385\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           mainly relate to local variation of target neuron activation\n          </a>\n          rather than its value. Multiplying sensitivity based contributions by the activation of previous layer neurons can alleviate this issue as in the IG method. In fact, it has been shown that decomposition based contribution methods and those similar to the IG approach are\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.06104.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           closely related\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"hw hx hy hz ia ib ae ic af id ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl if ig paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"ih ii gx ij ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd kv\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"kw r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"758\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU?q=20\" width=\"1416\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"758\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 1000w\" width=\"1416\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"758\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2832/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*38IID6_rhozd1stU 1000w\" width=\"1416\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew il im in de dc dd io ip aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             Explaining predictions of a neural network in term of input features using the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://www.heatmapping.org/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n              Layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP) method\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            :\n            <strong class=\"aq iq\">\n             first, a standard forward pass is applied to the network and each layer\u2019s activations are collected. Next, the score obtained at the network output is propagated backwards through the network, using a set of propagation rules.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"677d\">\n          Methods based on the backward propagation mechanism\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n          </strong>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1711.06104.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           require only one or a few inference passes\n          </a>\n          through the model to generate an explanation. This makes them more computationally efficient when compared to methods based on the perturbation mechanism. On the other hand, the backward propagation mechanism is only applicable to deep networks. In addition, explanations produced using this mechanism\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1810.03292.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           can be unreliable\n          </a>\n          . Some of the more recent methods such as DeepLIFT and LRP promise to provide more robust explanations. However, DeepLIFT\u2019s performance\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f_iAM0NPwnM&amp;list=PLJLjQOkqSRTP3cLB2cOOi_bQFw6KPGKML&amp;index=3\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           depends significantly on the choice of its reference\n          </a>\n          point, which must be determined by the user. Similarly, LRP has been shown to have\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0130140&amp;type=printable\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           numerical instability issues\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"9683\">\n          Another approach to obtain post-hoc explanations for a complex model is to imitate it with a simpler and more explainable model with comparable performance, namely, the\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           proxy mechanism.\n          </strong>\n          This mechanism is often applied to replace complex deep neural networks with more explainable models such as decision trees or decision rules. Early work in this category was\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/938448\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           only applicable to shallow neural networks\n          </a>\n          . More recent methods, however, are aimed for deep neural network models. For example, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-46307-0_29\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           DeepRED approach\n          </a>\n          , discussed earlier, is able to construct decision trees that faithfully represent a deep network model. However, the generated decision trees might be quite large, and thus not so explainable.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"1a88\">\n          One approach to alleviate this challenge is to learn proxy models that do not imitate the behaviour of a complex model globally. For example, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://homes.cs.washington.edu/~marcotcr/aaai18.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Anchors approach\n          </a>\n          aims at extracting local decision rules that imitate only an instance prediction of a given model. Similarly, the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1707.01154.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           BETA method\n          </a>\n          learns a small number of decision sets, each of which imitates the behaviour of a given complex model within a well-defined region of its input feature space.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"d81b\">\n          The\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           activation optimization\n          </strong>\n          <strong class=\"hg iq\">\n           mechanism\n          </strong>\n          is often used to generate explanations of the inner workings of deep network models. Its explanations are obtained by searching for an input pattern that\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1051200417302385\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           produces maximum (or minimum) response\n          </a>\n          for an inner component of a model as the target, e.g. a specific neuron. This search problem can in turn be formulated as an optimization problem and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1312.6034.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           solved using a gradient based approach\n          </a>\n          . This procedure is similar to that used to train the model where the optimization targets are input features rather than model parameters.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"7af2\">\n          Unfortunately, without adding any regularization, the input patterns obtained using the activation optimization mechanism often resemble high frequency noise.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://distill.pub/2017/feature-visualization/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Various families of regularization constraints\n          </a>\n          have been proposed to alleviate this challenge. For instance, we can attempt to directly reduce the high-frequency noise by\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1412.0035v1.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explicitly penalizing variance between neighbouring input features\n          </a>\n          . However, such a regularization constraint could also suppress legitimate high-frequency features, e.g. edges in an input image.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"jv\">\n          <div class=\"jw jx jy ar du b jz ka kb kc kd ke hr\" id=\"27ae\">\n           <p class=\"du b kf kg av\">\n            The activation optimization mechanism\n            <strong class=\"bd\">\n            </strong>\n            is often used to generate explanations of inner working of deep network models.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"b573\">\n          What\u2019s next?\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh jd hj je hl jf hn jg hp jh hr dl\" id=\"7235\">\n          Numerous methods have been proposed to explain pre-developed AI models. They vary in terms of their explanation target, driver, family and extraction mechanism. XAI is an active research area and new and improved methods are developed constantly. Such diversity of choices can make it challenging of XAI practitioners to adopt the most suitable approach for a given application.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"cd99\">\n          To help alleviate this challenge the\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Bw9aBq5VbQY5C5t0RAi9sFGSp3gQFu6V\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           appendix\n          </a>\n          of this series presents a snapshot of some of the most notable post-modelling explainability methods. Each method is characterized according to the four aspects introduced by the FATE taxonomy to systematically position it within the body of XAI literature. In addition, an overview of some of the off-the-shelf XAI software packages is provided.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n      <hr class=\"kx cl ky kz la in lb lc ld le lf\"/>\n      <section class=\"dl dm dn do dp\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"0bd9\">\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           Special thanks to\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://wxs.ca/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Xavier Snelgrove\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ca.linkedin.com/in/elnaz-barshan-845964ba\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Elnaz Barshan\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://www.lindsaydbrin.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Lindsay Brin\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ca.linkedin.com/in/santiagosalcido\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Santiago Salcido\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           , and\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://manongruaz.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Manon Gruaz\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           for valuable comments and illustrations. Edited by\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/pnhenderson/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"ko\">\n            Peter Henderson\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"ko\">\n           .\n          </em>\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n    </article>\n    <div class=\"gr dk lg lh ai lo lm lp\" data-test-id=\"post-sidebar\">\n     <div class=\"n p\">\n      <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n       <div class=\"lq n dg\">\n        <div class=\"dk\">\n         <div class=\"lr ls r\">\n          <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=post_sidebar--------------------------post_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n           <h2 class=\"aq it lt as dt\">\n            Towards Data Science\n           </h2>\n          </a>\n          <div class=\"lu lv r\">\n           <h4 class=\"aq cl ew as br lw ey ez lx fb av\">\n            A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas, and codes.\n           </h4>\n          </div>\n          <div aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"fw\">\n           <a class=\"ly fh ax ay lz bh bi ma bg fs aq b ar as at au fu fv df fw fx bj\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            Follow\n           </a>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"mb mc md n\">\n          <div class=\"n o\">\n           <div class=\"me r gx\">\n            <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-post-modelling-explainability-8b4cbc7adf5f&amp;source=post_sidebar-----8b4cbc7adf5f---------------------clap_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n             <div class=\"be mf mg mh mi mj mk ml ay mm bi\">\n              <svg height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n               <g fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                <path d=\"M13.74 1l.76 2.97.76-2.97zM16.82 4.78l1.84-2.56-1.43-.47zM10.38 2.22l1.84 2.56-.41-3.03zM22.38 22.62a5.11 5.11 0 0 1-3.16 1.61l.49-.45c2.88-2.89 3.45-5.98 0 0 0 .63-.62L6.1 15.04l-1.75-1.75a1 1 0 1 1 1.41-1.41l4.15 4.15a.44.44 0 0 0 .63 0 .44.44 0 0 0 0-.62L6.4 11.26l-1.18-1.18a1 1 0 0 1 0-1.4 1.02 1.02 0 0 1 1.41 0l1.18 1.16L11.96 14a.44.44 0 0 0 .62 0 .44.44 0 0 0 0-.63L8.43 9.22a.99.99 0 0 1-.3-.7.99.99 0 0 1 .3-.7 1 1 0 0 1 1.41 0l7 6.98a.44.44 0 0 0 .7-.5l-1.35-2.85c-.31-.68-.23-1.19.25-1.56a.85.85 0 0 1 .66-.16c.34.06.66.28.88.6L20.63 15c1.57 0zm8.89 2.06c-.38-.56-.9-.92-1.49-1.01a1.74 1.74 0 0 0-1.34.33c-.38.29-.61.65-.71 1.06a2.1 2.1 0 0 0-1.1-.56 1.78 1.78 0 0 0-.99.13l-2.64-2.64a1.88 1.88 0 0 0-2.65 0 1.86 1.86 0 0 0-.48.85 1.89 1.89 0 0 0-2.67-.01 1.87 1.87 0 0 0-.5.9c-.76-.75-2-.75-2.7-.04a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66c-.3.12-.61.29-.87.55a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66l.62.62a1.88 1.88 0 0 0-.9 3.16l5.01 5.02c1.6 1.6 3.52 2.64 5.4 2.96a7.16 7.16 0 0 0 1.18.1c1.03 0 2-.25 2.9-.7A5.9 5.9 0 0 0 23 23.24c3.34-3.34 3.08-6.93 1.74-9.17l-2.87-5.04z\">\n                </path>\n               </g>\n              </svg>\n             </div>\n            </a>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"mn r\">\n            <div class=\"mo\">\n             <h4 class=\"aq cl ew as av\">\n              <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\">\n               139\n              </button>\n             </h4>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"mc r\">\n         </div>\n         <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-post-modelling-explainability-8b4cbc7adf5f&amp;source=post_sidebar--------------------------post_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n          <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n           <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 5.66 4.13a.5.5 0 0 0 .71-.03.5.5 0 0 0 .12-.29H19V6zm-6.84 9.97L7 19.64V6a1 1 0 0 1 1-1h9a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v13.64l-5.16-3.67a.49.49 0 0 0-.68 0z\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n           </path>\n          </svg>\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n     </div>\n    </div>\n    <div class=\"gr dk lg lh li lj lk ll lm ln\">\n    </div>\n    <div>\n     <div class=\"mp gl n dg p\">\n      <div class=\"n p\">\n       <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n        <div class=\"n mq\">\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"n o mq\">\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"mr r\">\n         <ul class=\"be bf\">\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj ms\">\n           <a class=\"mt mu fx av r mv mw a b cm\" href=\"/tag/machine-learning\">\n            Machine Learning\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj ms\">\n           <a class=\"mt mu fx av r mv mw a b cm\" href=\"/tag/ai\">\n            AI\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj ms\">\n           <a class=\"mt mu fx av r mv mw a b cm\" href=\"/tag/explainability\">\n            Explainability\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj ms\">\n           <a class=\"mt mu fx av r mv mw a b cm\" href=\"/tag/black-box\">\n            Black Box\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj ms\">\n           <a class=\"mt mu fx av r mv mw a b cm\" href=\"/tag/trust\">\n            Trust\n           </a>\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"mx n em y\">\n         <div class=\"n o\">\n          <div class=\"my r gx\">\n           <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-post-modelling-explainability-8b4cbc7adf5f&amp;source=post_actions_footer-----8b4cbc7adf5f---------------------clap_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            <div class=\"c mz eq n o na gx nb nc nd ne nf ng nh ni nj nk nl nm nn ma\">\n             <div class=\"be mf mg mh mi mj no ml o hd eq n p np u gt s t ai ay mm bi nq\">\n              <svg height=\"33\" viewbox=\"0 0 33 33\" width=\"33\">\n               <path d=\"M28.86 17.34l-3.64-6.4c-.3-.43-.71-.73-1.16-.8a1.12 1.12 0 0 0-.9.21c-.62.5-.73 1.18-.32 2.06l1.22
