Thus, the majority of the XAI literature is dedicated to explaining pre-developed models. This bias of focus along with the recent popularity of XAI research has resulted in development of numerous and diverse post-hoc explainability methods.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_6\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_6\",\"name\":\"a78f\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"It\u2019s challenging to understand this vast body of literature because of the numerous approaches to XAI. In order to make sense of the post-hoc explainability methods, we propose a taxonomy or a way of breaking down these methods that shows their common structure, organized around four key aspects: the target, what is to be explained about the model; the drivers, what is causing the thing you want explained; the explanation family, how the explanation information about the drivers causing the target is communicated to the user; and the estimator, the computational process of actually obtaining the explanation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_7\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_7\",\"name\":\"43cf\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"For instance, the popular Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) approach provides explanation for an instance prediction of a model, the target, in terms of input features, the drivers, using importance scores, the explanation family, computed through local perturbations of the model input, the estimator.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_7.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_7.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":26,\"end\":80,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_8\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_8\",\"name\":\"6d1d\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"The proposed taxonomy of the post-hoc explainability methods including the four aspects of target, drivers, explanation family, and estimator.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_8.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd\":{\"id\":\"0*1qiKVxoIS3BOVhmd\",\"originalHeight\":747,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_8.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":142,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_9\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_9\",\"name\":\"03fe\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In the following sections we will discuss this Four-Aspect Taxonomy of post-hoc Explainability (FATE) in detail. Moreover, we provide examples of related methodologies to review the literature work.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_9.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_9.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_9.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":47,\"end\":94,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_9.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":96,\"end\":100,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_10\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_10\",\"name\":\"75a8\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation targets\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_11\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_11\",\"name\":\"c8b8\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The target specifies the object of an explainability method, which makes it the most important aspect of the FATE taxonomy. Targets can vary in terms of their type, scope, and complexity. We will present an overview of each of these three sources of target variation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_12\",\"name\":\"792d\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"An AI ecosystem includes users with various roles. The type of explanation target is often determined according to the role-specific goals of end users. In general, there are two types of targets: inside vs. outside, which can also be understood as mechanistic vs. functional.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":119,\"end\":151,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.07552.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":197,\"end\":215,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1901.06560.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_12.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":249,\"end\":275,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.heatmapping.org\\u002Fslides\\u002F2018_CVPR_1.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_13\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_13\",\"name\":\"7f5f\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"AI experts often require a mechanistic explanation of some component inside a model. For instance, model creators might require to understand how layers of a deep network respond to input data in order to debug or validate the model. In contrast, non-experts often require a functional explanation to understand how some output outside a model is produced. For instance, model examiners might require an understanding of how input data is used by a model to make a prediction in order to ensure the model is trustworthy, is not biased, or is compliant with regulation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_13.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_13.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_13.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":142,\"end\":192,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1610.01644.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_13.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":421,\"end\":475,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_14\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_14\",\"name\":\"9514\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The type of explanation target is often determined according to the role-specific goals of end users.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_15\",\"name\":\"d36d\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In addition, targets can vary in their scope. The outside-type targets are typically some form of model prediction. Their scope can be an instance prediction (aka local explanations), e.g. explaining prediction for an instance of a class, or all model predictions (aka global explanations), e.g. explaining predictions for all instances of a class. The inside-type targets also vary depending on the architecture of the underlying model. The model architecture of interest in the XAI literature is often some neural network architecture. Accordingly, the scope of inside targets can be a single neuron, or layers in a neural network.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":189,\"end\":237,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":296,\"end\":347,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.11279.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":588,\"end\":601,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fpapers.nips.cc\\u002Fpaper\\u002F6519-synthesizing-the-preferred-inputs-for-neurons-in-neural-networks-via-deep-generator-networks.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_15.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":606,\"end\":612,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1610.01644.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_16\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_16\",\"name\":\"ea46\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Explaining function of a given neuron, as target, by synthesizing an image that maximizes its activation, aka Activativation Maximization (AM): the hidden code input (red bar) of a deep image generator network is optimized to produce an image that highly activates the candle class output neuron. This optimization relies on gradient information (dashed blue line) flowing from the layer containing the target neuron al the way back to the input code layer.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_16.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_16.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo\":{\"id\":\"0*6PDhVLBZX1M3owIo\",\"originalHeight\":745,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_16.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":110,\"end\":142,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fpapers.nips.cc\\u002Fpaper\\u002F6519-synthesizing-the-preferred-inputs-for-neurons-in-neural-networks-via-deep-generator-networks.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_16.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":457,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_17\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_17\",\"name\":\"2127\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Lastly, targets can vary in their complexity. They can be a single numerical or categorical output, e.g. explaining predictions of a classifier, or a sequence of words, e.g. explaining prediction of a sequence-to-sequence model. The complexity of a target has a significant influence on the choice of the explanation family as discussed later on in this section.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_17.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_17.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_17.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":105,\"end\":143,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_17.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":174,\"end\":227,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1707.01943.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_18\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_18\",\"name\":\"230f\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation drivers\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_19\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_19\",\"name\":\"a1dc\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation targets can be caused by a wide variety of factors. The FATE taxonomy defines drivers as specific set of causal factors whose impact on a target is described by an explanation. The most common type of drivers are input features to an AI model. For instance, explanations that specify relative contribution of each input pixel to predictions of an image classifier are commonly studied in the XAI community.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_20\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_20\",\"name\":\"1c67\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The raw features of an AI model are not always the best choice of explanation drivers. For instance, explaining an image classifier predictions in terms of individual input pixels can result in explanations that are too noisy, too expensive to compute, and more importantly, difficult to interpret. Alternatively, we can rely on a more interpretable representation of input features, e.g. a contiguous patch of similar pixels (aka super-pixels) in the case of image classifier prediction. Identifying appropriate explanation drivers is related to the explainable feature engineering discussion presented earlier in the pre-modelling explainability section.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_20.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_20.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_20.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":391,\"end\":444,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_20.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":619,\"end\":647,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fmedium.com\\u002F@bahador.khaleghi\\u002Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-pre-modelling-explainability-699150495fe4?sk=2b46ff2038a0830c5c391dd54d7a92dd\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_21\",\"name\":\"21bb\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Input features are not the only choice of explanation drivers. All factors that have an impact on the development of an AI model could be explanation drivers. Those factors include (but are not limited to) training samples, hyperparameter settings, choice of optimization algorithm, or even the choice of model architecture.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":206,\"end\":222,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1703.04730.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":224,\"end\":247,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fproceedings.mlr.press\\u002Fv37\\u002Fmaclaurin15.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_21.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":249,\"end\":281,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1611.03530.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_22\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_22\",\"name\":\"8c29\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In particular, Koh and Liang proposed an approach to explain instance predictions of AI models in terms of training samples that are harmful or hurtful. Their solution is based on a classic technique from robust statistics called Influence Functions. For a given instance prediction, the Influence Functions provides an efficient way to estimate the impact of upweighting each training sample on model\u2019s loss function. Accordingly, training samples whose upweighting causes the loss function to worsen (increase) are considered harmful and vice versa.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_22.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_22.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":53,\"end\":123,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1703.04730.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_23\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_23\",\"name\":\"f84c\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"All factors that have an impact on the development of an AI model could be explanation drivers.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_24\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_24\",\"name\":\"96f2\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Some research work explores allowing drivers to be an arbitrary concept as long as it can be defined by a set of examples. For instance, this allows examining whether the concept of \u201cstriped textures\u201d is contributing to predicting zebras for an image classifier. The idea to first compute the concept activation vector (CAV) for a given concept. The CAV is obtained by training a linear classifier that separates positive and negative examples of given concept using their representation yielded by a hidden layer of a neural network. The final step is estimating the derivative of given class prediction loss, e.g. class Zebra, in the direction of a given CAV, e.g. \u201cstriped texture\u201d.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_24.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_24.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_24.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":54,\"end\":71,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.11279.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_24.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":53,\"end\":54,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_25\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_25\",\"name\":\"b2ba\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Explaining predictions of the zebra class instances in terms of the \u201cstriped textures\u201d concept as drivers using the Testing with Concept Activation Vectors (TCAV) method. The CAV is the vector orthogonal to the boundary of a linear classifier that separates given network layer activations for concept and non-concept examples. The TCAV then uses directional derivative of given class logit to measure model prediction sensitivity to changes in input towards the direction of the given concept.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_25.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_25.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM\":{\"id\":\"0*fBX9dJk1XutVFqXM\",\"originalHeight\":550,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_25.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":116,\"end\":162,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.11279.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_25.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":494,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_26\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_26\",\"name\":\"ecd8\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation families\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_27\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_27\",\"name\":\"2622\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"A post-hoc explanation aims at communicating some information about how a target is caused by drivers for a given AI model. The explanation family aspect of the FATE taxonomy determines the form of this information. Crucially, an explanation family must be chosen such that its information content is easily understandable (aka interpretable) by the user, which is usually a human. In addition, it should be chosen to enable generating explanations that are as faithful to the complexity of the model as possible (aka complete). Often there is a tradeoff involved in choosing an explanation family to ensure both interpretability and completeness.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_27.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_27.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":567,\"end\":646,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.00069.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_28\",\"name\":\"73b0\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Importance scores (aka saliency heatmaps) are perhaps the most common type of explanation families. The individual importance scores are meant to communicate the relative contribution made by each explanation driver to a given target; in other words, the higher the score, the more impactful the driver. For instance, Lundberg and Lee proposed SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), a unified framework for generating post-hoc local explanations in the form of additive feature attribution. The framework uses Shapley values to estimate the importance of each input feature for a given instance prediction. Shapley values is a classic approach from cooperative game theory for estimating marginal contribution of players in an alliance. The marginal contributions are obtained by averaging over every possible sequence in which the players could have been added to the game.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":344,\"end\":380,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fpapers.nips.cc\\u002Fpaper\\u002F7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":749,\"end\":817,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\\u002Fone-feature-attribution-method-to-supposedly-rule-them-all-shapley-values-f3e04534983d\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_28.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":17,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_29\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_29\",\"name\":\"c2d2\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Often there is a tradeoff involved in choosing an explanation family to ensure both interpretability and completeness.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_30\",\"name\":\"6457\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Decision rules are another common explanation family. Each decision rule is generally of the form \u201cif condition then outcome\u201d, where outcome represents prediction of an AI model and condition is a simple function defined over input features. Decision rules can be an ordered list, aka decision list, or an unordered set, aka decision set. For instance, the KT method extracts a set of rules to describe a neural network model in its entirety. However, such global rule-based explanations are often too costly computationally and unable to fully capture the complexity of modern deep networks. To alleviate these shortcomings, Ribeiro et al. propose the Anchors method to extract local rules that explain instance predictions of any black-box model.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.5\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.6\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":242,\"end\":337,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1802.01933.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":357,\"end\":366,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fieeexplore.ieee.org\\u002Fabstract\\u002Fdocument\\u002F299696\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":653,\"end\":667,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fhomes.cs.washington.edu\\u002F~marcotcr\\u002Faaai18.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":14,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":285,\"end\":298,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.5\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":325,\"end\":337,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_30.markups.6\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":99,\"end\":124,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_31\",\"name\":\"84bc\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Decision trees are an explanation family similar to decision rules, and can even be linearized into a set of decision rules. Unlike decision rules, they are structured as a graph where internal nodes represent conditional tests on input features and leaf nodes represent model outcomes. In addition, in contrast to decision rules, in a decision tree each input example can satisfy only one path from the root node to a leaf node. The DeepRED method provides a solution for extracting a decision tree to approximate a given deep neural network model. Decision trees generated using the DeepRED method are shown to be of high quality. However, they can be quite large, hence difficult to interpret, as well as expensive to obtain.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":84,\"end\":123,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.ijcai.org\\u002FProceedings\\u002F87-1\\u002FPapers\\u002F063.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":434,\"end\":448,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Flink.springer.com\\u002Fchapter\\u002F10.1007\\u002F978-3-319-46307-0_29\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":642,\"end\":665,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.00069.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_31.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":14,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_32\",\"name\":\"2669\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Dependency plots are another family of explanations. They aim at communicating how a target\u2019s value varies as a given explanation drivers\u2019 value varies, in other words, how a target\u2019s value depends on a driver\u2019s value. The partial dependence plot (PDP) is an example of this family of explanations. The PDP shows the expected model prediction as a function of a given features\u2019 values. The individual conditional expectation (ICE) is another example of this family of explanations. For a given instance, the ICE shows the expected model prediction as a function of a given features\u2019 values.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":223,\"end\":252,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fchristophm.github.io\\u002Finterpretable-ml-book\\u002Fpdp.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":390,\"end\":430,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fchristophm.github.io\\u002Finterpretable-ml-book\\u002Fice.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_32.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":16,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_33\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_33\",\"name\":\"0882\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The common explanation families discussed above often assume a target to be a simple numerical or categorical variable. They might be inadequate when a target is more complex and has some form of structure. For instance, importance score explanations cannot properly describe predictions of a language translation model where a sequence of input words are translated into a sequence of output words. Alvarez-Melis and Jaakkola proposed the Structured-Output Causal RATionalizer (SOCRAT) approach for extracting explanations of bipartite-graph form for such a model. The first set of nodes represent input words to the model while the second set of nodes represent the model output words. The edges represent the estimated influence of each input word on each output word.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_33.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_33.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_33.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":440,\"end\":486,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1707.01943.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_33.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":527,\"end\":543,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_34\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_34\",\"name\":\"9efd\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Explaining complex predictions of a sequence-to-sequence model, e.g. language translator, using a bi-partite graph as explanation family and the SOCRAT approach: first a perturbation model is used to obtain perturbed versions of the input sequence. Next, associations between input and predicted sequence are inferred using a causal inference model. Finally, the obtained associations are partitioned and the most relevant sets are selected.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_34.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_34.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC\":{\"id\":\"0*vavq9hQQWNer0TEC\",\"originalHeight\":404,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_34.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":145,\"end\":151,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1707.01943.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_34.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":441,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_35\",\"name\":\"3843\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"When explaining the inner workings of a model, explanation families are often some type of custom visualizations tailored to the target model\u2019s architecture. For instance, Strobelt et al. developed LSTMViz, a tool to understand the inner workings of special families of neural networks called long short-term memory (LSTM) designed for learning from sequential data. At its core, LSTMViz provides a solution to visualize the progression of so-called hidden states of an LSTM network as it processes a sequence of input data. It enables non-experts to better understand the intricacies of training a generative adversarial network (GAN) model by visualizing the intermediate results produced during this process.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":198,\"end\":205,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1606.07461.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":529,\"end\":536,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fminsuk.com\\u002Fresearch\\u002Fpapers\\u002Fkahng-ganlab-vast2018.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_35.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":91,\"end\":112,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_36\",\"name\":\"e1b4\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Verbal explanations are perhaps the most user-friendly explanation family as they are usually provided in natural language form similar to human explanations. Early works in this area were mainly template-based and thus rather restricted. More recent methods based on deep learning are capable of generating natural language text as justifications or even multi-modal, namely, textual augmented with visual justifications. Although appealing at first, such explanations have two main limitations. First, they are (at best) an indirect explanation of model\u2019s internal logic. Second, they have little utility when it comes to an understanding of model prediction errors.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":196,\"end\":210,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Ffileadmin.cs.lth.se\\u002Fai\\u002FProceedings\\u002Faaai06\\u002F17\\u002FAAAI06-293.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":308,\"end\":329,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.mpi-inf.mpg.de\\u002Ffileadmin\\u002Finf\\u002Fd2\\u002Fakata\\u002Fgenerating-visual-explanations.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":377,\"end\":421,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1802.08129.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_36.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":19,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_37\",\"name\":\"000b\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Counterfactual explanations describe the smallest change to explanation drivers required to change a target to a predefined outcome. They are an increasingly important family of explanations. Often, explanation drivers are input features and the target is a model prediction. Consider a model used for loans and customer lending that is rejecting an application. A counterfactual explanation of this rejection decision could be, \u201cIf the applicant had a $10,000 higher annual income, the application would have been accepted.\u201d There are usually multiple counterfactual explanation for a given target. This issue can be alleviated by selecting the best explanation based on the number of features that must be changed, as well as whether such feature changes would indeed be actionable. To generate counterfactual explanations we can define a loss function that favours the smallest change to as few input features as possible required to make model prediction as close as possible to the desired outcome. This loss function can then be optimized either directly or using the so-called Growing Spheres algorithm.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":544,\"end\":598,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fchristophm.github.io\\u002Finterpretable-ml-book\\u002Fcounterfactual.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":1052,\"end\":1060,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.00399.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":1084,\"end\":1109,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1712.08443.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_37.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":15,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_38\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_38\",\"name\":\"c711\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Counterfactual explanations describe the smallest change to explanation drivers required to change a target to a predefined outcome.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_39\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_39\",\"name\":\"6e3f\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation estimation methods\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_40\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_40\",\"name\":\"4c35\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The FATE taxonomy refers to the computational process used to obtain explanations as the estimator aspect. Explanation estimation methods are quite broad, yet they mainly vary in terms of their model applicability, and underlying mechanism. We will present an overview of explanation estimation methods according to these two sources of variation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_41\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_41\",\"name\":\"579d\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Some estimation methods are model-agnostic and can be applied to any black-box model, whereas others are developed for a specific model architecture only. For instance, the LIME method discussed earlier can, in theory, be applied to any model as long as we can construct meaningful perturbations of input and observe the corresponding model outputs. This does not mean the explanations generated with LIME, or any model-agnostic estimator, are always informative. For example, the local perturbation mechanism used by LIME must be extended to enable explaining models with complex outputs.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_41.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_41.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_41.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":173,\"end\":184,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1602.04938\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_41.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":531,\"end\":588,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1707.01943.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_42\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_42\",\"name\":\"f1ed\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation estimation methods are quite broad, yet they mainly vary in terms of their model applicability, and underlying mechanism.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_43\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_43\",\"name\":\"a229\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Model-specific methods are usually targeted towards deep neural networks as they are both popular and difficult to understand. For instance, the Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) approach is developed for producing visual explanations specifically for convolutional neural networks. It takes a feature map of the final convolutional layer and then weights every channel in that feature map based on the gradient of the target class with respect to the channel. Next, global average pooling across two dimensions of the class gradients followed by the RELU activation are applied to obtain the visual explanation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_43.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_43.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":145,\"end\":198,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1610.02391.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_44\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_44\",\"name\":\"5e21\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explanation estimation methods can be examined according to their underlying mechanism. We have identified four major mechanisms for estimating explanations, namely, perturbation, backward propagation, proxy, and activation optimization.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_44.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_44.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":86,\"end\":88,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_45\",\"name\":\"701e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Some post-hoc explainability methods are based on perturbation mechanisms. The idea is to generate perturbations of desired explanation drivers, analyze their impact on the given target, and summarize it all using an importance score family of explanation. For example, the LIME method, discussed earlier, extracts local explanations of an instance prediction in terms of input features by generating local perturbations of those features and capturing their impact using a linear model. Similarly, the Influence Functions approach generates explanations of an instance prediction in terms of training samples by perturbing their weight and estimating its impact on model parameters, and eventually model loss, for a given instance prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":274,\"end\":285,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1602.04938\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":503,\"end\":522,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1703.04730.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":50,\"end\":62,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_45.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":63,\"end\":73,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_46\",\"name\":\"0d59\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The perturbation mechanism methods have two main advantages: they are typically easy to implement, and they are not limited to a specific model architecture. They have shortcomings, as well: they are relatively computationally expensive as they require running a sizeable number of perturbed inputs through a model to generate an explanation. This is particularly a challenge for models with high-dimensional input as the number of required perturbations grows rapidly with the number of features. Moreover, the perturbation mechanism could underestimate the importance of features that have saturated their contribution as perturbing them will no longer yield an impact. Lastly, constructing meaningful perturbations of drivers can be a challenge. For example, each feature is often perturbed by replacing it by an uninformative value with maximum impact. Relying on heuristics or ad-hoc choices for the uninformative reference value could lead to unreliable explanations. In particular, to ensure consistency of explanations with distribution of training data, the reference values must be chosen from plausible alternative values.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":366,\"end\":414,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.06104.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":541,\"end\":620,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1704.02685.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_46.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":1104,\"end\":1132,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fopenreview.net\\u002Fpdf?id=B1MXz20cYQ\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_47\",\"name\":\"2106\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Shapley Values framework can be considered as a particular case of the perturbation mechanism. The key intuition behind this framework is that because of the interaction among explanation drivers, the contribution of each driver to a given target can vary based on other drivers that are already inputted to a given model. Accordingly, the marginal contribution of each driver, aka Shapley value, is computed by examining all possible perturbations of inputting other drivers. The well-known SHAP method, discussed earlier, relies on this framework to extract local explanations of model instance predictions. Computing exact Shapley values can be expensive. Accordingly, a number of efficient Shapley value estimation methods have been proposed for specific model architectures such as tree ensembles and deep networks.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":18,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Ftowardsdatascience.com\\u002Fone-feature-attribution-method-to-supposedly-rule-them-all-shapley-values-f3e04534983d\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":496,\"end\":507,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fpapers.nips.cc\\u002Fpaper\\u002F7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":645,\"end\":661,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fchristophm.github.io\\u002Finterpretable-ml-book\\u002Fshapley.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":791,\"end\":805,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1802.03888.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_47.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":810,\"end\":823,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1903.10992.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_48\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_48\",\"name\":\"167b\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Quantitative Input Influence (QII) measures are a family of measures to capture the influence degrees of a model inputs on its outputs. They construct a hypothetical input distribution, through intervention, and then quantify the resultant difference in a quantity of interest, which could be an instance or a set of model outputs. In principle, they can be categorized as a specific type of perturbation mechanism that can estimate the influence of an individual or a set of input features on an instance or a set of model outputs. Importantly, the QII measures carefully account for the input feature correlations when estimating their influence.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_48.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_48.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":38,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.andrew.cmu.edu\\u002Fuser\\u002Fdanupam\\u002Fdatta-sen-zick-oakland16.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_49\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_49\",\"name\":\"3e57\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Shapley Values framework can be considered as a particular case of the perturbation mechanism.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_50\",\"name\":\"1cea\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The backward propagation mechanism is commonly used to generate post-hoc explanations for deep network models. The resultant explanations are often importance scores in terms of input features of the model. To obtain these scores the backward propagation mechanism starts with the layer that is producing the given target, e.g. certain class logit, and estimates the contribution of neurons in the layer previous to that target. This process is repeated layer by layer until the contributions of input layer features are obtained. There are several backward propagation-based explainability methods. Some of the most notable examples include layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP), DeepLIFT, Guided Backprop (GB), SmoothGrad, and Integrated Gradients (IG).\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.5\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.6\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":642,\"end\":680,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fjournals.plos.org\\u002Fplosone\\u002Farticle?id=10.1371\\u002Fjournal.pone.0130140\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":682,\"end\":690,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1704.02685.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":692,\"end\":712,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1412.6806.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":714,\"end\":724,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1706.03825\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":730,\"end\":755,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1611.02639.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.5\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":4,\"end\":35,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_50.markups.6\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":110,\"end\":111,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_51\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_51\",\"name\":\"32ae\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"These methods differ mainly in terms of how they estimate contributions of the previous layer. In particular, contributions can be estimated based on partial gradients of a target neuron activation with respect to previous layer neurons (aka sensitivity analysis) as in the GB and SmoothGrad methods. Alternatively, they can be estimated by decomposing a target neuron activation value into its constituent values coming from previous layer (aka decomposition approach) as in the LRP and DeepLIFT methods. Contributions estimated using sensitivity analysis mainly relate to local variation of target neuron activation rather than its value. Multiplying sensitivity based contributions by the activation of previous layer neurons can alleviate this issue as in the IG method. In fact, it has been shown that decomposition based contribution methods and those similar to the IG approach are closely related.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_51.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_51.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_51.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":557,\"end\":617,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.sciencedirect.com\\u002Fscience\\u002Farticle\\u002Fpii\\u002FS1051200417302385\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_51.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":889,\"end\":904,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.06104.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_52\",\"name\":\"c4fb\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*38IID6_rhozd1stU\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Explaining predictions of a neural network in term of input features using the Layer-wise Relevance Propagation (LRP) method: first, a standard forward pass is applied to the network and each layer\u2019s activations are collected. Next, the score obtained at the network output is propagated backwards through the network, using a set of propagation rules.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*38IID6_rhozd1stU\":{\"id\":\"0*38IID6_rhozd1stU\",\"originalHeight\":758,\"originalWidth\":1416,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":79,\"end\":124,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.heatmapping.org\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":124,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_52.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":125,\"end\":352,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_53\",\"name\":\"677d\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Methods based on the backward propagation mechanism require only one or a few inference passes through the model to generate an explanation. This makes them more computationally efficient when compared to methods based on the perturbation mechanism. On the other hand, the backward propagation mechanism is only applicable to deep networks. In addition, explanations produced using this mechanism can be unreliable. Some of the more recent methods such as DeepLIFT and LRP promise to provide more robust explanations. However, DeepLIFT\u2019s performance depends significantly on the choice of its reference point, which must be determined by the user. Similarly, LRP has been shown to have numerical instability issues.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":52,\"end\":94,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.06104.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":397,\"end\":414,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1810.03292.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":550,\"end\":602,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.youtube.com\\u002Fwatch?v=f_iAM0NPwnM&list=PLJLjQOkqSRTP3cLB2cOOi_bQFw6KPGKML&index=3\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":686,\"end\":714,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fjournals.plos.org\\u002Fplosone\\u002Farticle\\u002Ffile?id=10.1371\\u002Fjournal.pone.0130140&type=printable\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_53.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":51,\"end\":52,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_54\",\"name\":\"9683\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Another approach to obtain post-hoc explanations for a complex model is to imitate it with a simpler and more explainable model with comparable performance, namely, the proxy mechanism. This mechanism is often applied to replace complex deep neural networks with more explainable models such as decision trees or decision rules. Early work in this category was only applicable to shallow neural networks. More recent methods, however, are aimed for deep neural network models. For example, the DeepRED approach, discussed earlier, is able to construct decision trees that faithfully represent a deep network model. However, the generated decision trees might be quite large, and thus not so explainable.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":361,\"end\":403,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fieeexplore.ieee.org\\u002Fdocument\\u002F938448\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":494,\"end\":510,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Flink.springer.com\\u002Fchapter\\u002F10.1007\\u002F978-3-319-46307-0_29\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_54.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":169,\"end\":186,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_55\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_55\",\"name\":\"1a88\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"One approach to alleviate this challenge is to learn proxy models that do not imitate the behaviour of a complex model globally. For example, the Anchors approach aims at extracting local decision rules that imitate only an instance prediction of a given model. Similarly, the BETA method learns a small number of decision sets, each of which imitates the behaviour of a given complex model within a well-defined region of its input feature space.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_55.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_55.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_55.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":146,\"end\":162,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fhomes.cs.washington.edu\\u002F~marcotcr\\u002Faaai18.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_55.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":277,\"end\":288,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1707.01154.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_56\",\"name\":\"d81b\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The activation optimization mechanism is often used to generate explanations of the inner workings of deep network models. Its explanations are obtained by searching for an input pattern that produces maximum (or minimum) response for an inner component of a model as the target, e.g. a specific neuron. This search problem can in turn be formulated as an optimization problem and solved using a gradient based approach. This procedure is similar to that used to train the model where the optimization targets are input features rather than model parameters.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":192,\"end\":230,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.sciencedirect.com\\u002Fscience\\u002Farticle\\u002Fpii\\u002FS1051200417302385\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":381,\"end\":419,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1312.6034.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":4,\"end\":27,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_56.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":28,\"end\":37,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:5ab1a6d6848b_57\":{\"id\":\"5ab1a6d6848b_57\",\"name\":\"7af2\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Unfortunately, without adding any regularization, the input patterns obtained using the activation optimization mechanism often resemble high frequency noise. Various families of regularization constraints have been proposed to alleviate this challenge. For instance, we can attempt to directly reduce the high-frequency noise by explicitly penalizing variance between neighbouring input features. However, such a regularization constraint could also suppress legitimate high-frequency features, e.g. edges in an input
