practice, however, simply adopting a model from an explainable family does not automatically guarantee explainability. For instance, a linear regression model that is operating on high dimensional input may not be simulatable, and hence, not explainable. To avoid this issue, we could limit the number of important input features during model training using some sort of regularization, e.g. L1 norm as in the Lasso regression. In addition, in the case of feature multicollinearity, that is, features that are correlated due to being caused by, either observed or unobserved confounding feature(s), the coefficients estimated for the linear regression model could be unstable. Further regularization, e.g. L2 norm, could be applied to alleviate this issue.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_10.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_10.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_10.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":206,\"end\":228,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1606.03490.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_10.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":704,\"end\":716,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.lexjansen.com\\u002Fwuss\\u002F2018\\u002F131_Final_Paper_PDF.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_11\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_11\",\"name\":\"2cb0\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Simply adopting a model from an explainable family does not automatically guarantee explainability.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_12\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_12\",\"name\":\"9b0e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"While some mitigations are available for specific methods, explainable model families are in general relatively simple and thus inadequate for capturing the complexity of some real-world problems. This observation has led to the so-called explainability vs performance tradeoff, namely, the more performant a model, the less explainable it is, and vice versa.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_12.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_12.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":239,\"end\":277,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.darpa.mil\\u002Fattachments\\u002FXAIProgramUpdate.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_13\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_13\",\"name\":\"1105\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*PAqdXEPjbjN7Nlsm\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"The alleged explainability vs performance tradeoff: the higher the model performance, the lower its explainability, and vice versa.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_13.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_13.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*PAqdXEPjbjN7Nlsm\":{\"id\":\"0*PAqdXEPjbjN7Nlsm\",\"originalHeight\":650,\"originalWidth\":864,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_13.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":12,\"end\":50,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.darpa.mil\\u002Fattachments\\u002FXAIProgramUpdate.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_13.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":131,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_14\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_14\",\"name\":\"6aff\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Yet a number of researchers have shown that the alleged explainability vs performance tradeoff does not always hold by developing models that are both explainable and performant. The main challenge when developing such a model is to devise it to be simple enough to be understood by its audience, yet sophisticated enough to properly fit the underlying data. There are a relatively large number of related methodologies in this category. So, we group them based on their key underlying, and possibly overlapping, ideas to make our presentation easier to follow.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_14.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_14.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":183,\"end\":197,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1901.04592.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_15\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_15\",\"name\":\"631e\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"A number of researchers have shown that the alleged explainability vs performance tradeoff does not always hold by developing models that are both explainable and performant.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_16\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_16\",\"name\":\"1128\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Hybrid explainable models\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_17\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_17\",\"name\":\"cc58\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"It might be possible to hybridize an inherently explainable modelling approach with a complex black-box method to devise a high-performance and explainable model. This is the underlying intuition of hybrid explainable models.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_18\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_18\",\"name\":\"7d5e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The deep k-Nearest Neighbours (DkNN) approach proposes to use K-nearest neighbour (kNN) inference on the hidden representation of training dataset learnt through layers of a deep network. The conformal prediction framework is then used to combine kNN predictions of all layers in a mathematically rigorous manner. The DkNN is shown to be efficient and robust while providing example-based explanations for its predictions in terms of nearest training samples used in each layer. However, DkNN requires storing hidden representation of the entire training dataset, which can be infeasible for large datasets.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_18.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_18.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":36,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1803.04765.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_19\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_19\",\"name\":\"5f2a\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Deep Weighted Averaging Classifier (DWAC) method resembles DkNN in terms of making its prediction, within the conformal prediction framework, by relying on labels of training samples similar to given input instance. However, the similarity is computed using only the low-dimensional representation of the final layer.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_19.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_19.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":46,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1811.02579.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_20\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_20\",\"name\":\"ca5b\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*nfsunJnA93P2ycrZ\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"The Deep k-Nearest Neighbors (DkNN) hybrid explainable modelling method: applying K-nearest neighbor (kNN) inference on the hidden representation of training dataset learnt through layers of a deep network.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_20.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_20.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*nfsunJnA93P2ycrZ\":{\"id\":\"0*nfsunJnA93P2ycrZ\",\"originalHeight\":601,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_20.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":35,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1803.04765.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_20.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":206,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_21\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_21\",\"name\":\"c967\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Another example is the Self-Explaining Neural Network (SENN). The key idea behind the SENN is to generalize a linear classifier by allowing its features, their corresponding coefficients, and the way they are aggregated into a prediction to be learned using three neural networks. These neural networks are referred to as concept encoder, relevance parameterizer, and aggregator, respectively. The resulting hybrid classifier is claimed to have the explainable structure of a linear model, and the expressive power and flexibility of a neural network. The SENN provides a flexible and appealing framework for learning hybrid explainable models. However, the preliminary work presented by the authors does not adequately address the challenge of learning high-level features using the concept encoder network. In particular, the authors acknowledge that these concepts should have an immediate human-understandable interpretation, which makes learning them a subjective task and difficult to quantify.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_21.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_21.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":23,\"end\":60,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.07538.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_22\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_22\",\"name\":\"5a51\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"As yet another example, consider the Contextual Explanation Networks (CEN) framework, which has some similarity with the SENN. The CEN assumes a learning problem where a prediction is to be made for an input in a given context. The idea is to first use a complex model to encode the context into parameter space of an inherently explainable model in a probabilistic manner. Then, the input is fed to this inherently explainable model to make a prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_22.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_22.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":37,\"end\":74,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1705.10301.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_23\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_23\",\"name\":\"9efa\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The BagNets architecture is yet another, and a very interesting, example of hybrid explainable models. The BagNets is basically a bag of features model where the features are learned using deep networks. For the task of image classification, it proposes to treat each image as a bag of features. This bag of features representation is obtained by dividing the image into patches that are passed through a deep network to obtain local class evidence for each patch. These local evidences are then summed together for each class and fed through a softmax function to obtain the overall probability for each class. Interestingly, when applied to the ImageNet dataset, BagNet yields a performance that is comparable to that of the state-of-the-art black-box deep network architectures, e.g. VGG-16, while remaining explainable by design.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_23.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_23.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":11,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fmedium.com\\u002Fbethgelab\\u002Fneural-networks-seem-to-follow-a-puzzlingly-simple-strategy-to-classify-images-f4229317261f\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_24\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_24\",\"name\":\"5305\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:1*MhaTR1OTz1BlWUiqheQ0nA.png\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"An overview of the deep bag of features model (BagNets) architecture: an input image is divided into small patches, which are passed through a deep network to obtain class evidences (logits) for each patch. These evidences are then fed into a linear classifier yielding one logit heatmap per class. Finally, these heatmaps are averaged spatially and fed to a softmax layer to produce the final class probabilities.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_24.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_24.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:1*MhaTR1OTz1BlWUiqheQ0nA.png\":{\"id\":\"1*MhaTR1OTz1BlWUiqheQ0nA.png\",\"originalHeight\":466,\"originalWidth\":576,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_24.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":19,\"end\":55,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fopenreview.net\\u002Fpdf?id=SkfMWhAqYQ\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_24.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":414,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_25\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_25\",\"name\":\"63d8\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Joint prediction and explanation\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_26\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_26\",\"name\":\"ab94\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"An AI model can be trained to jointly provide a prediction and the corresponding explanation. In other words, a complex model can be explicitly trained to provide an explanation for its prediction. Yet these approaches have several limitations, as we discuss below.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_27\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_27\",\"name\":\"00c4\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Teaching Explanations for Decisions (TED) framework, for instance, proposes to augment training dataset where each sample includes a set of features, a decision, and user\u2019s rationale for that decision, an explanation. The given decision and its explanation are encoded into a single label at training time. At test time, output provided by the model is decoded to produce a decision and its corresponding explanation. The TED framework is claimed to have several advantages including producing explanations that match the mental model of end users, and being widely applicable.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_27.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_27.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":55,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1811.04896.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_28\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_28\",\"name\":\"0625\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*o_pUb76unsPIGXQG\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"The TED (Teaching Explanations for Decisions) framework for explainable modelling through joint prediction and explanation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_28.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_28.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*o_pUb76unsPIGXQG\":{\"id\":\"0*o_pUb76unsPIGXQG\",\"originalHeight\":548,\"originalWidth\":1318,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_28.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":45,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1811.04896.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_28.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":123,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_29\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_29\",\"name\":\"4eac\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Park et al. propose a modelling approach to generate multimodal explanations. Their solution is similar to the TED as it requires a training dataset augmented with both visual and textual explanations. To evaluate their approach the authors collect two novel datasets augmented with such multi-modal explanations for activity recognition and visual question answering tasks. Their experiments show that incorporating multi-modal explanations leads to improved predictive performance.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_29.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_29.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":53,\"end\":76,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fexport.arxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1802.08129\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_30\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_30\",\"name\":\"e37a\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The methods mentioned above have two main shortcomings. First, they assume availability of explanations in training dataset, which is often not the case. Second, explanations generated by these methods are not necessarily reflective of how model predictions were made but rather what humans would like to see as explanation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_31\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_31\",\"name\":\"dce6\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Some methods in this category do not require explanations for each prediction in a training dataset. For instance, Hendricks et al. propose a visual explanation generation approach for the task of object recognition in images using deep networks. Their method requires only a textual description of images and their class label at train time in order to generate class-specific visual explanation of an image predictions at test time.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_31.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_31.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":142,\"end\":160,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fexport.arxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1603.08507\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_32\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_32\",\"name\":\"1e8a\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The Rationalizing Neural Predictions by Lei et al. is another example. Their proposed NLP model is made of two components, namely, a generator and an encoder, which are trained together. The former specifies a distribution over fragments of input text as candidate explanations (aka rationales by the authors), which are then passed to the latter to map into a prediction. Importantly, these rationales are discovered, and not provided, during training. This is achieved only by enforcing two requirements, namely, they must be short and coherent pieces of text and they must suffice on their own as a substitute of the original text for the given prediction task. As the encoder relies on the rationales generated by the generator to make predictions, their approach does not suffer from either of two shortcomings mentioned earlier. However, providing rationales only is not adequate to allow end user to simulate the prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_32.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_32.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_32.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":4,\"end\":36,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fpeople.csail.mit.edu\\u002Ftaolei\\u002Fpapers\\u002Femnlp16_rationale.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_32.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":844,\"end\":885,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.06178.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_33\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_33\",\"name\":\"bd62\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explainability through architectural adjustments\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_34\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_34\",\"name\":\"f0aa\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Methods in this category enhance model explainability by making adjustments to model architecture. In addition, they are exclusively focused on deep network architectures.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_35\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_35\",\"name\":\"b303\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"For instance, Zhang et al. develop an explainable convolutional neural network architecture that can automatically push representations of higher layer filters to be an object part, as opposed to a mixture of patterns. This is achieved by adding a specific loss function, which is applied to feature maps of filters in conventional convolutional networks. This loss function favours specific object parts of a class category and keeps silent on images of other class categories. Importantly, no object part annotation data is required by this approach. The explainable convolutional networks trained using this approach are shown to encode more semantically meaningful knowledge in their high layer filters than traditional convolutional networks. Moreover, in terms of prediction performance, explainable convolutional networks compared favourably, to their unexplainable counterpart models, for single-category classification problem, and even outperformed them for multi-category classification problem.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_35.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_35.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":38,\"end\":78,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fopenaccess.thecvf.com\\u002Fcontent_cvpr_2018\\u002Fpapers\\u002FZhang_Interpretable_Convolutional_Neural_CVPR_2018_paper.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_36\",\"name\":\"46a6\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Another example is the This Looks Like That explainable deep architecture proposed by Chen et al. This architecture is inspired by how humans describe their own reasoning for classification in terms of comparison of image parts to a set of learned image part prototypes. The authors propose adding a prototype layer to conventional convolutional networks that sits between the convolutional layers and the fully connected layer. The prototype layer contains a preset number of image part prototypes for each class. Each class-specific protype is meant to capture the most relevant parts or semantic concepts for identifying images of a given class. The prototype layer parameters along with conventional convolutional layers\u2019 parameters are learned together using a special loss function. Next, the weights of the fully connected layer are learned using a sparse convex optimization approach. The experimental results for two image classification tasks show that the proposed explainable deep network yields a performance comparable to that of unexplainable deep models.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":23,\"end\":43,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.10574.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":23,\"end\":27,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_36.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":39,\"end\":43,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_37\",\"name\":\"15de\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*yE-snpxCPSy9FGmP\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"An overview of the This Looks Like That explainable deep network architecture: The key idea is to add a prototype layer to conventional convolutional networks. The prototype layer contains a preset number of image part prototypes for each class. Each class-specific protype is meant to capture the most relevant parts or semantic concepts for identifying images of a given class.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*yE-snpxCPSy9FGmP\":{\"id\":\"0*yE-snpxCPSy9FGmP\",\"originalHeight\":483,\"originalWidth\":1176,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":19,\"end\":39,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1806.10574.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":379,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":19,\"end\":24,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_37.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":35,\"end\":39,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_38\",\"name\":\"34fa\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Attention mechanisms aim at identifying the most relevant parts of an input for a given task. Typically, this relevance is characterized by a set of weights\\u002Fscores assigned to input parts, namely, attention map. Many varieties of the attention mechanisms exist. Attention-based models are commonly used in various NLP, vision, and time series modelling tasks and are claimed to afford some level of explainability. Deep network architectures that incorporate some form of attention, often to increase model performance, are sometimes considered explainable models.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":217,\"end\":254,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Flilianweng.github.io\\u002Flil-log\\u002F2018\\u002F06\\u002F24\\u002Fattention-attention.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":314,\"end\":317,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1811.05544.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":319,\"end\":325,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1704.03549.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_38.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":331,\"end\":342,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1608.05745.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_39\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_39\",\"name\":\"4f3c\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"However, a recent formal study on attention as an explainability mechanism has found little evidence to support this long-held belief. In other words, attention may not constitute an explanation. An extensive set of experiments across various NLPs tasks shows that attention maps are only weakly correlated with gradient-based measures of feature importance. In addition, it is often possible to identify very different set of attention maps that result in the same prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_39.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_39.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":151,\"end\":194,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1902.10186.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_40\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_40\",\"name\":\"4557\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Explainability through regularization\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_41\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_41\",\"name\":\"c6b6\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Various regularization methods are often used to improve predictive performance of AI models. However, regularization can also be used to improve explainability of a model.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_42\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_42\",\"name\":\"6037\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"For instance, Wu et al. present Tree Regularization to enhance explainability of deep networks. The key idea is to encourage learning a model whose decision boundary can be well-approximated using a small decision tree, hence making its predictions simulatable by humans. This is achieved by adding a novel regularization term to the loss function used to train the model. Their experimental results for several real-world tasks show models developed using this approach to be more explainable without sacrificing predictive performance.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_42.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_42.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":32,\"end\":51,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1711.06178.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_43\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_43\",\"name\":\"3951\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In addition, there is a growing body of work on using regularization to explicitly constrain explanations of models predictions to ensure they are right for better reasons.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_44\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_44\",\"name\":\"33d8\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Ross et al. propose a framework to constrain local explanations of model predictions to match domain knowledge during training. They consider input gradients as the first-order linear approximation of model behaviour locally, that is, first-order explanation for a given model input. The domain knowledge is assumed to be encoded as a binary annotation matrix, which specifies whether each feature should be used to make a prediction for each input. The loss function used to train the model is then augmented with a novel term to penalize input gradients that do not match this annotation matrix. Their experimental results show models trained with their approach generalize much better when training and testing on datasets that differ significantly.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_44.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_44.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":35,\"end\":63,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1703.03717.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_45\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_45\",\"name\":\"bbc3\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"There is a growing body of work on using regularization to explicitly constrain explanations of models predictions to ensure they are right for better reasons.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_46\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_46\",\"name\":\"51fa\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"A method with similar characteristics to that of Ross et al. called Saliency Learning has been proposed by Ghaeini et al. Saliency learning includes expert annotations that focus on relevant parts of input, as opposed to irrelevant parts, as well as annotations at the word embedding level, as opposed to input dimension level. Experiments performed on several tasks using simulated explanations show models trained using Saliency Learning provide more accurate and reliable predictions.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_46.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_46.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":68,\"end\":85,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1902.08649.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_47\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_47\",\"name\":\"8ba6\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Other methodologies\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_48\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_48\",\"name\":\"aea9\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"There are a number of other noteworthy explainable modelling methodologies. The Certifiable Optimal RulE ListS (CORELS) approach proposed by Angelino et al. is an appealing choice, as it provides a solution for discovering optimal rule lists for minimizing empirical risk of given training data. In addition, the CORELS is shown to be fast and comes with an easy-to-use software implementation. Its main limitation, however, is being able to deal with categorical data only.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_48.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_48.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_48.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":80,\"end\":119,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.jmlr.org\\u002Fpapers\\u002Fvolume18\\u002F17-716\\u002F17-716.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_48.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":370,\"end\":393,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fcorels.eecs.harvard.edu\\u002Fcorels\\u002Finstall.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_49\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_49\",\"name\":\"7ee6\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"What\u2019s next?\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_50\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_50\",\"name\":\"6907\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Model explainability is often dealt with as an afterthought. In other words, some post-modelling explainability method is used to extract explanations for a pre-developed model. This is partially due to the alleged explainability vs performance tradeoff. However, we presented a growing and diverse set of methodologies that demonstrate the possibility of developing models that are both explainable and performant. Further research on explainable modelling will provide more solid evidence to support this possibility in the future.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_51\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_51\",\"name\":\"0e6f\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Currently, the bulk of XAI research is focused on post-modelling explainability methodologies, The next and final part of this series explores the related literature in this domain based on a novel taxonomy.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_51.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_51.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":108,\"end\":118,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fmedium.com\\u002F@bahador.khaleghi\\u002Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-post-modelling-explainability-8b4cbc7adf5f\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:6080e377587d_52\":{\"id\":\"6080e377587d_52\",\"name\":\"5490\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Special thanks to Xavier Snelgrove, Elnaz Barshan, Lindsay Brin, Santiago Salcido, and Manon Gruaz for valuable comments and illustrations. fg\">\n           <div class=\"o n\">\n            <div>\n             <a href=\"/@mazzanti.sam?source=post_page-----ab81cc69ef30----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n              <img <div class=\"fk ai r\">\n             <div class=\"n\">\n              <div style=\"flex:1\">\n               <span class=\"aq b ar as at au r dt q\">\n                <div class=\"fl n o fm\">\n                 <span class=\"aq cl fn as br fo fp fq fr fs dt\">\n                  <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg ft bj bk fu fv\" href=\"/@mazzanti.sam?source=post_page-----ab81cc69ef30----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                   Samuele Mazzanti\n                  </a>\n                 </span>\n                 <div class=\"fw r an h\">\n                  <a class=\"fx dt q fy fz ga gb gc bg fu gd ge gf gg gh gi gj aq b ar gk cm au gl gm df gn go bj\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fshap-explained-the-way-i-wish-someone-explained-it-to-me-ab81cc69ef30&amp;source=-e16f3bb86e03-------------------------follow_byline-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                   Follow\n                  </a>\n                 </div>\n                </div>\n               </span>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n             <span class=\"aq b ar as at au r av aw\">\n              <span class=\"aq cl fn as br fo fp fq fr fs av\">\n               <div>\n                <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg ft bj bk fu fv\" href=\"/shap-explained-the-way-i-wish-someone-explained-it-to-me-ab81cc69ef30?source=post_page-----ab81cc69ef30----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                 Jan 4\n                </a>\n                <!-- -->\n                \u00b7\n                <!-- -->\n                <!-- -->\n                7\n                <!-- -->\n                min read\n                <span style=\"padding-left:4px\">\n                 <svg class=\"star-15px_svg__svgIcon-use\" height=\"15\" style=\"margin-top:-2px\" viewbox=\"0 0 15 15\" width=\"15\">\n                  <path d=\"M7.44 2.32c.03-.1.09-.1.12 0l1.2 3.53a.29.29 0 0 0 .26.2h3.88c.11 0 .13.04.04.1L9.8 8.33a.27.27 0 0 0-.1.29l1.2 3.53c.03.1-.01.13-.1.07l-3.14-2.18a.3.3 0 0 0-.32 0L4.2 12.22c-.1.06-.14.03-.1-.07l1.2-3.53a.27.27 0 0 0-.1-.3L2.06 6.16c-.1-.06-.07-.12.03-.12h3.89a.29.29 0 0 0 .26-.19l1.2-3.52z\">\n                  </path>\n                 </svg>\n                </span>\n               </div>\n              </span>\n             </span>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"n gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw y\">\n            <div class=\"n o\">\n             <div class=\"gx r an\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gy gz bj bk fu fv\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ab81cc69ef30/share/twitter?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\"
