4.3 0 0 1-2.02-.57v.08a4.55 4.55 0 0 0 3.63 4.44c-.4.08-.8.13-1.21.16l-.81-.08a4.54 4.54 0 0 0 4.2 3.15 9.56 9.56 0 0 1-5.66 1.94l-1.05-.08c2 1.27 4.38 2.02 6.94 2.02 8.3 0 12.86-6.9 12.84-12.85.02-.24 0-.43 0-.65a8.68 8.68 0 0 0 2.26-2.34c-.82.38-1.7.62-2.6.72a4.37 4.37 0 0 0 1.95-2.51c-.84.53-1.81.9-2.83 1.13z\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gx r an\">\n              <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gy gz bj bk fu fv\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\" height=\"29\" viewbox=\"0 0 29 29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M5 6.36C5 5.61 5.63 5 6.4 5h16.2c.77 0 1.4.61 1.4 1.36v16.28c0 .75-.63 1.36-1.4 1.36H6.4c-.77 0-1.4-.6-1.4-1.36V6.36z\">\n                </path>\n                <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 1.48h.01zM12.35 20.9h2.87v-4.79c0-.25.02-.5.1-.7.2-.5.67-1.04 1.46-1.04 1.04 0 1.46.8 1.46 1.95v4.59h2.87v-4.92c0-2.64-1.42-3.87-3.3-3.87-1.55 0-2.23.86-2.61 1.45h.02v-1.24h-2.87c.04.8 0 8.58 0 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </button>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gx r an\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gy gz bj bk fu fv\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ab81cc69ef30/share/facebook?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"ha r\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gy gz bj bk fu fv\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fshap-explained-the-way-i-wish-someone-explained-it-to-me-ab81cc69ef30&amp;source=post_actions_header--------------------------bookmark_header-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n                <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 5.66 4.13a.5.5 0 0 0 .71-.03.5.5 0 0 0 .12-.29H19V6zm-6.84 9.97L7 19.64V6a1 1 0 0 1 1-1h9a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v13.64l-5.16-3.67a.49.49 0 0 0-.68 0z\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"hb r am\">\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd hc\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"hu r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"486\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png?q=20\" width=\"790\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"486\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 700w\" width=\"790\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"486\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1580/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*_gSI1LZituR9QuMgxNARVQ.png 700w\" width=\"790\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"ce4b\">\n          Demystifying the demystifier\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"cd65\">\n          In a previous post (\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"/black-box-models-are-actually-more-explainable-than-a-logistic-regression-f263c22795d\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Black-Box models are actually more explainable than a Logistic Regression\n          </a>\n          ) we saw how SHAP values can be used to interpret the decisions taken by any machine learning methods. In other words, we used SHAP to demystify a black-box model.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"48d8\">\n          So far, we exploited the\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"https://github.com/slundberg/shap\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP library for Python\n          </a>\n          without worrying too much about how it works.\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           Ironically enough, we used SHAP as a black-box itself!\n          </strong>\n          However, understanding the idea behind the calculation of SHAP values is crucial to make sense of their outcome.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"b57f\">\n          This is why, in this post, we will go through the theoretical foundation of SHapley Additive exPlanations described in the\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07874\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           article\n          </a>\n          by Slundberg and Lee, and see why SHAP values are computed the way they are computed.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"66d3\">\n          Game theory and machine learning\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"c784\">\n          SHAP values are based on Shapley values, a concept coming from game theory. But game theory needs at least two things: a game and some players. How does this apply to machine learning explainability? Imagine that we have a predictive model, then:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw jh ji jj\" id=\"81f7\">\n           <strong class=\"in jg\">\n            the \u201cgame\u201d is reproducing the outcome of the model\n           </strong>\n           ,\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"cdff\">\n           <strong class=\"in jg\">\n            the \u201cplayers\u201d are the features included in the model\n           </strong>\n           .\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"eb3e\">\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           What Shapley does is quantifying the contribution that each player brings to the game. What SHAP does is quantifying the contribution that each feature brings to the prediction made by the model\n          </strong>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"fba5\">\n          It is important to stress that what we called a \u201cgame\u201d concerns a single observation.\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           One game: one observation\n          </strong>\n          . Indeed, SHAP is about local interpretability of a predictive model.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"920b\">\n          A power set of features\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"bd37\">\n          By way of example, we will imagine a machine learning model (let\u2019s say a linear regression, but it could be any other machine learning algorithm) that predicts the income of a person knowing age, gender and job of the person.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"888a\">\n          Shapley values are based on the idea that the outcome of\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           each possible combination (or coalition) of players should be considered to determine the importance of a single player\n          </strong>\n          . In our case, this corresponds to each possible combination of\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          features (\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          going from 0 to\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          ,\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          being the number of all features available, in our example 3).\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"ed8b\">\n          In math, this is called a \u201c\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_set\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           power set\n          </a>\n          \u201d and can be represented as a tree.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jq\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"jr r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png?q=20\" width=\"708\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 700w\" width=\"708\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1416/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*GOwxZ1ApAidTIDoa2l98ew.png 700w\" width=\"708\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fn js jt ju de dc dd jv jw aq cl\">\n           Power set of features\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"cfda\">\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           Each node represents a coalition of features. Each edge represents the inclusion of a feature not present in the previous coalition\n          </strong>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"c2d8\">\n          We know from math that the cardinality of a power set is 2 ^\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           n\n          </em>\n          , where\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           n\n          </em>\n          is the number of elements of the original set. Indeed, in our case, we have 2 ^\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          = 2 ^ 3 = 8 possible coalitions of features.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"338b\">\n          Now,\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           SHAP requires to train a distinct predictive model for each distinct coalition in the power set, meaning 2 ^\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            F\n           </em>\n           models\n          </strong>\n          . Of course, these models are completely equivalent to each other for what concerns their hyperparameters and their training data. The only thing that changes is the set of features included in the model.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"406c\">\n          Let us imagine that we have already trained our 8 linear regression models on the same training data. We can then take a new observation (let us call it\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          ) and see what the 8 different models predict for the same observation\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jx\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"jy r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png?q=20\" width=\"707\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 700w\" width=\"707\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1414/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*9oHGJ9kAMaUUEYtnfKKKEA.png 700w\" width=\"707\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fn js jt ju de dc dd jv jw aq cl\">\n           Predictions made by different models for\n           <em class=\"jz\">\n            x\u2080.\n           </em>\n           In each node, the first row reports the coalition of features included in the model, the second row reports the income predicted for\n           <em class=\"jz\">\n            x\u2080\n           </em>\n           by that model.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"1622\">\n          Here,\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           each node represents a model\n          </strong>\n          . But what do edges represent?\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"1b60\">\n          Building SHAP formula (1/2) \u2014 Marginal contributions of a feature\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"e335\">\n          As seen above, two nodes connected by an edge differ for just one feature, in the sense that the bottom one has exactly the same features of the upper one plus an additional feature that the upper one did not have. Therefore,\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           the gap between the predictions of two connected nodes can be imputed to the effect of that additional feature. This is called \u201cmarginal contribution\u201d of a feature\n          </strong>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"eef7\">\n          Therefore,\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           each edge represents the marginal contribution brought by a feature to a model\n          </strong>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"350d\">\n          Imagine that we are in node 1, which is the model with no features. This model will simply predict the average income of all the training observations (50k $). If we move to node 2, which is a model with just one feature (Age), the prediction for\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          is now 40k $. This means that knowing the age of\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          has lowered our prediction by 10k $.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"697f\">\n          Thus, the marginal contribution brought by Age to the model containing only Age as a feature is -10k $. In formula:\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd ka\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"kb r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"55\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png?q=20\" width=\"1539\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"55\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 700w\" width=\"1539\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"55\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3078/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*buYfUtthXqbHWtGguF22VQ.png 700w\" width=\"1539\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"0853\">\n          Of course, to obtain the overall effect of Age on the final model (i.e. the SHAP value of Age for\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          ) it is necessary to consider\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           the marginal contribution of Age in all the models where Age is present\n          </strong>\n          . In our tree representation, this means to consider all the edges connecting two nodes such that:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw jh ji jj\" id=\"5b51\">\n           the upper one does not contain Age, and\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"4d47\">\n           the bottom one contains Age.\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"31bc\">\n          In the following figure, such edges have been highlighted in red.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jq\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"jr r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png?q=20\" width=\"708\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 700w\" width=\"708\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"441\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1416/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*7keBLSQszepu5jITz8SKxA.png 700w\" width=\"708\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fn js jt ju de dc dd jv jw aq cl\">\n           Marginal contributions of Age\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"0aee\">\n          All these marginal contributions are then aggregated through a weighted average. In formula:\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kc\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"kd r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"234\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png?q=20\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"234\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"234\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3072/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*QpRB2gX5uJVU2cWRkrNvsA.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"56a5\">\n          where\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           w\u2081+w\u2082 +w\u2083+w\u2084=\n          </em>\n          1.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"ecbe\">\n          Building SHAP formula (2/2) \u2014 Weighing the marginal contributions\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"0540\">\n          But how do we determine the weights of the edges (i.e. of the marginal contiributions of Age in the 4 models)?\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"5ab1\">\n          The idea is that:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw jh ji jj\" id=\"42ae\">\n           <strong class=\"in jg\">\n            the sum of the weights of all the marginal contributions to 1-feature-models should equal the sum of the weights of all the marginal contributions to 2-feature-models and so on...\n           </strong>\n           In other words, the sum of all the weights on the same \u201crow\u201d should equal the sum of all the weights on any other \u201crow\u201d.\n           <br/>\n           In our example, this implies:\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2081 = w\u2082 + w\u2083 = w\u2084.\n           </em>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"7d53\">\n           <strong class=\"in jg\">\n            All the weights of marginal contributions to\n            <em class=\"jp\">\n             f\n            </em>\n            -feature-models should equal to each other, for each\n            <em class=\"jp\">\n             f\n            </em>\n           </strong>\n           . In other words, all the edges on the same \u201crow\u201d should equal to each other.\n           <br/>\n           In our example, this means:\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2082 = w\u2083.\n           </em>\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"7484\">\n          Therefore, (keeping in mind that they should sum to 1) the solution is:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw jh ji jj\" id=\"2570\">\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2081\n           </em>\n           = 1/3\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"570b\">\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2082 =\n           </em>\n           1/6\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"69e8\">\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2083\n           </em>\n           = 1/6\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"c5f2\">\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            w\u2084\n           </em>\n           = 1/3\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"e18e\">\n          Looking at the figure above, can you guess the pattern for determining weights in a general framework?\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"3e3a\">\n          Spoiler: the weight of an edge is the reciprocal of the total number of edges in the same \u201crow\u201d. Or, equivalently,\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           the weight of a marginal contribution to a\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            f\n           </em>\n           -feature-model is the reciprocal of the number of possible marginal contributions to all the\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            f\n           </em>\n           -feature-models\n          </strong>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"d02d\">\n          Is there a formula to calculate this? It is straightforward, actually.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"470d\">\n          Each\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          -feature-model has\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          marginal contributions (one per feature), so it is enough to count the number of possible\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          -feature-models and to multiply it by\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          . Thus, the problem boils down to counting the number of possible\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          -feature-models, given\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          and knowing that the total number of feature is\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          . This is simply the definition of binomial coefficient.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"a61f\">\n          Putting things together, we have that the number of all the marginal contributions of all the\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          -feature-models \u2014 in other words, the number of edges in each \u201crow\u201d \u2014 is:\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kc\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"ke r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"120\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png?q=20\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"120\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"120\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3072/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*Wa7mMf4KR8Lh9bPXdtzM8g.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"26cd\">\n          It is enough to take the reciprocal of this and we have the weight of a marginal contribution to a\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           f\n          </em>\n          -feature-model.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"a319\">\n          This is exemplified in the figure below:\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kf\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"kg r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"588\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png?q=20\" width=\"915\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"588\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 700w\" width=\"915\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"588\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1830/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*wOLS6BO2vGTSB4sCoAb6fQ.png 700w\" width=\"915\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fn js jt ju de dc dd jv jw aq cl\">\n           How weigths are obtained from the number of edges\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"dca6\">\n          Now, we have all the elements required for calculating the SHAP value of Age for\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           x\u2080\n          </em>\n          :\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kh\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"ki r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"694\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png?q=20\" width=\"1571\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"694\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 700w\" width=\"1571\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"694\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3142/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*AwrLs6-GRrruYZ4euTUQmA.png 700w\" width=\"1571\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"d4e8\">\n          Wrapping it up\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"5f3c\">\n          We have built the formula for calculating the SHAP value of Age in a 3-feature-model. Generalizing to any feature and any\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          , we obtain the formula reported in the\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07874\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           article\n          </a>\n          by Slundberg and Lee:\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"hd he hf hg hh hi dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hj hk hl hm ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kc\">\n            <div class=\"hs r hl ht\">\n             <div class=\"kj r\">\n              <div class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai br hq hr\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai hv hw hx\" height=\"134\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png?q=20\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hn ho s t u hp ai hy\" height=\"134\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hp ai\" height=\"134\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3072/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*U4yqx7idwCpWznTcP9Ntqg.png 700w\" width=\"1536\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"1c06\">\n          Applied on our example, the formula yields:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw jh ji jj\" id=\"1582\">\n           SHAP_Age(\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            x\u2080\n           </em>\n           ) = -11.33k $\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"5bd9\">\n           SHAP_Gender(\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            x\u2080\n           </em>\n           ) = -2.33k $\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im dt ar in b em jk eo jl iq jm is jn iu jo iw jh ji jj\" id=\"0aeb\">\n           SHAP_Job(\n           <em class=\"jp\">\n            x\u2080\n           </em>\n           ) = +46.66k $\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"c1c4\">\n          Summing them up gives +33k $, which is exactly the difference between the output of the full model (83k $) and the output of the dummy model with no features (50k $).\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"10ba\">\n          This is a fundamental characteristic of SHAP values:\n          <strong class=\"in jg\">\n           summing the SHAP values of each feature of a given observation yields the difference between the prediction of the model and the null model\n          </strong>\n          (or its logistic function, as we have seen\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"/black-box-models-are-actually-more-explainable-than-a-logistic-regression-f263c22795d\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           here\n          </a>\n          ). This is actually the reason for their name: SHapley Additive exPlanations.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia dt ar aq ib dv ic dx id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"14d6\">\n          Great! Now I can calculate SHAP values by myself\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em io eo ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"0577\">\n          Err\u2026 No!\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"a254\">\n          As seen above, the original SHAP formula requires to train 2 ^\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          models. For a model with just 50 features, this would mean to train 1e15 models! Indeed, as\n          <em class=\"jp\">\n           F\n          </em>\n          increases, the formula seen above becomes inapplicable soon.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im dt ar in b em jb eo jc iq jd is je iu jf iw dl\" id=\"292f\">\n          However, libraries such as\n          <a class=\"cq go ix iy iz ja\" href=\"https://github.com/slundberg/shap\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           the one by Slundberg\n          </a>\n          employ some brilliant approximations and samplings (I will treat the topic in a follow-up post) that make the job feasible.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n    </article>\n    <div class=\"hn dk kk kl ai ks kq kt\" data-test-id=\"post-sidebar\">\n     <div class=\"n p\">\n      <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n       <div class=\"ku n dg\">\n        <div class=\"dk\">\n         <div class=\"kv kw r\">\n          <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gy gz bj bk fu fv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=post_sidebar--------------------------post_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n           <h2 class=\"aq ib kx as dt\">\n            Towards Data Science\n           </h2>\n          </a>\n          <div class=\"ky kz r\">\n           <h4 class=\"aq cl fn as br la fp fq lb fs av\">\n            A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas, href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fshap-explained-the-way-i-wish-someone-explained-it-to-me-ab81cc69ef30&amp;source=post_sidebar--------------------------follow_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            Follow\n           </a>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"lf lg lh n\">\n          <div class=\"n o\">\n           <div class=\"li r hl\">\n    <div class=\"s u dh di dj dk\">\n      </div>\n      <section class=\"dl dm dn do dp\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <figure class=\"ds dt      <div class=\"ec ed s t u ee ai br ef eg\">\n               <img class=\"s t u ee ai ek el em\" height=\"627\" role=\"presentation\" <h1 class=\"er b es fd eu fe ew ff ey fg fa fh eq\">\n            Correlation is not causation\n           </h1>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"fi ep av ar aq cl fj fk fl fm business management\n          </h2>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"fz\">\n          <div class=\"n ga gb gc gd\">\n           <div class=\"o n\">\n            <div>\n             <a               </path>\n                <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg hv hw bj bk gr gs\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ae05d03c1f53/share/facebook?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"hx r\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg hv hw bj bk gr gs\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fcorrelation-is-not-causation-ae05d03c1f53&amp;source=post_actions_header--------------------------bookmark_header-\" </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"hy r am\">\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia eq ar aq ib es ic eu id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"f902\">\n          Introduction\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"74c1\">\n          In correlated data, a pair of variables are related in that one thing is likely to change when the other does. This relationship might lead us to assume that a change to one thing causes the change in the other. This article clarifies that kind of faulty thinking by explaining correlation, causation, and the bias that often lumps the two together.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"0983\">\n          The human brain simplifies incoming information, so we can make sense of it. Our brains often do that by making assumptions about things based on slight relationships, or bias. But that thinking process isn\u2019t foolproof. An example is when we mistake correlation for causation. Bias can make us conclude that one thing must cause another if both change in the same way at the same time. This article clears up the misconception that correlation equals causation by exploring both of those subjects and the human brain\u2019s tendency toward bias.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia eq ar aq ib es ic eu id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"d411\">\n          About correlation and causation\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"f57c\">\n          Correlation is a relationship or connection between two variables where whenever one changes, the other is likely to also change. But a change in one variable doesn\u2019t cause the other to change. That\u2019s a correlation, but it\u2019s not causation. Your growth from a child to an adult is an example. When your height increased, your mass increased too. Getting taller didn\u2019t make you also get wider. Instead, maturing to adulthood caused both variables to increase \u2014 that\u2019s causation.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"394d\">\n          Causation in business\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"401c\">\n          Let\u2019s say that we want to offer a promotion or discount to some of our customers. Our marketing department wants to maximize the delta, in other words, the increase in sales as a result of the promotion. So we need to decide which customers will give us the best return on our investment in the promotion or discount. Do we want to offer it only to our top 10% of your clients? Or the bottom 10%?\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"e282\">\n          You might assume that the users who drive more sales are the ones more responsible for your business success. However, this assumption could be wrong. The best choice of which customers to offer the promotion to might be totally different. In the absence of valid experimentation or analytics, you don\u2019t have accurate answers to those questions.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"420c\">\n          Cognitive bias\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"d719\">\n          There are many forms of cognitive bias or irrational thinking patterns that often lead to faulty conclusions and economic decisions. These types of cognitive bias are some reasons why people assume false causations in business and marketing:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw jo jp jq\" id=\"e751\">\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            Confirmation bias.\n           </strong>\n           People want to be right. They often can\u2019t admit or accept that they\u2019re wrong about something, even if that attitude causes eventual harm and loss.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"b7a1\">\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            The illusion of causality.\n           </strong>\n           Putting too much weight on your own personal beliefs, over-confidence, and other unproven sources of information often produce an illusion of casualty. An economic example is the recent U.S. housing bubble. Millions of people believed that buying a home for much more than its actual value would continue to result in a return on the investment just because that happened in the past.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"fc30\">\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            Money.\n           </strong>\n           You want to sell your product. You might spend more than your return on investment (ROI) on marketing and other business expenses if the desire to make money clouds your logic.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"8404\">\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            Major marketing implications.\n           </strong>\n           Marketing statistics and data are often complicated and confusing. It can be easy to see relationships between changing sales numbers and the many other variables in your business when no causation exists.\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"2c1a\">\n          Experimentation\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"cc62\">\n          To know that something is valuable takes experimentation. Experimentation helps you understand if you\u2019re making the right choices. But it has a cost. If you hold a workgroup back by not giving them a feature that brings in value, you\u2019ll lose money. But you\u2019ll learn the importance of that feature.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"789e\">\n          The value of an experiment lies in the accomplishment of these two things:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw jo jp jq\" id=\"4b55\">\n           Decide between different choices.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"450d\">\n           Quantify the value of the best choice.\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"d5e1\">\n          Experimental variables\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"2c5e\">\n          A scientifically valid experiment needs to have three types of variables: controlled, independent, and dependent:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw jo jp jq\" id=\"822f\">\n           A\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            controlled\n           </strong>\n           variable is kept constant, so other variables that change in relation to each other can be measured in a static environment.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"3693\">\n           An experiment\u2019s\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            independent\n           </strong>\n           variable is the only one that can be changed.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"il im eq ar in b fj js fl jt iq ju is jv iu jw iw jo jp jq\" id=\"a09e\">\n           <strong class=\"in jr\">\n            Dependent\n           </strong>\n           variables are the results that are observed when changes are made to independent variables.\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"51d2\">\n          Any\n          <strong class=\"in jr\">\n           uncontrolled\n          </strong>\n          variables, or mediator variables, can cloud an experiment\u2019s accuracy. So they need to be identified and eliminated in order to properly assess the experiment\u2019s results. Differences in uncontrolled variables can also impact the relationship between independent and dependent variables.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"3fde\">\n          Uncontrolled variables add the influence of unrelated factors to an experiment\u2019s results. Correlations might be assumed, and an hypothesis might be formed where none exist. Accurate analysis becomes difficult or impossible. Examples of conclusions draw from uncontrolled variables are shown in the children\u2019s music lessons and mobile phone cancer examples that follow.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"5305\">\n          How our brain tricks us\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"90c2\">\n          It\u2019s easy to watch correlated data change in tandem and assume that one thing causes the other. That\u2019s because our brains are wired for cause-relation cognitive bias. We need to make sense of large amounts of incoming data, so our brain simplifies it. This process is called heuristics, and it\u2019s often useful and accurate. But not always. An example of where heuristics goes wrong is whenever you believe that correlation implies causation.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"251a\">\n          Spurious correlations\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"646b\">\n          It is a mathematical relationship in which two or more events or variables are associated but not causally related, due to either coincidence or the presence of a certain third, unseen factor\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"jy jz ka kb kc dx dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"dy dz ea eb ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jx\">\n            <div class=\"eh r ea ei\">\n             <div class=\"kd r\">\n              <div class=\"ec ed s t u ee ai br ef eg\">\n               <img class=\"s t u ee ai ek el em\" height=\"612\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png?q=20\" width=\"859\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ec ed s t u ee ai en\" height=\"612\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 700w\" width=\"859\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u ee ai\" height=\"612\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1718/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*NaXGm0CE6EVEa5FDWAZlDQ.png 700w\" width=\"859\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"34fc\">\n          Children and music lessons\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"e3d2\">\n          After a study of human brain development, researchers concluded that kids between 4 and 6 years old who took music lessons showed evidence of boosted brain development in the areas related to memory and attention. Based on this study, our biased brain might connect the dots quickly and conclude that music lessons improve brain development. But there are other variables to consider. The fact that the children took music lessons is an indicator of wealth. So they probably had access to other resources that are known to boost brain development like good nutrition.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"4619\">\n          The point of this example is that researchers can\u2019t assume from only this much data that music lessons affect brain development. Yes, there\u2019s clearly a correlation, but there\u2019s no actual evidence of causation. We need more data to get a true causal explanation.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"3f64\">\n          Cancer and mobile phones\n         </h2>\n         <figure class=\"jy jz ka kb kc dx dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"dy dz ea eb ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd ke\">\n            <div class=\"eh r ea ei\">\n             <div class=\"kf r\">\n              <div class=\"ec ed s t u ee ai br ef eg\">\n               <img class=\"s t u ee ai ek el em\" height=\"317\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png?q=20\" width=\"975\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ec ed s t u ee ai en\" height=\"317\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 700w\" width=\"975\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u ee ai\" height=\"317\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1950/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*lwmhdOY09TCO_JfZxLVvaQ.png 700w\" width=\"975\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"4b3e\">\n          If you study a chart that shows both the number of cancer cases and the number of mobile phones, you\u2019ll notice that both numbers went up in the last 20 years. If your brain processes this information with cause-relation cognitive bias, you might decide that mobile phones cause cancer. But that\u2019s ridiculous. There\u2019s no proof other than both datapoints happening to increase. A lot of other things have also increased in the past 20 years, and they can\u2019t all-cause cancer or be caused by mobile phone use.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia eq ar aq ib es ic eu id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"d4d5\">\n          Explainability\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"0bcc\">\n          To find causation, we need explainability. In the era of artificial intelligence and big data analysis, this topic becomes increasingly more important. AIs make data-based recommendations. Sometimes, humans can\u2019t see any reason for those recommendations except that an AI made them. In other words, they lack explainability.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"f467\">\n          Explainability in medicine\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"8b79\">\n          The FDA won\u2019t approve cancer treatments that lack explainability. Think about this situation for a minute. Do you want the best possible treatment for your cancer, based on an AI\u2019s analysis of your genomes, your cancer DNA, millions of other cases, and more data, even if you can\u2019t explain how the computer\u2019s neural network came up with that exact treatment? Or would you rather have a suboptimal treatment that you can explain the reasoning for?\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"fa95\">\n          <em class=\"kg\">\n           Medical explainability will be probably one of the biggest topics of this century.\n          </em>\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"9eaa\">\n          One way versus two way\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"766d\">\n          Correlations go both ways. We can say that mobile phone usage correlates to increased cancer risk and that cancer cases correlate to the number of mobile phones. Basically, you can swap the correlation. In causation relationships, we can say that a new marketing campaign caused an increase in sales. But saying that the increase in sales (after the campaign ran) caused the marketing campaign doesn\u2019t make any sense.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"9bf0\">\n          Any causal statement, by definition, is one way. That\u2019s a big clue about whether you\u2019re dealing with correlation or causation.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia eq ar aq ib es ic eu id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"67ef\">\n          The big dilemma\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"9b0e\">\n          In \u201cThe causal effect of education on earnings,\u201d David Card says that better education is correlated to higher earnings. But the most important thing he says is that if we can\u2019t do an experiment, with all our\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"df91\">\n          variables constant, we can\u2019t infer causation from a correlation. We can always bring explainability to the table. But in real life and with big enough problems, causations based on explainability are hard to prove. From a scientific viewpoint, they can\u2019t be called anything more than a theory.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"kh\">\n          <div class=\"ki kj kk ar er b kl km kn ko kp kq iw\" id=\"fbda\">\n           <p class=\"er b kr ks av\">\n            In the absence of experimental evidence, it is very difficult to know whether the higher earnings observed better-educated workers are caused by their higher education, or whether individuals with greater earning capacity have chosen to acquire more schooling.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"ki kj kk ar er b kl kt ku kv kw kx iw\" id=\"1d72\">\n           <p class=\"er b kr ks av\">\n            \u2014 David Card, The causal effect of education in earnings\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ky fl kz iq la is lb iu lc iw dl\" id=\"d7c8\">\n          Does higher-earning cause higher education? Does higher education cause higher earning potential? We don\u2019t know. However, we can make predictions. We can use this correlation to predict the earning potential of an individual based on his education. We can also predict his education based on his earnings.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"f839\">\n          Good predictions are based on correlations\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"525c\">\n          It sounds like a contradiction, given the context of this article. Correlation is about analyzing static historical datasets and considering the correlations that might exist between observations and outcomes. However, predictions don\u2019t change a system. That\u2019s decision making. To make software development decisions, we need to understand the difference it would make in how a system evolves if you take an action or don\u2019t take action. Decision making requires a casual understanding of the impact of an action.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jc ia eq ar aq ib jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk jl jm jn\" id=\"84d8\">\n          What are predictions?\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"f943\">\n          We don\u2019t make better predictions by developing a better casual understanding. Instead, we need to know the precise limits of the techniques we use to make predictions and what each method can do for us.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"hz ia eq ar aq ib es ic eu id ie if ig ih ii ij ik\" id=\"7e53\">\n          References\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj io fl ip iq ir is it iu iv iw dl\" id=\"ce73\">\n          Lovestats (2019). \u201cCartoons.\u201d\n          <em class=\"kg\">\n           The LoveStats Blog\n          </em>\n          . Retrieved from lovestats.wordpress.com.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"il im eq ar in b fj ix fl iy iq iz is ja iu jb iw dl\" id=\"efa6\">\n          Card, D.. (1999). \u201cThe causal effect of education on earnings.\u201d\n          <em class=\"kg\">\n           Handbook of Labor Economics\n          </em>\n          , vol 3.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n    </article>\n    <div class=\"ec dk ld le ai ll lj lm\" data-test-id=\"post-sidebar\">\n     <div class=\"n p\">\n      <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n       <div class=\"ln n dg\">\n        <div class=\"dk\">\n         <div class=\"lo lp r\">\n          <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg hv hw bj bk gr gs\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=post_sidebar--------------------------post_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n           <h2 class=\"aq ib lq as eq\">\n            Towards Data Science\n           </h2>\n          </a>\n          <div class=\"lr ls r\">\n           <h4 class=\"aq cl gk as br lt gm gn lu gp av\">\n            A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas, and codes.\n           </h4>\n          </div>\n          <div aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"hk\">\n           <a class=\"lv gv ax ay lw bh bi lx bg hg aq b ar as at au hi hj df hk hl bj\"       <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg hv hw bj bk gr gs\" rel=\"noopener\">\n             <div class=\"be mc md me mf mg mh mi ay mj bi\">\n              <svg height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n               <g fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                <path d=\"M13.74 1l.76 2.97.76-2.97zM16.82 4.78l1.84-2.56-1.43-.47zM10.38 2.22l1.84 2.56-.41-3.03zM22.38 22.62a5.11 5.11 0 0 1-3.16 1.61l.49-.45c2.88-2.89 3.45-5.98 0 0 0 .63-.62L6.1 15.04l-1.75-1.75a1 1 0 1 1 1.41-1.41l4.15 4.15a.44.44 0 0 0 .63 0 .44.44 0 0 0 0-.62L6.4 11.26l-1.18-1.18a1 1 0 0 1 0-1.4 1.02 1.02 0 0 1 1.41 0l1.18 1.16L11.96 14a.44.44 0 0 0 .62 0 .44.44 0 0 0 0-.63L8.43 9.22a.99.99 0 0 1-.3-.7.99.99 0 0 1 .3-.7 1 1 0 0 1 1.41 0l7 6.98a.44.44 0 0 0 .7-.5l-1.35-2.85c-.31-.68-.23-1.19.25-1.56a.85.85 0 0 1 .66-.16c.34.06.66.28.88.6L20.63 15c1.57 2.88 1.07 5.54-1.55 8.16a5.62 5.62 0 0 1-5.06 1.65 9.35 9.35 0 0 1-4.93-2.72zM13 6.98l2.56 2.56c-.5.6-.56 1.41-.15 2.28l.26.56-4.25-4.25a.98.98 0 0 1-.12-.45 1 1 0 0 1 .29-.7 1.02 1.02 0 0 1 1.41 0zm8.89 2.06c-.38-.56-.9-.92-1.49-1.01a1.74 1.74 0 0 0-1.34.33c-.38.29-.61.65-.71 1.06a2.1 2.1 0 0 0-1.1-.56 1.78 1.78 0 0 0-.99.13l-2.64-2.64a1.88 1.88 0 0 0-2.65 0 1.86 1.86 0 0 0-.48.85 1.89 1.89 0 0 0-2.67-.01 1.87 1.87 0 0 0-.5.9c-.76-.75-2-.75-2.7-.04a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66c-.3.12-.61.29-.87.55a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66l.62.62a1.88 1.88 0 0 0-.9 3.16l5.01 5.02c1.6 1.6 3.52 2.64 5.4 2.96a7.16 7.16 0 0 0 1.18.1c1.03 0 2-.25 2.9-.7A5.9 5.9 0 0 0 23 23.24c3.34-3.34 3.08-6.93 1.74-9.17l-2.87-5.04z\">\n                </path>\n               </g>\n              </svg>\n             </div>\n            </a>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"mk r\">\n            <div class=\"ml\">\n             <h4 class=\"aq cl gk as av\">\n              <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg correlated data, a pair of variables are related in that one thing is likely to change when the other does. This relationship might lead us to assume that a change to one thing causes the change in the other. This article clarifies that kind of faulty thinking by explaining correlation, causation, and the bias that often lumps the two together.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_5\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_5\",\"name\":\"0983\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The human brain simplifies incoming information, so we can make sense of it. Our brains often do that by making assumptions about things based on slight relationships, or bias. But that thinking process isn\u2019t foolproof. An example is when we mistake correlation for causation. Bias can make us conclude that one thing must cause another if both change in the same way at the same time. This article clears up the misconception that correlation equals causation by exploring both of those subjects and the human brain\u2019s tendency toward bias.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_6\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_6\",\"name\":\"d411\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"About correlation and causation\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_7\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_7\",\"name\":\"f57c\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Correlation is a relationship or connection between two variables where whenever one changes, the other is likely to also change. But a change in one variable doesn\u2019t cause the other to change. That\u2019s a correlation, but it\u2019s not causation. Your growth from a child to an adult is an example. When your height increased, your mass increased too. Getting taller didn\u2019t make you also get wider. Instead, maturing to adulthood caused both variables to increase \u2014 that\u2019s causation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_8\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_8\",\"name\":\"394d\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Causation in business\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_9\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_9\",\"name\":\"401c\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Let\u2019s say that we want to offer a promotion or discount to some of our customers. Our marketing department wants to maximize the delta, in other words, the increase in sales as a result of the promotion. So we need to decide which customers will give us the best return on our investment in the promotion or discount. Do we want to offer it only to our top 10% of your clients? Or the bottom 10%?\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_10\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_10\",\"name\":\"e282\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"You might assume that the users who drive more sales are the ones more responsible for your business success. But the most important thing he says is that if we can\u2019t do an experiment, with all our\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_50\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_50\",\"name\":\"df91\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"variables constant, we can\u2019t infer causation from a correlation. Correlation is about analyzing static historical datasets and considering the correlations that might exist between observations and outcomes. However, predictions don\u2019t change a system. That\u2019s decision making. To make software development decisions, we need to understand the difference it would make in how a system evolves if you take an action or don\u2019t take action. Decision making requires a casual understanding of the impact of an action.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_56\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_56\",\"name\":\"84d8\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"What are predictions?\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:ed40d3ea4f3c_57\":{\"id\":\"ed40d3ea4f3c_57\",\"name\":\"f943\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"We don\u2019t make better predictions by developing a better casual understanding.
