</path>\n                </svg>\n               </a>\n              </div>\n              <div class=\"gk r am\">\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl ai\">\n        <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl ai paragraph-image\">\n         <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n          <div class=\"gz r\">\n           <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n            <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"667\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n           </div>\n           <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"667\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1600px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2160/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1080w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2700/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1350w, https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1600w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n           <noscript>\n            <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"667\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1600px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2160/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1080w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2700/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1350w, https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*5a7sHMpoIqMB4QYo 1600w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n           </noscript>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </figure>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"253e\">\n          AI explainability is a broad and multi-disciplinary domain, being studied in several fields including machine learning, knowledge representation and reasoning, human-computer interaction, and the social sciences. Accordingly, XAI literature includes a large and growing number of methodologies.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"1ca3\">\n          There are many factors that could contribute to how an AI model operates and makes its predictions, and thus many ways to explain them. This is also partially due to a\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.03490.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           lack of an agreed-upon definition\n          </a>\n          for XAI. In general, explainability can be applied throughout the entire AI development pipeline. Specifically, it can be applied before (\n          <strong class=\"hg hw\">\n           pre-modelling explainability)\n          </strong>\n          , during (\n          <strong class=\"hg hw\">\n           explainable modelling\n          </strong>\n          ), and after (\n          <strong class=\"hg hw\">\n           post-modelling explainability\n          </strong>\n          ) the modelling stage.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"700f\">\n          What follows is a non-exhaustive overview of some of the most important XAI methodologies and approaches, split up into these three stages: pre-modelling explainability, explainable modelling, and post-modelling explainability.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"hx\">\n          <div class=\"hy hz ia ar du b ib ic id ie if ig hr\" id=\"33ed\">\n           <p class=\"du b ih ii av\">\n            There are many factors that could contribute to how an AI model operates and makes it predictions, and thus many ways to explain them.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"ij ik il im in io ae ip af iq ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"is it iu iv iw gl ix iy paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"iz ja gx jb ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ir\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"jc r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"1333\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*rXoGlA5oICgpUEXQ 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew jd je jf de dc dd jg jh aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             The three stages of AI explainability: Pre-modelling explainability, Explainable modelling and post-modelling explainability.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"9361\">\n          Pre-modelling explainability is a collection of diverse methods with a common goal of gaining a better understanding of dataset used for model development. This approach is motivated by the fact that the behaviour of an AI model is, to a large extent, driven by dataset used to train it.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ji jj dt ar aq jk dv jl dx jm jn jo jp jq jr js jt\" id=\"a455\">\n          Pre-modelling explainability\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"17f3\">\n          The pre-modelling explainability literature can be divided into four main categories:, exploratory data analysis, dataset description standardization, explainable feature engineering, and dataset summarization methods.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"hx\">\n          <div class=\"hy hz ia ar du b ib ic id ie if ig hr\" id=\"b016\">\n           <p class=\"du b ih ii av\">\n            Pre-modelling explainability is a collection of diverse methods with a common goal of gaining a better understanding of dataset used for model development.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <h2 class=\"jz jj dt ar aq jk ka kb kc kd ke kf kg kh ki kj kk\" id=\"977c\">\n          Exploratory data analysis\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"9d32\">\n          The goal of exploratory data analysis is to extract a summary of the main characteristics of a dataset. This summary often includes various statistical properties of the dataset such as its dimensionality, mean, standard deviation, range, missing samples, and so on.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://pair-code.github.io/facets/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Google Facets\n          </a>\n          is an example of a powerful toolkit for rapidly extracting such properties from a given dataset.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"7911\">\n          As an example, consider a simple supervised binary classification problem where a model is developed to detect defective vs non-defective products. Assume the dataset provided contains a large number of images provided by an assembly line\u2019s overhead camera, each labeled as either defective or non-defective. Let\u2019s further assume that the preliminary classifier model developed for this model is not performing well. An exploratory data analysis\n          <strong class=\"hg hw\">\n          </strong>\n          task that examines the relative frequency of defective and non-defective images can reveal a class imbalance problem, namely, far less defective images than non-defective ones. Having discovered this challenge within the training dataset, various solutions can then be leveraged to alleviate it and improve the classifier\u2019s performance.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"ij ik il im in io ae ip af iq ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl ix iy paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"iz ja gx jb ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ir\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"kl r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"419\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"419\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"419\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew jd je jf de dc dd jg jh aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             An example of datasets with identical mean and standard deviation, and different graphs to demonstrate the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3025912\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n              importance of visualization\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             in exploratory data analysis.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"9717\">\n          However, merely relying on statistical properties is often not enough when analyzing datasets. For example, it has been shown that datasets can have\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=3025912\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           identical statistical properties and yet have different appearance\n          </a>\n          when displayed on a graph. Accordingly, data visualization methods make up a large portion of the exploratory data analysis machinery. Data visualization offers numerous ways to plot a dataset using\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://datavizcatalogue.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           various types of charts\n          </a>\n          . Choosing an appropriate type of chart depends on a given dataset, given application, and specific statistical properties that we want to communicate.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"efb9\">\n          Real-world datasets are often complex and high dimensional, that is, have a large number of features. Visualizing such high-dimensional data can be a challenge, as humans can only imagine up to three dimensions with ease.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"hx\">\n          <div class=\"hy hz ia ar du b ib ic id ie if ig hr\" id=\"b15c\">\n           <p class=\"du b ih ii av\">\n            Merely relying on statistical properties is often not enough when analyzing datasets.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh km hj kn hl ko hn kp hp kq hr dl\" id=\"a81e\">\n          One way to deal with this challenge is to use specialized type of charts, e.g.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1905.10035.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           parallel coordinate plots\n          </a>\n          , to allow humans to perceive dimensions larger than three. Alternatively, one can project a high-dimensional dataset into a lower-dimensional representation while preserving its underlying structure as much as possible. This is the goal of dimensionality reduction methods. Some of the popular methods in this category include principal component analysis (PCA) and t-SNE. The\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://projector.tensorflow.org/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Embedding Projector toolkit\n          </a>\n          provides an easy-to-use implementation of both of these methods. If the underlying structure of a dataset is known to be relatively linear, PCA is the method of choice, otherwise, t-SNE will often be the proper choice. Unfortunately, t-SNE is too slow when applied to large datasets. In such cases, recent alternatives such as\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://github.com/lmcinnes/umap\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           UMAP\n          </a>\n          dimensionality reduction technique can be used. In fact, UMAP is claimed to be more scalable, as well as more accurate, than t-SNE.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"jz jj dt ar aq jk ka kr kc ks ke kt kg ku ki kv kk\" id=\"0dab\">\n          Dataset description standardization\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"d311\">\n          Datasets are usually released with insufficient documentation. Standardization can ensure proper communication between creators and users of datasets, and can help alleviate issues such as systemic bias in AI models or the misuse of data. Motivated by this observation, a number of recommendations have been proposed for standardizing dataset descriptions.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"bff4\">\n          Some of these recommendations include\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1803.09010.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           datasheets for datasets\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://openreview.net/pdf?id=By4oPeX9f\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           data statements\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ahmedhosny.github.io/datanutrition/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           dataset nutrition labels\n          </a>\n          . They all essentially propose various schemas for specific information accompanying a dataset to document its creation, composition, data collection process, legal/ethical considerations, etc. For example, the dataset nutrition labels framework proposes including several modules of information in the dataset documentation that resemble the nutrition facts label for packaged food. Similar to the way consumers can choose their desired food based on its nutrition facts, AI experts are envisioned to use dataset nutrition labels to efficiently select the best dataset for their modelling purposes.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"ij ik il im in io ae ip af iq ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl ix iy paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"iz ja gx jb ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd ir\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"kw r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"1155\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j-?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"1155\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"1155\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j-\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*QZwbbxNNPgIQS9j- 1000w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew jd je jf de dc dd jg jh aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             The information modules proposed by the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1805.03677.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n              Dataset Nutrition Label framework\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             as a standard for providing a distilled yet comprehensive overview of datasets.\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <h2 class=\"jz jj dt ar aq jk ka kr kc ks ke kt kg ku ki kv kk\" id=\"ff0c\">\n          Explainable feature engineering\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"d46f\">\n          Beyond being highly useful for improving AI model\u2019s performance, dataset explainability can also contribute to developing explainable models and making post-hoc model explanations more interpretable.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"3e81\">\n          Feature attribution, a popular type of post-hoc explanation, involves determining the relative importance of input features for given model prediction(s). To make feature attribution explanations more useful to the end user, the related\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.04592.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           features themselves should also be explainable\n          </a>\n          , in other words, users should be able to assign intuitive meaning to them. In other words,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://export.arxiv.org/pdf/1801.09808\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           explanations are only as good as the features they use\n          </a>\n          to explain model predictions. Explainable feature engineering aims at tackling this challenge.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"7331\">\n          There are two main approaches to achieve explainable feature engineering, namely,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.04592.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           domain-specific and model-based\n          </a>\n          feature engineering. The domain-specific approaches rely on domain expert\u2019s knowledge and insights drawn from exploratory data analysis to extract and/or identify features. For instance, detecting cloudy pixels in satellite imagery of the arctic is a challenging task due to qualitative similarity of ice/snow to clouds. Following a domain-specific feature engineering approach Shi et al.\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1198/016214507000001283\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           developed three explainable and efficient features\n          </a>\n          used by a binary classifier to tackle this problem.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"hx\">\n          <div class=\"hy hz ia ar du b ib ic id ie if ig hr\" id=\"c3cd\">\n           <p class=\"du b ih ii av\">\n            Explanations are only as good as the features they use to explain model predictions.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh km hj kn hl ko hn kp hp kq hr dl\" id=\"b2f8\">\n          On the other hand, model-based feature engineering approaches apply various mathematical models to uncover underlying structure of a dataset. Some of the related methodologies include\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1901.04592.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           clustering and dictionary learning\n          </a>\n          . Another interesting and related research area is\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1812.02230.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           disentangled representation learning\n          </a>\n          , which aims at learning a representation of given dataset where its generative latent factors are isolated. These latent factors can be considered as explainable features describing the dataset. For instance, the figure above shows a disentangled representation learning model called\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://openreview.net/references/pdf?id=Sy2fzU9gl\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00df-VAE\n          </a>\n          trained using a dataset of chair images taken from various perspectives (aka 3D chairs dataset). As shown, the model appears to have successfully isolated three latent factors of this dataset, namely, azimuth angle, chair width, and chair leg style.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"iz ja gx jb ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd kx\">\n            <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n             <div class=\"ky r\">\n              <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n               <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"540\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a?q=20\" width=\"960\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"540\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 700w\" width=\"960\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"540\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1920/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*7F9gyc9Uth_mE57a 700w\" width=\"960\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av ew jd je jf de dc dd jg jh aq cl\">\n           <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n            Manipulating three latent factors of the 3D chairs dataset, namely, azimuth angle, width, and leg style, using the\n           </strong>\n           <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://openreview.net/references/pdf?id=Sy2fzU9gl\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             \u00df-VAE distentagled representation learning approach\n            </strong>\n           </a>\n           <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n            .\n           </strong>\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <h2 class=\"jz jj dt ar aq jk ka kr kc ks ke kt kg ku ki kv kk\" id=\"975c\">\n          Dataset summarization\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"22a8\">\n          Case-based reasoning, a type of explainable modelling approach, makes predictions for a given sample based on training samples (cases) similar to it according to some distance measure. These\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://europepmc.org/backend/ptpmcrender.fcgi?accid=PMC2232607&amp;blobtype=pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           similar training samples can be presented to end user\n          </a>\n          , along with model prediction, as the explanation. An important limitation of case-based reasoning approach, however, is the requirement to store the entire training dataset, which can be too costly or simply impossible for extremely large datasets. One way to alleviate this issue is to store a subset of training dataset that is still representative of the essence of the dataset. Dataset summarization aims at tackling this challenge.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"67d1\">\n          To summarize a dataset often means to seek a minimal subset of representative samples (aka prototypes) that provide a condensed view of it. Early work in this area dates back to the 1980s with methods such as\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Peter_Rousseeuw/publication/243777819_Clustering_by_Means_of_Medoids/links/00b7d531493fad342c000000.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           K-medoid clustering\n          </a>\n          . Interest in data summarization has been revived lately mainly due to the increasing availability of large datasets. For instance, a number of methods have been proposed for\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.computer.org/csdl/proceedings-article/iccv/2007/04408863/12OmNywfKEO\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           scene summarization\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2002537\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           document summarization\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1202.5933.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           classification\n          </a>\n          tasks. The first method relies on a specialized clustering algorithm whereas the last two methods are both formulated as an optimization problem. Moreover, all of these methods extract a dataset summary for a target application.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"ij ik il im in io ae ip af iq ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl ix iy paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"iz ja gx jb ai\">\n            <div class=\"dc dd kz\">\n             <div class=\"gw r gx gy\">\n              <div class=\"la r\">\n               <div class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai br gu gv\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai ha hb hc\" height=\"574\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq?q=20\" width=\"1420\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gr gs s t u gt ai hd\" height=\"574\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 1000w\" width=\"1420\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gt ai\" height=\"574\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2840/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq 1000w\" width=\"1420\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"av ew jd je jf de dc dd jg jh aq cl\">\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             A random subset of prototype and criticism examples extracted for the USPS dataset using the\n            </strong>\n            <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://people.csail.mit.edu/beenkim/papers/KIM2016NIPS_MMD.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n              MMD-critic data summarization method\n             </strong>\n            </a>\n            <strong class=\"aq hw\">\n             .\n            </strong>\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"9873\">\n          It has been argued recently that prototype examples are not adequate for understanding large and complex datasets, we need criticisms too. A\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://christophm.github.io/interpretable-ml-book/proto.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           criticism\n          </a>\n          is an often (relatively) rare data point that is not well described by the set of prototypes. Kim et al. propose an\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://people.csail.mit.edu/beenkim/papers/KIM2016NIPS_MMD.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           unsupervised learning method to extract prototypes and criticisms\n          </a>\n          for a given dataset, and conduct a human study to validate the results of their method. First, human subjects are shown a set of prototype and criticism images for a number of classes of animals. Then, they are asked to predict the class label of a given test image. The study revealed that humans who were shown both prototype and criticism images performed better than those that were only shown the prototypes.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"1fcb\">\n          So-called data squashing is related to data summarization. The goal of\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://www.cs.princeton.edu/courses/archive/spr04/cos598B/bib/DuMouchel.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           data squashing\n          </a>\n          is to construct a smaller substitute of a dataset that leads to approximately the same analysis result. In contrast to data summarization, samples in the substitute dataset often have weights associated to them. The recent work on so-called\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://github.com/trevorcampbell/bayesian-coresets\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Bayesian coresets\n          </a>\n          is in this category. In other words, it can be considered as a data squashing problem formulated within the Bayesian learning setting.\n         </p>\n         <blockquote class=\"hx\">\n          <div class=\"hy hz ia ar du b ib ic id ie if ig hr\" id=\"6d90\">\n           <p class=\"du b ih ii av\">\n            Prototype examples are not adequate for understanding large and complex datasets, we need criticisms too.\n           </p>\n          </div>\n         </blockquote>\n         <h1 class=\"ji jj dt ar aq jk dv jl dx jm jn jo jp jq jr js jt\" id=\"4adf\">\n          What\u2019s next?\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh ju hj jv hl jw hn jx hp jy hr dl\" id=\"3eeb\">\n          Pre-modelling explainability is a diverse set of methodologies with a common goal to obtain a better understanding of a given dataset available for modelling. Data-related insights extracted through pre-modelling explainability can enable developing more efficient, explainable, and robust AI solutions.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"6e80\">\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://medium.com/@bahador.khaleghi/the-how-of-explainable-ai-explainable-modelling-55c8c43d7bed\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           The next part\n          </a>\n          of this series is focused on the modelling stage of AI development. In particular, it explores various families of methodologies for developing AI models that are both explainable and performant.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n      <hr class=\"lb cl lc ld le jf lf lg lh li lj\"/>\n      <section class=\"dl dm dn do dp\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"he hf dt ar hg b hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp hq hr dl\" id=\"82d5\">\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           Special thanks to\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://wxs.ca/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Xavier Snelgrove\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ca.linkedin.com/in/elnaz-barshan-845964ba\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Elnaz Barshan\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://www.lindsaydbrin.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Lindsay Brin\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           ,\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://ca.linkedin.com/in/santiagosalcido\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Santiago Salcido\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           , and\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"http://manongruaz.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Manon Gruaz\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           for valuable comments and illustrations. Edited by\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq fx hs ht hu hv\" href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/pnhenderson/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"lk\">\n            Peter Henderson\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"lk\">\n           .\n          </em>\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n mx\">\n           <a class=\"my mz fx av r na nb a b cm\" href=\"/tag/blackbox\">\n            Blackbox\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fw bx gj mx\">\n           <a <div class=\"ms r\">\n           <div class=\"mt\">\n            <h4 class=\"aq cl ew as dt\">\n             <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\">\n              156         </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"gg r an\">\n           <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\">\n            <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\"         </path>\n             <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n             </path>\n            </svg>\n           </button>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"gg r an\">\n           <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"//medium.com/p/699150495fe4/share/facebook?source=post_actions_footer---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n             </path>\n            </svg>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"nw r an\">\n           <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fthe-how-of-explainable-ai-pre-modelling-explainability-699150495fe4&amp;source=post_actions_footer--------------------------bookmark_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n             <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 goal of exploratory data analysis is to extract a summary of the main characteristics of a dataset. This summary often includes various statistical properties of the dataset such as its dimensionality, mean, standard deviation, range, missing samples, and so on. Google Facets is an example of a powerful toolkit for rapidly extracting such properties from a given dataset.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_12.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_12.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":267,\"end\":280,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fpair-code.github.io\\u002Ffacets\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_13\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_13\",\"name\":\"7911\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"As an example, consider a simple supervised binary classification problem where a model is developed to detect defective vs non-defective products. Assume the dataset provided contains a large number of images provided by an assembly line\u2019s overhead camera, each labeled as either defective or non-defective. Let\u2019s further assume that the preliminary classifier model developed for this model is not performing well. An exploratory data analysis task that examines the relative frequency of defective and non-defective images can reveal a class imbalance problem, namely, far less defective images than non-defective ones. Having discovered this challenge within the training dataset, various solutions can then be leveraged to alleviate it and improve the classifier\u2019s performance.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_13.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_13.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":445,\"end\":446,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_14\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_14\",\"name\":\"bcdb\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"An analysis.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_14.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_14.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0\":{\"id\":\"0*lv2hjJcWPvPgPWf0\",\"originalHeight\":419,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_14.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":107,\"end\":134,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdl.acm.org\\u002Fcitation.cfm?id=3025912\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_14.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":164,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_15\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_15\",\"name\":\"9717\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"However, merely relying on statistical properties is often not enough when analyzing datasets. For example, it has been shown that datasets can have identical statistical properties and yet have different appearance when displayed on a graph. Accordingly, data visualization methods make up a large portion of the exploratory data analysis machinery. Data visualization offers numerous ways to plot a dataset using various types of charts. Choosing an appropriate type of chart depends on a given dataset, given application, and specific statistical properties that we want to communicate.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_15.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_15.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_15.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":149,\"end\":215,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdl.acm.org\\u002Fcitation.cfm?id=3025912\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_15.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":415,\"end\":438,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdatavizcatalogue.com\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_16\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_16\",\"name\":\"efb9\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Real-world datasets are often complex and high dimensional, that is, have a large number of features. Visualizing such high-dimensional data can be a challenge, as humans can only imagine up to three dimensions with ease.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_17\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_17\",\"name\":\"b15c\",\"type\":\"PQ\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Merely relying on statistical properties is often not enough when analyzing datasets.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_18\",\"name\":\"a81e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"One way to deal with this challenge is to use specialized type of charts, e.g. parallel coordinate plots, to allow humans to perceive dimensions larger than three. Alternatively, one can project a high-dimensional dataset into a lower-dimensional representation while preserving its underlying structure as much as possible. This is the goal of dimensionality reduction methods. Some of the popular methods in this category include principal component analysis (PCA) and t-SNE. The Embedding Projector toolkit provides an easy-to-use implementation of both of these methods. If the underlying structure of a dataset is known to be relatively linear, PCA is the method of choice, otherwise, t-SNE will often be the proper choice. Unfortunately, t-SNE is too slow when applied to large datasets. In such cases, recent alternatives such as UMAP dimensionality reduction technique can be used. In fact, UMAP is claimed to be more scalable, as well as more accurate, than t-SNE.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":79,\"end\":104,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1905.10035.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":482,\"end\":509,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fprojector.tensorflow.org\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_18.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":837,\"end\":841,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fgithub.com\\u002Flmcinnes\\u002Fumap\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_19\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_19\",\"name\":\"0dab\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Dataset description standardization\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_20\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_20\",\"name\":\"d311\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Datasets are usually released with insufficient documentation. Standardization can ensure proper communication between creators and users of datasets, and can help alleviate issues such as systemic bias in AI models or the misuse of data. Motivated by this observation, a number of recommendations have been proposed for standardizing dataset descriptions.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_21\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_21\",\"name\":\"bff4\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Some of these recommendations include datasheets for datasets, data statements, and dataset nutrition labels. They all essentially propose various schemas for specific information accompanying a dataset to document its creation, composition, data collection process, legal\\u002Fethical considerations, etc. For example, the dataset nutrition labels framework proposes including several modules of information in the dataset documentation that resemble the nutrition facts label for packaged food. Similar to the way consumers can choose their desired food based on its nutrition facts, AI experts are envisioned to use dataset nutrition labels to efficiently select the best dataset for their modelling attribution, a popular type of post-hoc explanation, involves determining the relative importance of input features for given model prediction(s). To make feature attribution explanations more useful to the end user, the related features themselves should also be explainable, in other words, users should be able to assign intuitive meaning to them. In other words, explanations are only as good as the features they use to explain model predictions. Explainable feature engineering aims at tackling this challenge.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_25.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_25.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_25.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":237,\"end\":283,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1901.04592.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_25.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":375,\"end\":429,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fexport.arxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1801.09808\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_26\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_26\",\"name\":\"7331\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"There are two main approaches to achieve explainable feature engineering, namely, domain-specific and model-based feature engineering. Some of the related methodologies include clustering and dictionary learning. Another interesting and related research area is disentangled representation learning, which aims at learning a representation of given dataset where its generative latent factors are isolated. These latent factors can be considered as explainable features describing the dataset. For instance, the figure above shows a disentangled representation learning model called \u00df-VAE trained using a dataset of chair images taken from various perspectives (aka 3D chairs dataset). summarization\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_31\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_31\",\"name\":\"22a8\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Case-based reasoning, a type of explainable modelling approach, makes predictions for a given sample based on training samples (cases) similar to it according to some distance measure. These similar training samples can be presented to end user, along with model prediction, as the explanation. An important limitation of case-based reasoning approach, however, is the requirement to store the entire training dataset, which can be too costly or simply impossible for extremely large datasets. One way to alleviate this issue is to store a subset of training dataset that is still representative of the essence of the dataset. Dataset summarization aims at tackling this challenge.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_31.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_31.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":191,\"end\":244,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Feuropepmc.org\\u002Fbackend\\u002Fptpmcrender.fcgi?accid=PMC2232607&blobtype=pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_32\",\"name\":\"67d1\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"To summarize a dataset often means to seek a minimal subset of representative samples (aka prototypes) that provide a condensed view of it. Early work in this area dates back to the 1980s with methods such as K-medoid clustering. Interest in data summarization has been revived lately mainly due to the increasing availability of large datasets. For instance, a number of methods have been proposed for scene summarization, document summarization, and classification tasks. The first method relies on a specialized clustering algorithm whereas the last two methods are both formulated as an optimization problem. Moreover, all of these methods extract a dataset summary for a target application.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":209,\"end\":228,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.researchgate.net\\u002Fprofile\\u002FPeter_Rousseeuw\\u002Fpublication\\u002F243777819_Clustering_by_Means_of_Medoids\\u002Flinks\\u002F00b7d531493fad342c000000.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":402,\"end\":422,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.computer.org\\u002Fcsdl\\u002Fproceedings-article\\u002Ficcv\\u002F2007\\u002F04408863\\u002F12OmNywfKEO\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":423,\"end\":446,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdl.acm.org\\u002Fcitation.cfm?id=2002537\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_32.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":451,\"end\":466,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1202.5933.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_33\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_33\",\"name\":\"118c\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"OUTSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq\",\"typename\":\"ImageM method.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_33.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_33.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq\":{\"id\":\"0*KfhYSQCO5U0eheJq\",\"originalHeight\":574,\"originalWidth\":1420,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_33.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":93,\"end\":129,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fpeople.csail.mit.edu\\u002Fbeenkim\\u002Fpapers\\u002FKIM2016NIPS_MMD.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_33.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":130,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_34\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_34\",\"name\":\"9873\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"It has been argued recently that prototype examples are not adequate for understanding large and complex datasets, we need criticisms too. A criticism is an often (relatively) rare data point that is not well described by the set of prototypes. Kim et al. propose an unsupervised learning method to extract prototypes and criticisms for a given dataset, and conduct a human study to validate the results of their method. First, human subjects are shown a set of prototype and criticism images for a number of classes of animals. Then, they are asked to predict the class label of a given test image. The study revealed that humans who were shown both prototype and criticism images performed better than those that were only shown the prototypes.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_34.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_34.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_34.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":141,\"end\":150,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fchristophm.github.io\\u002Finterpretable-ml-book\\u002Fproto.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_34.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":267,\"end\":332,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fpeople.csail.mit.edu\\u002Fbeenkim\\u002Fpapers\\u002FKIM2016NIPS_MMD.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:af30f270fa92_35\":{\"id\":\"af30f270fa92_35\",\"name\":\"1fcb\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"So-called data squashing is related to data summarization. The goal of data squashing is to construct a smaller substitute of a dataset that leads to approximately the same analysis result. In contrast to data summarization, samples in the substitute dataset often have weights associated to them. The recent work on so-called Bayesian coresets is in this category. In other words, it can be considered as a data squashing problem formulated within the Bayesian learning       </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl ai\">\n        <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl ai paragraph-image\">\n         <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n          <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n           <div class=\"hc r\">\n            <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n             <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"2278\" https://miro.medium.com/max/4320/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 2160w, https://miro.medium.com/max/4800/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 2400w\" width=\"3791\"/>\n            <noscript>\n             <img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"2278\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"100vw\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/7582/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/3240/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 1620w, https://miro.medium.com/max/3780/1*HZK9iLiHfAaAjXaxJl8OQw.jpeg 1890w, </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n          Image courtesy:\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/birsas/4217163553/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           https://www.flickr.com/photos/birsas/4217163553/\n          </a>\n         </figcaption>\n        </figure>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"c382\">\n          In this world of ever increasing data at a hyper pace, we use all kinds of complex ensemble and deep learning algorithms to achieve the highest possible accuracy. It\u2019s sometimes magical how these models predict, classify, recognize, and track unknown data. Accomplishing this magic and more has been and would be the goal of intensive research and development in the data science community.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"a733\">\n          But, around all this great work, a question arises:\n          <br/>\n          <strong class=\"hs ie\">\n           <em class=\"if\">\n            Can we always trust this prediction, classification, recognition, and tracking\n           </em>\n          </strong>\n          <em class=\"if\">\n           ?\n          </em>\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"b172\">\n          A variety of reasons, like lack of data, imbalanced datasets, biased datasets etc. can impact the decision rendered by the learning models. Models are gaining traction for explainability. Financial institutions and law agencies, for example demand explanations and evidences (\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.federalreserve.gov/supervisionreg/srletters/sr1107.htm\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SR 11\u20137\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://thehill.com/policy/technology/364482-lawmakers-introduce-bipartisan-ai-legislation\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           The FUTURE of AI Act\n          </a>\n          ) bolstering the output of these learning models.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"96f6\">\n          I am going to demonstrate explainability on the decisions made by LightGBM and Keras models in classifying a transaction for fraudulence on the\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.kaggle.com/c/ieee-fraud-detection/data\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           IEEE CIS dataset\n          </a>\n          . I will use two state of the art open source explainability techniques in this article, namely\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/slundberg/shap\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP\n          </a>\n          from these research papers (\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.03888\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"if\">\n            1\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04938\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           2\n          </a>\n          ). I have saved another great open source explainability technique \u2014\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/IBM/AIX360\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           AIX360\n          </a>\n          for my next post as it proposes 8 novel algorithms by itself for explainability.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"72df\">\n          I have borrowed the awesome feature engineering techniques on this dataset from\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.kaggle.com/cdeotte/xgb-fraud-with-magic-0-9600\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           here\n          </a>\n          . Additionally, I have used feature scaling to even out the variability in the magnitude of feature values.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ig ih dp az ay ii dr ij dt ik il im in io ip iq ir\" id=\"d435\">\n          LIME\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id dh\" id=\"97d8\">\n          Intuitively, an explanation is a local linear approximation of the model\u2019s behaviour. While the model may be very complex globally, it is easier to approximate it around the vicinity of a particular instance. While treating the model as a black box, LIME perturbs the instance desired to explain and learn a sparse linear model around it, as an explanation. The figure below illustrates the intuition for this procedure. The model\u2019s decision function is represented by the blue/pink background, and is clearly nonlinear. The bright red cross is the instance being explained (let\u2019s call it X). We sample instances around X, and weight them according to their proximity to X (weight here is indicated by size). We then learn a linear model (dashed line) that approximates the model well in the vicinity of X, but not necessarily globally. For more information,\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1602.04938\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           read this paper\n          </a>\n          , or take a look at\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.oreilly.com/learning/introduction-to-local-interpretable-model-agnostic-explanations-lime\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           this blog post\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"ea79\">\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\n          </a>\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"cy cz ix\">\n           <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n            <div class=\"iy r\">\n             <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n              <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"344\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png?q=20\" width=\"553\"/>\n             </div>\n             <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"344\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"553px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1106/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 553w\" width=\"553\"/>\n             <noscript>\n              <img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"344\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"553px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1106/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1106/1*kjUrB4gRpeLf0cadxjds9A.png 553w\" width=\"553\"/>\n             </noscript>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n           LIME Technique (\n           <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\n           </a>\n           )\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <h2 class=\"iz ih dp az ay ii ja jb jc jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk\" id=\"d1b0\">\n          Ensemble model \u2014 LightGBM\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id dh\" id=\"8b1b\">\n          Below is my model configuration. I have got an auc score of 0.972832 for this model.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"dbe4\"># Create training and validation sets</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"b6bb\">x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(x, y, test_size=0.30, random_state=42)</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"fa65\"># Train the model</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"31bf\">parameters = {<br/>    'application': 'binary',<br/>    'objective': 'binary',<br/>    'metric': 'auc',<br/>    'is_unbalance': 'true',<br/>    'boosting': 'gbdt',<br/>    'num_leaves': 31,<br/>    'feature_fraction': 0.5,<br/>    'bagging_fraction': 0.5,<br/>    'bagging_freq': 20,<br/>    'learning_rate': 0.05,<br/>    'verbose': 0<br/>}</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"bf13\">model = lightgbm.train(parameters,<br/>                       train_data,<br/>                       valid_sets=test_data,<br/>                       num_boost_round=5000,<br/>                       early_stopping_rounds=100)</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"f316\">y_pred = model.predict(x_test)</span></pre>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"4c30\">\n          This the classification report of the above model.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"d193\">from sklearn.metrics import classification_report<br/>print(classification_report(y_test, y_pred_bool))</span></pre>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n           <div class=\"cy cz jw\">\n            <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n             <div class=\"jx r\">\n              <div width=\"970\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"332\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*UiAg-D5WxhvnSzHCTUL6_g.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*UiAg-D5WxhvnSzHCTUL6_g.png 552w, </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"236a\">\n          Before, I explore the formal LIME and SHAP explainability techniques to explain the model classification results, I thought why not use LightGBM\u2019s inbuilt \u2018feature importance\u2019 function to visually understand the 20 most important features which helped the model lean towards a particular classification.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"97e6\">feature_imp= pd.DataFrame({'Value':model.feature_importance(),'Feature':X.columns})<br/>plt.figure(figsize=(40, 20))<br/>sns.set(font_scale = 5)<br/>sns.barplot(x=\"Value\", y=\"Feature\", data=feature_imp.sort_values(by=\"Value\", ascending=False)[0:20])<br/>plt.title('LightGBM Features (avg over folds)')<br/>plt.tight_layout()<br/>plt.savefig('lgbm_importances-01.png')<br/>plt.show()</span></pre>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"jy jz ka kb kc kd ae ke af kf ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl kh ki paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n            <div class=\"cy cz https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*XLMNtAAPboR_z8fQtKjBAA.png 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*XLMNtAAPboR_z8fQtKjBAA.png 1000w\" width=\"2764\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n            Top 20 important features in the LightGBM model above\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"0907\">\n          Having seen the top 20 crucial features enabling the model, let us dive into explaining these decisions through few amazing open source python libraries, namely\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/marcotcr/lime\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://github.com/slundberg/shap\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"dac6\">\n          The code for using LIME to explain the decisions made by model is simple and takes few lines.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"8825\">def prob(data):<br/>    return np.array(list(zip(1-model.predict(data),model.predict(data))))</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"63ca\">import lime<br/>import lime.lime_tabular<br/>explainer = lime.lime_tabular.LimeTabularExplainer(new_df[list(X.columns)].astype(int).values,  <br/>mode='classification',training_labels=new_df['isFraud'],feature_names=list(X.columns))</span></pre>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"a5d9\">\n          I would use this explainer to explain any random instance as follows:\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"051f\">i = 2<br/>exp = explainer.explain_instance(new_df.loc[i,list(X.columns)].astype(int).values, prob, num_feature=5)</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"fea2\">##visualize the result<br/>exp.show_in_notebook(show_table=True)</span></pre>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"jy jz ka kb kc kd ae ke af kf ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl kh ki paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n            <div class=\"cy cz kk\">\n             <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n              <div class=\"kl r\">\n               <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"450\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png?q=20\" width=\"2026\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"450\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 276w, 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 904w,
