<img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"450\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/4052/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*913LQOJzbvZx5Hns53WG2w.png 1000w\" width=\"2026\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <h2 class=\"iz ih dp az ay ii ja jb jc jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk\" id=\"e84b\">\n          Deep Learning model \u2014 Keras (tensorflow)\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id dh\" id=\"a913\">\n          I have attempted to explain the decisions of my neural network (Keras) model as below. The model is configured as follows.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"65de\">classifier = Sequential()<br/>#First Hidden Layer<br/>classifier.add(Dense(16, activation='sigmoid', kernel_initializer='random_normal', input_dim=242))<br/>#Second  Hidden Laye<br/>classifier.add(Dense(8, activation='sigmoid', kernel_initializer='random_normal'))</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"e0d0\">#Output Layer<br/>classifier.add(Dense(1, activation='sigmoid', kernel_initializer='random_normal'))</span></pre>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"3780\">\n          This the classification report of the above model.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"fd43\">from sklearn.metrics import classification_report<br/>y_pred=classifier.predict(X_test, batch_size=64, verbose=1)<br/>y_pred =(y_pred&gt;0.5)<br/>y_pred_bool = np.argmax(y_pred, axis=1)</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"40b6\">print(classification_report(Y_test, y_pred_bool))</span></pre>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n           <div class=\"cy cz km\">\n            <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n             <div class=\"kn r\">\n              <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n               <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"348\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png?q=20\" width=\"1122\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"348\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 700w\" width=\"1122\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"348\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2244/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*1NWCssngZjb44HojVhc1kQ.png 700w\" width=\"1122\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"8e68\">\n          Following is the code for LIME explainer for the results of the above Keras model.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"605b\">def prob(data):<br/>    print(data.shape)<br/>    y_pred=classifier.predict(data).reshape(-1, 1)<br/>    y_pred =(y_pred&gt;0.5)<br/>    print(np.array(list(zip(1-y_pred.reshape(data.shape[0]),y_pred.reshape(data.shape[0])))))<br/>    return np.hstack((1-y_pred,y_pred))</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"fa63\">import lime<br/>import lime.lime_tabular<br/>explainer = lime.lime_tabular.LimeTabularExplainer(X[list(X.columns)].astype(int).values,  <br/>mode='classification',training_labels=new_df['isFraud'],feature_names=list(X.columns))</span></pre>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"aeb4\">\n          I would use the above explainer to explain any random instance as below.\n         </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"d03f\">i = 19<br/>exp = explainer.explain_instance(X.loc[i,X.columns].astype(int).values, prob, num_features=5)</span></pre>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"jy jz ka kb kc kd ae ke af kf ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl kh ki paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n            <div class=\"cy cz ko\">\n             <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n              <div class=\"kp r\">\n               <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n                <img class=\"s 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*YlTn3RJvo7iF292t4CwaLQ.png 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*YlTn3RJvo7iF292t4CwaLQ.png 992w,        </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <h1 class=\"ig ih dp az ay ii dr ij dt ik il im in io ip iq ir\" id=\"0bff\">\n          SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations)\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id dh\" id=\"3e08\">\n          The beauty of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) lies in the fact that it unifies all available frameworks for interpreting predictions. SHAP assigns each feature an importance value for a particular prediction. Its novel components include: (1) the identification of a new class of additive feature importance measures, and (2) theoretical results showing there is a unique solution in this class with a set of desirable properties. The new class unifies six existing methods, notable because several recent methods in the class lack the proposed desirable properties. Based on insights from this unification, it presents new methods that show improved computational performance and/or better consistency with human intuition than previous approaches.\n         </p>\n         <h2 class=\"iz ih dp az ay ii ja jb jc jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk\" id=\"cbfb\">\n          Ensemble model \u2014 LightGBM\n         </h2>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"3611\">import shap</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"92a4\"># load JS visualization code to notebook<br/>shap.initjs()</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"a13e\"># explain the model's predictions using SHAP values<br/># (this syntax works for LightGBM, CatBoost, scikit-learn and spark models)<br/>explainer = shap.TreeExplainer(model)<br/>shap_values = explainer.shap_values(X)</span><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jr js jt ju jv jp r jq\" id=\"df6b\"># visualize the first prediction's explanation (use matplotlib=True to avoid Javascript)<br/>shap.force_plot(explainer.expected_value, shap_values[0,:], X.iloc[0,:])</span></pre>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"jy jz ka kb kc kd ae ke af kf ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl kh ki https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*LEpick_TcPLzj5b6sg5DkA.png 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*LEpick_TcPLzj5b6sg5DkA.png 1000w\" width=\"2190\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n            The above explanation shows features each contributing to push the model output from the base value (the average model output over the training dataset we passed) to the model output. Features pushing the prediction higher are shown in red, those pushing the prediction lower are in blue (these force plots were introduced in the\n            <a class=\"ez fx hm hn ho hp\" href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41551-018-0304-0\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n             Nature BME paper\n            </a>\n            ). If we take many explanations such as the one shown above, rotate them 90 degrees, and then stack them horizontally, we can see explanations for an entire dataset .\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"ee8c\">shap.dependence_plot(\"TransactionAmt\", shap_values, X)</span></pre>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"cy cz ks\">\n           <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n            <div class=\"kt r\">\n             <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n              <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"327\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png?q=20\" width=\"488\"/>\n             </div>\n             <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"327\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"488px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/976/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png 488w\" width=\"488\"/>\n             <noscript>\n              <img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"327\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"488px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/976/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/976/1*aTXcCioYVG6sWH8FQAPsNA.png 488w\" width=\"488\"/>\n             </noscript>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n           To understand how a single feature affects the output of the model we can plot the SHAP value of that feature vs. the value of the feature for all the examples in a dataset. Since SHAP values represent a feature\u2019s responsibility for a change in the model output, the plot below represents the change in predicted house price as TransactionAmt (the amount in the transaction) changes. Vertical dispersion at a single value of TransactionAmt represents interaction effects with other features. To help reveal these interactions\n           <code class=\"hb ku kv kw jn b\">\n            dependence_plot\n           </code>\n           automatically selects another feature for coloring. In this case coloring by V284 highlights that the average number of TransactionAmt has less impact on fraud probability for cases with a high V284 value.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"d911\"># summarize the effects of all the features<br/>shap.summary_plot(shap_values, X)</span></pre>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n           <div class=\"cy cz kx\">\n            <div class=\"ha r gt </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n           To get an overview of which features are most important for a model we can plot the SHAP values of every feature for every sample. The plot below sorts features by the sum of SHAP value magnitudes over all samples, and uses SHAP values to show the distribution of the impacts each feature has on the model output. The color represents the feature value (red high, blue low). This reveals for example that a card holder address has a high impact on its predicted fraudulent status.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"5cca\">shap.summary_plot(shap_values, X, plot_type=\"bar\")</span></pre>\n         <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl cy cz paragraph-image\">\n          We can also just take the mean absolute value of the SHAP values for each feature to get a standard bar plot\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <h2 class=\"iz ih dp az ay </p>\n         <pre class=\"gm gn go gp gq jl jm co\"><span class=\"iz ih dp az jn b et jo jp r jq\" id=\"fc66\">import shap<br/>import tensorflow.keras.backend <br/>background = https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*aWgWrMBR1lh59c6u_FpYMw.png 1000w\" width=\"2008\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <figcaption class=\"bx et hh hi hj da cy cz hk hl ay es\">\n            We can also just take the mean absolute value of the SHAP values for each feature to get a standard bar plot\n           </figcaption>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <h2 class=\"iz ih dp az ay ii ja jb jc jd je jf jg jh ji jj jk\" id=\"5940\">\n          Differences between SHAP and LIME\n         </h2>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id dh\" id=\"04be\">\n          LIME creates a surrogate model locally around the unit who\u2019s prediction you wish to understand. Thus it is inherently local. Shapely values \u2018decompose\u2019 the final prediction into the contribution of each attribute \u2014 this is what some mean by \u2018consistent\u2019 (the values add up to the actual prediction of the true model, this is not something you get with LIME). But to actually get the shapely values there is some decision that must be made about what to do/how to handle the values of the attributes \u2018left out\u2019, this is how the values are arrived at. In this decision there is some choice which could change the interpretation. If I \u2018leave out\u2019 an attribute do I average all the possibilities? Do choose some \u2018baseline\u2019? So Shapely actually tells you, in an additive way, how you got your score, but there is some choice about the \u2018starting point\u2019 (i.e. the decision about omitted attributes). LIME simply tells you, in a local sense, what is the most important attribute around the data point of interest.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht hu hv hw hx hy hz ia ib ic id dh\" id=\"489e\">\n          In production, we can use the following architecture to share model explainability with the stakeholders.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"gl\">\n        <div class=\"n p\">\n         <div class=\"jy jz ka kb kc kd ae ke af kf ah ai\">\n          <figure class=\"gm gn go gp gq gl kh ki paragraph-image\">\n           <div class=\"gr gs gt gu ai\">\n            <div class=\"cy cz lg\">\n             <div class=\"ha r gt hb\">\n              <div class=\"lh r\">\n               <div class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai cf gy gz\">\n                <img class=\"s t u gx ai hd he hf\" height=\"1280\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png?q=20\" width=\"3358\"/>\n               </div>\n               <img class=\"gv gw s t u gx ai hg\" height=\"1280\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 1000w\" width=\"3358\"/>\n               <noscript>\n                <img class=\"s t u gx ai\" height=\"1280\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"1000px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/6716/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1456/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 728w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1632/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 816w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1808/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 904w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1984/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 992w, https://miro.medium.com/max/2000/1*VoR-zomO3ULW2THkKa6f0g.png 1000w\" width=\"3358\"/>\n               </noscript>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </figure>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dm ah ai\">\n         <h1 class=\"ig ih dp az ay ii dr ij dt ik il im in io ip iq ir\" id=\"d16b\">\n          References\n         </h1>\n         <ol class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"hq hr dp az hs b ht is hv it hx iu hz iv ib iw id li lj lk\" id=\"2088\">\n <div class=\"ng r\">\n           <div class=\"nh\">\n            <h4 class=\"ay es et ba dp\">\n             <button class=\"ez fa bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bo gh gi br bs fc fd\">\n              208    <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65 \\u002Fabs\\u002F1602.04938\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_5.markups.5\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":372,\"end\":378,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fgithub.com\\u002FIBM\\u002FAIX360\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_5.markups.6\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":299,\"end\":300,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_6\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_6\",\"name\":\"72df\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"I have borrowed the awesome feature engineering techniques on this dataset from here. Additionally, I have used feature scaling to even out the variability in the magnitude of feature values.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_6.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_6.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":80,\"end\":84,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.kaggle.com\\u002Fcdeotte\\u002Fxgb-fraud-with-magic-0-9600\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_7\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_7\",\"name\":\"d435\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"LIME\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_8\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_8\",\"name\":\"97d8\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Intuitively, an explanation is a local linear approximation of the model\u2019s behaviour. While the model may be very complex globally, it is easier to approximate it around the vicinity of a particular instance. While treating the model as a black box, LIME perturbs the instance desired to explain and learn a sparse linear model around it, as an explanation. The figure below illustrates the intuition for this procedure. The model\u2019s decision function is represented by the blue\\u002Fpink background, and is clearly nonlinear. The bright red cross is the instance being explained (let\u2019s call it X). We sample instances around X, and weight them according to their proximity to X (weight here is indicated by size). We then learn a linear model (dashed line) that approximates the model well in the vicinity of X, but not necessarily globally. For more information, read this paper, or take a look at this blog beauty of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) lies in the fact that it unifies all available frameworks for interpreting predictions. SHAP assigns each feature an importance value for a particular prediction. Its novel components include: (1) the identification of a new class of additive feature importance measures, and (2) theoretical results showing there is a unique solution in this class with a set of desirable properties. The new class unifies six existing methods, notable because several recent methods in the class lack the proposed desirable properties. Based on insights from this unification, it presents new methods that show improved computational performance and\\u002For better consistency with human intuition than previous approaches.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_49\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_49\",\"name\":\"cbfb\",\"type\":\"H4\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Ensemble shap\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_51\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_51\",\"name\":\"92a4\",\"type\":\"PRE\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"# between SHAP and LIME\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_68\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_68\",\"name\":\"04be\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"LIME creates a surrogate model locally around the unit who\u2019s prediction you wish to understand. Thus it is inherently local. Shapely values \u2018decompose\u2019 the final prediction into the contribution of each attribute \u2014 this is what some mean by \u2018consistent\u2019 (the values add up to the actual prediction of the true model, this is not something you get with LIME). But to actually get the shapely values there is some decision that must be made about what to do\\u002Fhow to handle the values of the attributes \u2018left out\u2019, this is how the values are arrived at. In this decision there is some choice which could change the interpretation. If I \u2018leave out\u2019 an attribute do I average all the possibilities? Do choose some \u2018baseline\u2019? So Shapely actually tells you, in an additive way, how you got your score, but there is some choice about the \u2018starting point\u2019 (i.e. the decision about omitted attributes). LIME simply tells you, in a local sense, what is the most important attribute around the data point of interest.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:39ddb85f4b05_69\":{\"id\":\"39ddb85f4b05_69\",\"name\":\"489e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In style=\"padding-left:4px\">\n                 <svg class=\"star-15px_svg__svgIcon-use\" height=\"15\" style=\"margin-top:-2px\" viewbox=\"0 0 15 15\" width=\"15\">\n                  <path d=\"M7.44 12.22c-.1.06-.14.03-.1-.07l1.2-3.53a.27.27 0 0 0-.1-.3L2.06 6.16c-.1-.06-.07-.12.03-.12h3.89a.29.29 0 0 0 .26-.19l1.2-3.52z\">\n                  </path>\n                 </svg>\n                </span>\n               </div>\n              </span>\n             </span>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"n gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx y\">\n            <div class=\"n o\">\n             <div class=\"gy r an\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gz ha bj bk fv fw\" href=\"//medium.com/p/649672aa7bdd/share/twitter?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65 2.26c.03 1.6.83 2.99 2.02 3.79a4.3 4.3 0 0 1-2.02-.57v.08a4.55 4.55 0 0 0 3.63 4.44c-.4.08-.8.13-1.21.16l-.81-.08a4.54 4.54 0 0 0 4.2 3.15 9.56 9.56 0 0 1-5.66 1.94l-1.05-.08c2 1.27 4.38 2.02 6.94 2.02 8.3 0 12.86-6.9 12.84-12.85.02-.24 0-.43 0-.65a8.68 8.68 0 0 0 2.26-2.34c-.82.38-1.7.62-2.6.72a4.37 4.37 0 0 0 1.95-2.51c-.84.53-1.81.9-2.83 1.13z\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gy r an\">\n              <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gz ha bj bk fv fw\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\" height=\"29\" viewbox=\"0 0 29 29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M5 6.36C5 5.61 5.63 5 6.4 5h16.2c.77 0 1.4.61 1.4 1.36v16.28c0 .75-.63 1.36-1.4 1.36H6.4c-.77 0-1.4-.6-1.4-1.36V6.36z\">\n                </path>\n                <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 1.48h.01zM12.35 20.9h2.87v-4.79c0-.25.02-.5.1-.7.2-.5.67-1.04 1.46-1.04 1.04 0 1.46.8 1.46 1.95v4.59h2.87v-4.92c0-2.64-1.42-3.87-3.3-3.87-1.55 0-2.23.86-2.61 1.45h.02v-1.24h-2.87c.04.8 0 8.58 0 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </button>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gy r an\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gz ha bj bk fv fw\" href=\"//medium.com/p/649672aa7bdd/share/facebook?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"hb r\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gz ha bj bk fv fw\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fnavigating-the-sea-of-explainability-649672aa7bdd&amp;source=post_actions_header--------------------------bookmark_header-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n                <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 5.66 4.13a.5.5 0 0 0 .71-.03.5.5 0 0 0 .12-.29H19V6zm-6.84 9.97L7 19.64V6a1 1 0 0 1 1-1h9a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v13.64l-5.16-3.67a.49.49 0 0 0-.68 0z\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"hc r am\">\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd hd\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"hv r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"800\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png?q=20\" width=\"1202\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"800\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 700w\" width=\"1202\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"800\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2404/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*Hga8Mn8prFbfLUsk.png 700w\" width=\"1202\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"830e\">\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           This article is coauthored by\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://medium.com/@Joy_Rimchala\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"im\">\n            Joy Rimchala\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           and\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://medium.com/@DataLady\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"im\">\n            Shir Meir Lador\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           .\n          </em>\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"f1d8\">\n          Setting the right course\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"e6cf\">\n          Rapid adoption of complex machine learning (ML) models in recent years has brought with it a new challenge for today\u2019s companies: how to interpret, understand, and explain the reasoning behind these complex models\u2019 predictions. Treating complex ML systems as trustworthy black boxes without sanity checking has led to some disastrous outcomes, as evidenced by recent disclosures of gender and racial biases in\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"http://proceedings.mlr.press/v81/buolamwini18a.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           GenderShades\n          </a>\n          \u00b9.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"0c58\">\n          As ML-assisted predictions integrate more deeply into high-stakes decision-making, such as medical diagnoses, recidivism risk prediction, loan approval processes, etc., knowing the root causes of an ML prediction becomes crucial. If we know that certain model predictions reflect bias and are not aligned with our best knowledge and societal values (such as an equal opportunity policy or outcome equity), we can detect these undesirable ML defects, prevent the deployment of such ML systems, and correct model defects.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd ji\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"jj r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"870\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv?q=20\" width=\"1282\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"870\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 700w\" width=\"1282\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"870\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2564/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*6TMEgv9nvAUfdLGv 700w\" width=\"1282\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           The\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"http://gendershades.org/overview.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            GenderShades\n           </a>\n           study reported noticeable differences in gender classification accuracy of widely used face detection algorithms including\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/cognitive-services/face/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            Microsoft Cognitive Services Face API\n           </a>\n           ,\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.faceplusplus.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            FACE++\n           </a>\n           , and\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.ibm.com/watson/services/visual-recognition/?mhsrc=ibmsearch_a&amp;mhq=face%20recognition\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            IBM watson visual recognition\n           </a>\n           . There\u2019s a large gap in gender misclassification rates among different subgroups, with the largest gap of 34.4% observed between a lighter skinned male face compared to darker skinned female face.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"1ce3\">\n          Our mission at Intuit is\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           powering prosperity around the world\n          </em>\n          . To help small businesses and individuals increase their odds for success, in the last few years Intuit has been infusing AI and ML across its platform and solutions. As data scientists at Intuit, we have a unique privilege and power to develop ML models that make decisions that affect people\u2019s lives. With that power, we also bear the responsibility to make sure our models are held in the highest standards, and are not discriminating in any manner.\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cIntegrity without compromise\u201d\n          </em>\n          is one of Intuit\u2019s core values. As we grow as an AI/ML-driven organization, machine intelligibility has become a priority for Intuit\u2019s AI/ML products.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"f923\">\n          This year, Intuit hosted an Explainable AI workshop (\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://xai.kdd2019.a.intuit.com/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           XAI 2019\n          </a>\n          ) at\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.kdd.org/kdd2019/#!\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           KDD 2019\n          </a>\n          . We gleaned many valuable learnings from this workshop that we will start to incorporate in our product and service strategies.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"597d\">\n          Understanding the current state of interpretability\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"70a6\">\n          Interpretability is an active area of research and the description provided below is meant to provide a high level summary of the current state of the field. Interpretability methods fall into two major categories based on whether the model being interpreted is: (a) black box (unintelligible) or (b) glass box (intelligible). In the following section, we will explain and compare each of the approaches. We will also describe how we can use intelligible models to better understand our data. Then we will review a method to detect high-performing intelligible models for any use case (Rashomon curves). Finally, we will compare local and global explanations and feature-based vs. concept-based explanation.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"efec\">\n          Black box:\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"c2e5\">\n          Black box interpretability methods attempt to explain already-existing ML models without taking into account the inner workings of the model (i.e., the learned decision functions). This class of interpretability methods is model-agnostic and can be integrated easily with a wide variety of ML models, from decision tree-based models to complex neural networks\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.05386\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b2\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.03296\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b3\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07857\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u2074\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1807.08024\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u2075\n          </a>\n          . Applying black box interpretability does not require any changes in the way ML practitioners create and train the models. For this reason, black box interpretability methods enjoy wider adoption among ML practitioners. Black box interpretability methods are also referred to as \u201cpost-hoc\u201d interpretability, as they can be used to interrogate ML models after training and deployment without any knowledge of the training procedures. Examples of black box interpretability methods include\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME\n          </a>\n          \u00b2,\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Shapley\u2076,\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.01365\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Integrated Gradients\n          </a>\n          \u2077,\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.02685\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           DeepLIFT\n          </a>\n          \u2078, etc. Post-hoc model interpretations are a proxy for explanations. The explanations derived in this manner are not necessarily guaranteed to be human-friendly, useful, or actionable.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"53cc\">\n          Glass box:\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"8383\">\n          A glass box approach with intelligible ML models requires that models be \u201cinterpretable\u201c upfront (aka \u201cpre-hoc\u201d)\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1503.01161\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u2079\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1405.4047\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2070\n          </a>\n          . The advantage of this approach is the ease with which ML practitioners can tease out model explanations, detect data and/or label flaws, and in some cases, edit the model\u2019s decisions if they do not align with practitioner values or domain knowledge.\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/people/rcaruana/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Rich Caruana\n          </a>\n          , Senior Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research and one of KDD XAI 2019\u2019s keynote speakers, demonstrated how his team built a highly accurate, intelligible, and editable ML model based on generalized additive models (GAMs)\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01621459.1987.10478440\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u00b9\n          </a>\n          and applied it to mortality prediction in pneumonia cases\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2788613\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u00b2\n          </a>\n          .\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.cs.cornell.edu/~yinlou/papers/lou-kdd12.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           This version\n          </a>\n          , named also GA2M ( or\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cGAM on steroids\u201d\n          </em>\n          ) is optimized by\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_boosting\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           gradient boosting\n          </a>\n          instead of the cubic\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"http://mathworld.wolfram.com/CubicSpline.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           splines\n          </a>\n          in the original version, and achieves results comparable to modern ML models (such as random forest or gradient-boosted trees).\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"c7d1\">\n          Using Intelligible models\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"71d5\">\n          Caruana shared how his team uses intelligible models to better understand and correct their data. For example, the intelligible model learned the rule that patients with pneumonia who have a history of asthma have a lower risk of dying from pneumonia than the general population. This rule is counterintuitive, but reflects a true pattern in the training data: patients with a history of asthma who presented with pneumonia usually were admitted not only to the hospital but directly to the Intensive Care Unit. The aggressive care received by asthmatic pneumonia patients was so effective that it lowered their risk of dying from pneumonia in comparison with the general population. Because the prognosis for these patients is better than average, models trained on the data incorrectly learn that asthma lowers mortality risk, when in fact asthmatics have much higher risk (if not aggressively treated).\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"3b14\">\n          If simpler, intelligible models can learn counterintuitive association \u2014 such as,\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           having asthma implies lower pneumonia risk\n          </em>\n          \u2014 more complex neural network-based algorithms can probably do the same. Even if we can remove the asthma bias from the data, what other incorrect things were learned? This is the classic problem of\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confounding\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           statistical confounding\n          </a>\n          : when a variable (in our case, treatment intensity) is associated with both the dependent and independent variable, causing a spurious association. The treatment intensity is influenced by the variable of asthma, and in turn reduces the risk of mortality.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"31fe\">\n          This observation illustrates the importance of model intelligibility in high stakes decision-making. Models that captured true but spurious patterns or idiosyncrasies in the data \u2014 such as false association in the pneumonia example or societal biases \u2014 could generate predictions that lead to undesirable consequential outcomes such as mistreating patients. Current ML models are trained to minimize prediction errors on the training data and not on aligning with any human intuition and concepts, so there\u2019s no guarantee that models will align the human\u2019s values. More often than not, ML models trained on human-curated datasets will reflect the defect or bias in the data\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.02641\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u00b3\n          </a>\n          . An intelligible model allows these defects to surface during model validation.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"847f\">\n          Currently, only a small subset of algorithms \u2014 namely decision tree-based models and generalized additive models (GAMs) \u2014 are intelligible. Decision tree-based models and GAMs are not used in ML applications (such as computer vision, natural language processing, and time series predictions) because the best possible versions of these models currently do not perform at the state-of-the-art-level of complex deep neural network-based models.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"4aa0\">\n          Detecting high-performing intelligible models for any use case\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"865e\">\n          When we\u2019re able to choose between equally-performing intelligible and black box models, the best practice is to choose the intelligible one\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1811.10154\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2074\n          </a>\n          . How can we know whether a high-performing intelligible model exists for a particular application?\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://users.cs.duke.edu/~cynthia/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Cynthia Rudin\n          </a>\n          , Professor of Computer Science at Duke University and the Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS) Fellow 2019 (also a KDD XAI 2019 panelist) proposed a diagnostic tool, called the \u201c\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           Rashomon Curve\n          </em>\n          ,\u201d\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.01755\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2075\n          </a>\n          that helps ML practitioners answer this question.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"1020\">\n          Let\u2019s first define a few terms. \u201cRashomon effect\u201d denotes the situation in which there exist many different and approximately-equally accurate descriptions to explain a phenomenon. The term \u201cRashomon effect\u201d is derived from a popular Japanese film (\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashomon\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Rashomon\n          </a>\n          ) known for a plot that involves various characters providing self-serving descriptions of the same incident. A\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cRashomon set,\u201d\n          </em>\n          defined over the hypothesis space of all possible models in a model class, is a subset of ML models that have training performance close to the best model in the class. The\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cRashomon ratio\u201d\n          </em>\n          is the cardinality of the Rashomon set divided by the cardinality of all possible models (with varying levels of accuracy). Thus,\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cRashomon ratio\u201d\n          </em>\n          is defined uniquely for each ML task/dataset pair. When the Rashomon ratio is large, there exist several equally highly accurate ML models to solve that ML task. Some of these highly accurate models within the Rashomon set might have desirable properties such as intelligibility and it may be worthwhile to find such models. Thus, Rashomon ratio serves as an indicator of the simplicity of the ML problem.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"8edf\">\n          In her\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wL4X4lG20sM\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           KDD 2019 keynote talk\n          </a>\n          , Rudin introduced the\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cRashomon curve\u201d\n          </em>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1908.01755\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           <em class=\"im\">\n            \u00b9\u2075\n           </em>\n          </a>\n          (see figure below), a diagnostic curve connecting the log Rashomon ratio of hierarchy of model classes with increasing complexity as a function of the empirical risk (the error rate bound on the model classes).\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jp\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"jq r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"658\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ?q=20\" width=\"1600\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"658\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 700w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"658\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3200/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ 700w\" width=\"1600\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            Left figure\n           </strong>\n           : Empirical Rashomon sets are defined for each ML task/dataset pair and class of model (hypothesis space). Rashomon curves connect the Rashomon ratio of increasingly complex model classes as a function of empirical risk (the observed error of a particular model class). The horizontal part of the \u0393-shape corresponds to a decrease in the empirical risk (increase in model accuracy) as we move through the hierarchy of hypothesis spaces (H1 on the top right to H7 on the bottom left). The length of arrow delta is the generalization error. If the ML problem is too complex for a model class considered, only the horizontal part of the Rashomon curve is observed. This is an indication that the model class considered is not complex enough to learn the training data well. On the other hand, if the ML model class considered is too complex for the training data, only the vertical part of the Rashomon curve is observed.\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            Right Figure:\n           </strong>\n           The state-of-the-art for the various public ML problems/datasets on their own Rashomon curve, indicating whether it\u2019s likely to be too complex or too simple for the given ML task/dataset pairs.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"33a2\">\n          When solving an ML problem, one might consider a hierarchy of model classes starting from simpler to more complex model (hypothesis) classes. In the beginning, the model classes remain too simple for the ML task and the model\u2019s error rate continues to decrease with increasing complexity. This observation corresponds to moving along the horizontal part of the Rashomon curve from right to left. In this case, the Rashomon volume grows at about the same rate as the volume of all the set of all possible models (with varying accuracy). In the regime when the ML model classes start to become too complex for the ML tasks, the model error rates remain the same. This corresponds to traversing the vertical part of the Rashomon curve from the top toward the bottom. In this regime, the set of all possible models outgrow the Rashomon set and the Rashomon ratio drops sharply. The turning point in the Rashomon curve (\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cRashomon elbow\u201d\n          </em>\n          ) is a sweet spot where lower complexity (higher log Rashomon ratio) and higher accuracy (low empirical risk) meet. Thus, among the hierarchy of model classes, those that fall in the vicinity of the Rashomon elbow are likely to have the right level of complexity for achieving the best balance of high accuracy with desired properties such as generalizability and interpretability.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"0cf0\">\n          Local vs. Global Explanation\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"3086\">\n          Interpretability methods can provide two types of explanations: local and global\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1702.08608\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2076\n          </a>\n          . Local explanations describe how a model classifies a single data instance, and answer questions such as,\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           \u201cWhich data element(s) are most responsible for the classification output?\u201d\n          </em>\n          In image classification, this is equivalent to identifying which pixel is responsible for a \u201ccat\u201d image class prediction, and by how much. Local explanations are crucial for investigating ML decisions around individual data points.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"dc dd js\">\n           <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n            <div class=\"jt r\">\n             <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n              <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"350\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB?q=20\" width=\"544\"/>\n             </div>\n             <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"350\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"544px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1088/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB 544w\" width=\"544\"/>\n             <noscript>\n              <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"350\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"544px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1088/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1088/0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB 544w\" width=\"544\"/>\n             </noscript>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            LIME\n           </strong>\n           [local interpretable model-agnostic explanations taken from\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            [2]\n           </a>\n           ]. The original model\u2019s decision function is represented by the blue/pink background, and is clearly nonlinear. The bright red cross is the instance being explained (let\u2019s call it X). Perturbed instances are sampled around X and are weighted according to their proximity to X (weight here is represented by size). Original model predictions are calculated on these perturbed instances. These are used to train a linear model (dashed line) that approximates the model well in the vicinity of X. Note that the explanation in this case is not faithful globally, but it is faithful locally around X.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd ju\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"jv r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"500\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g?q=20\" width=\"1440\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"500\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 700w\" width=\"1440\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"500\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2880/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g 700w\" width=\"1440\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           This figure illustrates a local explanation of Google\u2019s\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://github.com/google/inception\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            Inception neural network\n           </a>\n           on some arbitrary image. (4) keep as explanations of the parts of the image that are most positive toward a certain class. In this case, the classifier predicts Electric Guitar, even though the image contains an acoustic guitar. The explanation reveals why it would confuse the two: the fretboard is very similar.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"c05e\">\n          A global explanation, on the other hand, attempts to provide a holistic summarization of how a model generates predictions for an entire class of objects or data sets, rather than focusing on a single prediction and data point.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jw\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"jx r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"405\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png?q=20\" width=\"1822\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"405\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 700w\" width=\"1822\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"405\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3644/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*AaHj7mA0ARaljmMp.png 700w\" width=\"1822\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           The plots above demonstrate\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            global explanations\n           </strong>\n           for a model trained on the\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/census+income\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            census income dataset\n           </a>\n           to predict the income level for adults, based on demographic features.\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            The left figure\n           </strong>\n           (calculated using\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://github.com/microsoft/interpret\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            InterpertML\n           </a>\n           ) shows the score predicted by a GA2M model as a function of age. This directly illustrates the age contribution to the model.\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            The right figure\n           </strong>\n           shows the mean absolute score of each feature to the model (aka feature importance).\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"fafe\">\n          The two most popular techniques for global explanations are feature importance and\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/partial_dependence.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           partial dependence plots\n          </a>\n          . Feature importance provides a score that indicates how useful or valuable each feature was in the construction of the model. In models based on decision trees (like random forests or gradient boosting), the more a feature is used to make key decisions within the decision trees, the higher its relative importance. Partial dependence plots (PDP) show the dependence between the target variable and a set of \u201ctarget\u201d features, marginalizing over the values of all other features (the \u201ccomplement\u201d features). Intuitively, we can interpret the partial dependence as the expected target response as a function of the \u201ctarget\u201d features. A partial dependence plot helps us understand how a specific feature value affects predictions, which can be useful for model and data debugging as demonstrated in\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2788613\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u00b2\n          </a>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"b39e\">\n          Feature-based vs. concept-based explanation\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"8374\">\n          Early interpretability methods relied on using input features to construct the explanation. This approach is known as feature-based explanation. A key difficulty with feature-based explanations is that most ML models operate on features, such as pixel values, that do not correspond to high-level concepts that humans can easily understand. In her KDD XAI 2019 keynote,\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://ai.google/research/people/106045/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Been Kim\n          </a>\n          , Senior Research Scientist at Google Brain, pointed out that feature-based explanations applied to state-of-the-art complex black-box models (such as\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1512.00567\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           InceptionV3\n          </a>\n          or\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://ai.google/research/pubs/pub43022\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           GoogleLeNet\n          </a>\n          ) can yield non-sensible explanations\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.03292\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2077\n          </a>\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.09701\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2078\n          </a>\n          . More importantly, feature-based explanations for ML problems where the input features have high dimensionality does not necessarily lead to human-friendly explanations.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd jy\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"jz r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"804\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc?q=20\" width=\"1540\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"804\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 700w\" width=\"1540\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"804\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3080/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc 700w\" width=\"1540\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            Testing with concept activation vectors (TCAV)\n           </strong>\n           quantitatively measures how a \u201cconcept\u201d (defined by a collection of inputs) is learned by a trained model by quantifying sensitivity of a model prediction class along the direction of concept activation vectors (CAVs). CAVs are defined per layer and per concept by training a linear classifier [such as support vector machine (SVM)] over the activation states of a layer of a pre-trained network using a collection of \u201cconcept-defining\u201d inputs vs. random inputs (CAV testing inputs). These CAV testing inputs can be constructed post-hoc and do not need to be part of the training/evaluation and target task-specific datasets. TCAV can be used with both black box complex models as well as interpretable models. TCAV is currently publicly available at :\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://github.com/tensorflow/tcav\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            https://github.com/tensorflow/tcav\n           </a>\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"8f9e\">\n          Concept-based explainability constructs the explanation based on human-defined concepts rather than a representation of the inputs based on features and internal model (activation) states. To achieve this, the input feature and model internal state and human-defined concept are represented in two vector spaces: (Em) and (Eh), respectively. The functional mapping between these two vector spaces, if it exists, provides a way of extracting human-defined concepts from input features and ML model internal states.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"d0c2\">\n          In her keynote, Kim presented testing with concept activation vector (TCAV), a procedure to quantitatively translate between the human-defined concept space (Eh) and the model internal state (Em)\n          <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1711.11279\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           \u00b9\u2079\n          </a>\n          . TCAV requires two main ingredients: (1) concept-containing inputs and negative samples (random inputs), and (2) pretrained ML models on which the concepts are tested. To test how well a trained ML model captured a particular concept, the concept-containing and random inputs are inferenced on subcomponents (layers) of a trained ML model. Then, a linear classifier such as a support vector machine is trained to distinguish the activation of the network due to concept-containing vs. random inputs. A result of this training are concept activation vectors (CAVs). Once CAVs are defined, the directional derivative of the class probability along CAVs can be computed for each instance that belong to a class. Finally, the \u201cconcept importance\u201d for a class is computed as a fraction of the instances in the class that get positively activated by the concept containing inputs vs. random inputs. This approach allows humans to ask whether a model \u201clearns\u201d a particular expressible concept, and how well.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"eea7\">\n          For example, a human can ask how well a computer vision model \u201cX\u201d learns to associate the concept of \u201cwhite coat\u201d or \u201cstethoscope\u201d in doctor images using TCAV. To do this, human testers can first assemble a collection of images containing white coats and random images, then apply the pretrained \u201cX\u201d on this collection of images to get the predictions, and compute the TCAV scores for the \u201cwhite coat\u201d concept. This TCAV score quantifies how important the concept of \u201cwhite coat\u201d was to a prediction of class \u201cdoctor\u201d in an image classification task. TCAV is an example-driven approach, so it still requires careful selection of the concept data instances as inputs. TCAV also relies on humans to generate concepts to test, and on having the concept be expressible in the concept inputs.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"he hf hg hh hi hj dc dd paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hk hl hm hn ai\">\n           <div class=\"dc dd ka\">\n            <div class=\"ht r hm hu\">\n             <div class=\"kb r\">\n              <div class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai br hr hs\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai hw hx hy\" height=\"387\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z?q=20\" width=\"862\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"ho hp s t u hq ai hz\" height=\"387\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 700w\" width=\"862\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hq ai\" height=\"387\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1724/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z 700w\" width=\"862\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"av fo jk jl jm de dc dd jn jo aq cl\">\n           Example of a realistic use of\n           <strong class=\"aq jr\">\n            TCAV\n           </strong>\n           to quantify how much the concepts of \u201cwhite coat,\u201d \u201cstethoscope,\u201d and \u201cmale\u201d are important for an image classification model for a positive prediction of the \u201cdoctor\u201d class.\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"0ea4\">\n          Concept-based interpretability methods like TCAV are a step toward extracting \u201chuman-friendly\u201d ML explanations. It is up to today\u2019s ML practitioners to make responsible and correct judgment calls on whether model predictions are sensible, and whether they align with our positive values. It is up to us to correct the defects in trained black-box ML models, and TCAV can help illuminate where the flaws are.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"b0b1\">\n          What can we do better?\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"4f82\">\n          As a community of ML practitioners, it\u2019s our responsibility to clearly define what we want Explainable AI to become, and to establish guidelines for generating explanations that take into consideration\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           what\n          </em>\n          piece of information to use,\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           how\n          </em>\n          (in what manner) to construct the explainability in a way that is beneficial (not harmful or abusive), and\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           when\n          </em>\n          (in which situation/context and to whom) to deliver it. While today\u2019s Explainable AI methods help to pinpoint the defects in ML systems, there\u2019s much work ahead of us.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il dl\" id=\"83ed\">\n          For now, here are some tips for bringing explainability to the forefront of today\u2019s practice:\n         </p>\n         <ul class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em id eo ie if ig ih ii ij ik il kc kd ke\" id=\"b5ed\">\n           Choose an intelligible model whenever possible.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em kf eo kg if kh ih ki ij kj il kc kd ke\" id=\"7aef\">\n           Make sure the model and data align with your domain knowledge and societal values, using intelligible models and local explanations.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em kf eo kg if kh ih ki ij kj il kc kd ke\" id=\"94e8\">\n           Measure machine learning model performance to be sure decisions are aligned with societal values (for example, when modeling data includes protected groups, optimize for consistency and equal opportunity, as well as accuracy)\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.07538\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            \u00b2\u2070\n           </a>\n           .\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em kf eo kg if kh ih ki ij kj il kc kd ke\" id=\"c5f7\">\n           Build causality into model explanations\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.07165\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            \u00b2\u00b9\n           </a>\n           .\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em kf eo kg if kh ih ki ij kj il kc kd ke\" id=\"7ad6\">\n           Measure explanation usefulness and actionability\n           <a class=\"cq gp in io ip iq\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1809.06514\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            \u00b2\u00b2\n           </a>\n           .\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"46e6\">\n          Closing Thoughts\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"b1b2\">\n          In the span of a few short years, explainable AI as a field has come a very long way. As co-organizers of this workshop, we were privileged to witness tremendous enthusiasm for explainability in ML. For all of us, explainability can be our \u201ctrue North.\u201d How we can use ML responsibly by ensuring that \u201cour values are aligned and our knowledge is reflected\u201d for the benefit of humanity. This goes beyond achieving end user\u2019 trust or achieving fairness in a narrowly-defined sense. We want to use explainability in conjunction with societal values for the benefit of everyone whose life and livelihood comes into contact with, or is affected by, ML.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"3a53\">\n          Acknowledgment\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"2475\">\n          We would like to thank the community of volunteers who helped review the XAI KDD workshop papers in a timely manner. We are also grateful to our workshop speakers and panelists for sharing their knowledge, wisdom and superb content.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ir is dt ar aq it dv iu dx iv iw ix iy iz ja jb jc\" id=\"333c\">\n          References:\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"ia ib dt ar ic b em jd eo je if jf ih jg ij jh il dl\" id=\"d0b2\">\n          <em class=\"im\">\n           [1] Joy Buolamwini, Timnit Gebru. <div class=\"n p\">\n       <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n        <div class=\"n lu\">\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"n o lu\">\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"lv r\">\n         <ul class=\"be bf\">\n          <li class=\"go bx hb lw\">\n           <a class=\"lx ly gp av r lz ma a b cm\" href=\"/tag/machine-learning\">\n            Machine Learning\n           </a>\n
