We gleaned many valuable learnings from this workshop that we will start to incorporate in our product and service strategies.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_9.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_9.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_9.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":53,\"end\":61,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fxai.kdd2019.a.intuit.com\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_9.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":66,\"end\":74,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.kdd.org\\u002Fkdd2019\\u002F#!\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_10\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_10\",\"name\":\"597d\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Understanding the current state of interpretability\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_11\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_11\",\"name\":\"70a6\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Interpretability is an active area of research and the description provided below is meant to provide a high level summary of the current state of the field. Interpretability methods fall into two major categories based on whether the model being interpreted is: (a) black box (unintelligible) or (b) glass box (intelligible). In the following section, we will explain and compare each of the approaches. We will also describe how we can use intelligible models to better understand our data. Then we will review a method to detect high-performing intelligible models for any use case (Rashomon curves). Finally, we will compare local and global explanations and feature-based vs. concept-based explanation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_12\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_12\",\"name\":\"efec\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Black box:\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_13\",\"name\":\"c2e5\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Black box interpretability methods attempt to explain already-existing ML models without taking into account the inner workings of the model (i.e., the learned decision functions). This class of interpretability methods is model-agnostic and can be integrated easily with a wide variety of ML models, from decision tree-based models to complex neural networks\u00b2 \u00b3 \u2074 \u2075. Applying black box interpretability does not require any changes in the way ML practitioners create and train the models. For this reason, black box interpretability methods enjoy wider adoption among ML practitioners. Black box interpretability methods are also referred to as \u201cpost-hoc\u201d interpretability, as they can be used to interrogate ML models after training and deployment without any knowledge of the training procedures. Examples of black box interpretability methods include LIME\u00b2, Shapley\u2076, Integrated Gradients\u2077, DeepLIFT\u2078, etc. Post-hoc model interpretations are a proxy for explanations. The explanations derived in this manner are not necessarily guaranteed to be human-friendly, useful, or actionable.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.5\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.6\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.7\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":359,\"end\":360,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1606.05386\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":361,\"end\":362,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1704.03296\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":363,\"end\":364,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1705.07857\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":365,\"end\":366,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1807.08024\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_13.mar box:\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_15\",\"name\":\"8383\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"A glass box approach with intelligible ML models requires that models be \u201cinterpretable\u201c upfront (aka \u201cpre-hoc\u201d)\u2079 \u00b9\u2070. The advantage of this approach is the ease with which ML practitioners can tease out model explanations, detect data and\\u002For label flaws, and in some cases, edit the model\u2019s decisions if they do not align with practitioner values or domain knowledge. Rich Caruana, Senior Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research and one of KDD XAI 2019\u2019s keynote speakers, demonstrated how his team built a highly accurate, intelligible, and editable ML model based on generalized additive models (GAMs)\u00b9\u00b9 and applied it to mortality prediction in pneumonia cases\u00b9\u00b2. This version, named also GA2M ( or \u201cGAM on steroids\u201d) is optimized by gradient boosting instead of the cubic splines in the original version, and achieves results comparable to modern ML models (such as random forest or gradient-boosted trees).\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.5\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.6\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.7\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.8\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":112,\"end\":113,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1503.01161\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":114,\"end\":116,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1405.4047\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":368,\"end\":380,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.microsoft.com\\u002Fen-us\\u002Fresearch\\u002Fpeople\\u002Frcaruana\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":606,\"end\":608,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.tandfonline.com\\u002Fdoi\\u002Fabs\\u002F10.1080\\u002F01621459.1987.10478440\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":666,\"end\":668,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdl.acm.org\\u002Fcitation.cfm?id=2788613\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.5\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":670,\"end\":682,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.cs.cornell.edu\\u002F~yinlou\\u002Fpapers\\u002Flou-kdd12.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.6\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":740,\"end\":757,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\\u002Fwiki\\u002FGradient_boosting\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.7\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":779,\"end\":786,\"href\":\"http:\\u002F\\u002Fmathworld.wolfram.com\\u002FCubicSpline.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_15.markups.8\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":705,\"end\":722,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_16\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_16\",\"name\":\"c7d1\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Using Intelligible models\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_17\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_17\",\"name\":\"71d5\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Caruana shared how his team uses intelligible models to better understand and correct their data. For example, the intelligible model learned the rule that patients with pneumonia who have a history of asthma have a lower risk of dying from pneumonia than the general population. This rule is counterintuitive, but reflects a true pattern in the training data: patients with a history of asthma who presented with pneumonia usually were admitted not only to the hospital but directly to the Intensive Care Unit. The aggressive care received by asthmatic pneumonia patients was so effective that it lowered their risk of dying from pneumonia in comparison with the general population. Because the prognosis for these patients is better than average, models trained on the data incorrectly learn that asthma lowers mortality risk, when in fact asthmatics have much higher risk (if not aggressively treated).\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_18\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_18\",\"name\":\"3b14\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"If simpler, intelligible models can learn counterintuitive association \u2014 such as, having asthma implies lower pneumonia risk \u2014 more complex neural network-based algorithms can probably do the same. Even if we can remove the asthma bias from the data, what other incorrect things were learned? This is the classic problem of statistical confounding: when a variable (in our case, treatment intensity) is associated with both the dependent and independent variable, causing a spurious association. The treatment intensity is influenced by the variable of asthma, and in turn reduces the risk of mortality.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_18.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_18.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_18.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":323,\"end\":347,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\\u002Fwiki\\u002FConfounding\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_18.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":82,\"end\":124,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_19\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_19\",\"name\":\"31fe\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"This observation illustrates the importance of model intelligibility in high stakes decision-making. Models that captured true but spurious patterns or idiosyncrasies in the data \u2014 such as false association in the pneumonia example or societal biases \u2014 could generate predictions that lead to undesirable consequential outcomes such as mistreating patients. Current ML models are trained to minimize prediction errors on the training data and not on aligning with any human intuition and concepts, so there\u2019s no guarantee that models will align the human\u2019s values. More often than not, ML models trained on human-curated datasets will reflect the defect or bias in the data\u00b9\u00b3. An intelligible model allows these defects to surface during model validation.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_19.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_19.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":673,\"end\":675,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1908.02641\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_20\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_20\",\"name\":\"847f\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Currently, only a small subset of algorithms \u2014 namely decision tree-based models and generalized additive models (GAMs) \u2014 are intelligible. Decision tree-based models and GAMs are not used in ML applications (such as computer vision, natural language processing, and time series predictions) because the best possible versions of these models currently do not perform at the state-of-the-art-level of complex deep neural network-based models.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_21\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_21\",\"name\":\"4aa0\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Detecting high-performing intelligible models for any use case\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_22\",\"name\":\"865e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"When we\u2019re able to choose between equally-performing intelligible and black box models, the best practice is to choose the intelligible one\u00b9\u2074. How can we know whether a high-performing intelligible model exists for a particular application? Cynthia Rudin, Professor of Computer Science at Duke University and the Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS) Fellow 2019 (also a KDD XAI 2019 panelist) proposed a diagnostic tool, called the \u201cRashomon Curve,\u201d\u00b9\u2075 that helps ML practitioners answer this question.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":139,\"end\":141,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1811.10154\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":241,\"end\":254,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fusers.cs.duke.edu\\u002F~cynthia\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":455,\"end\":457,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1908.01755\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_22.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":439,\"end\":453,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_23\",\"name\":\"1020\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Let\u2019s first define a few terms. \u201cRashomon effect\u201d denotes the situation in which there exist many different and approximately-equally accurate descriptions to explain a phenomenon. The term \u201cRashomon effect\u201d is derived from a popular Japanese film (Rashomon) known for a plot that involves various characters providing self-serving descriptions of the same incident. A \u201cRashomon set,\u201d defined over the hypothesis space of all possible models in a model class, is a subset of ML models that have training performance close to the best model in the class. The \u201cRashomon ratio\u201d is the cardinality of the Rashomon set divided by the cardinality of all possible models (with varying levels of accuracy). Thus, \u201cRashomon ratio\u201d is defined uniquely for each ML task\\u002Fdataset pair. When the Rashomon ratio is large, there exist several equally highly accurate ML models to solve that ML task. Some of these highly accurate models within the Rashomon set might have desirable properties such as intelligibility and it may be worthwhile to find such models. Thus, Rashomon ratio serves as an indicator of the simplicity of the ML problem.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":249,\"end\":257,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\\u002Fwiki\\u002FRashomon\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":369,\"end\":384,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":558,\"end\":574,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_23.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":705,\"end\":721,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_24\",\"name\":\"8edf\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In her KDD 2019 keynote talk, Rudin introduced the \u201cRashomon curve\u201d\u00b9\u2075 (see figure below), a diagnostic curve connecting the log Rashomon ratio of hierarchy of model classes with increasing complexity as a function of the empirical risk (the error rate bound on the model classes).\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":7,\"end\":28,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fwww.youtube.com\\u002Fwatch?v=wL4X4lG20sM\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":67,\"end\":69,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1908.01755\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_24.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":51,\"end\":69,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_25\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_25\",\"name\":\"d91b\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Left figure : Empirical Rashomon sets are defined for each ML task\\u002Fdataset pair and class of model (hypothesis space). Rashomon curves connect the Rashomon ratio of increasingly complex model classes as a function of empirical risk (the observed error of a particular model class). The horizontal part of the \u0393-shape corresponds to a decrease in the empirical risk (increase in model accuracy) as we move through the hierarchy of hypothesis spaces (H1 on the top right to H7 on the bottom left). The length of arrow delta is the generalization error. If the ML problem is too complex for a model class considered, only the horizontal part of the Rashomon curve is observed. This is an indication that the model class considered is not complex enough to learn the training data well. On the other hand, if the ML model class considered is too complex for the training data, only the vertical part of the Rashomon curve is observed. Right Figure: The state-of-the-art for the various public ML problems\\u002Fdatasets on their own Rashomon curve, indicating whether it\u2019s likely to be too complex or too simple for the given ML task\\u002Fdataset pairs.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_25.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_25.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ\":{\"id\":\"0*W2ULTHBvFSvLLZYZ\",\"originalHeight\":658,\"originalWidth\":1600,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_25.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":12,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_25.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":931,\"end\":944,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_26\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_26\",\"name\":\"33a2\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"When solving an ML problem, one might consider a hierarchy of model classes starting from simpler to more complex model (hypothesis) classes. In the beginning, the model classes remain too simple for the ML task and the model\u2019s error rate continues to decrease with increasing complexity. This observation corresponds to moving along the horizontal part of the Rashomon curve from right to left. In this case, the Rashomon volume grows at about the same rate as the volume of all the set of all possible models (with varying accuracy). In the regime when the ML model classes start to become too complex for the ML tasks, the model error rates remain the same. This corresponds to traversing the vertical part of the Rashomon curve from the top toward the bottom. In this regime, the set of all possible models outgrow the Rashomon set and the Rashomon ratio drops sharply. The turning point in the Rashomon curve (\u201cRashomon elbow\u201d) is a sweet spot where lower complexity (higher log Rashomon ratio) and higher accuracy (low empirical risk) meet. Thus, among the hierarchy of model classes, those that fall in the vicinity of the Rashomon elbow are likely to have the right level of complexity for achieving the best balance of high accuracy with desired properties such as generalizability and interpretability.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_26.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_26.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":915,\"end\":931,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_27\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_27\",\"name\":\"0cf0\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Local vs. Global Explanation\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_28\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_28\",\"name\":\"3086\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Interpretability methods can provide two types of explanations: local and global\u00b9\u2076. Local explanations describe how a model classifies a single data instance, and answer questions such as, \u201cWhich data element(s) are most responsible for the classification output?\u201d In image classification, this is equivalent to identifying which pixel is responsible for a \u201ccat\u201d image class prediction, and by how much. Local explanations are crucial for investigating ML decisions around individual data points.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_28.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_28.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_28.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":80,\"end\":82,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1702.08608\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_28.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":189,\"end\":264,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_29\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_29\",\"name\":\"9d63\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"LIME [local interpretable model-agnostic explanations taken from [2]]. The original model\u2019s decision function is represented by the blue\\u002Fpink background, and is clearly nonlinear. The bright red cross is the instance being explained (let\u2019s call it X). Perturbed instances are sampled around X and are weighted according to their proximity to X (weight here is represented by size). Original model predictions are calculated on these perturbed instances. These are used to train a linear model (dashed line) that approximates the model well in the vicinity of X. Note that the explanation in this case is not faithful globally, but it is faithful locally around X.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_29.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_29.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB\":{\"id\":\"0*I-DacdShKkkfWYqB\",\"originalHeight\":350,\"originalWidth\":544,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_29.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":65,\"end\":68,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fpdf\\u002F1602.04938.pdf\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_29.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":4,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_30\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_30\",\"name\":\"ed47\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*brbVrR62wTlHjd5g\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"This figure illustrates a local explanation of Google\u2019s Inception neural network on some arbitrary image. d\":\"c8566e5c313c_33\",\"name\":\"fafe\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"The two most popular techniques for global explanations are feature importance and partial dependence plots. Feature importance provides a score that indicates how useful or valuable each feature was in the construction of the model. In models based on decision trees (like random forests or gradient boosting), the more a feature is used to make key decisions within the decision trees, the higher its relative importance. Partial dependence plots (PDP) show the dependence between the target variable and a set of \u201ctarget\u201d features, marginalizing over the values of all other features (the \u201ccomplement\u201d features). Intuitively, we can interpret the partial dependence as the expected target response as a function of the \u201ctarget\u201d features. A partial dependence plot helps us understand how a specific feature value affects predictions, which can be useful for model and data debugging as demonstrated in\u00b9\u00b2.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_33.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_33.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_33.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":83,\"end\":107,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fscikit-learn.org\\u002Fstable\\u002Fmodules\\u002Fpartial_dependence.html\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_33.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":904,\"end\":906,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fdl.acm.org\\u002Fcitation.cfm?id=2788613\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_34\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_34\",\"name\":\"b39e\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Feature-based vs. concept-based explanation\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_35\",\"name\":\"8374\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Early interpretability methods relied on using input features to construct the explanation. This approach is known as feature-based explanation. A key difficulty with feature-based explanations is that most ML models operate on features, such as pixel values, that do not correspond to high-level concepts that humans can easily understand. In her KDD XAI 2019 keynote, Been Kim, Senior Research Scientist at Google Brain, pointed out that feature-based explanations applied to state-of-the-art complex black-box models (such as InceptionV3 or GoogleLeNet) can yield non-sensible explanations\u00b9\u2077 \u00b9\u2078. More importantly, feature-based explanations for ML problems where the input features have high dimensionality does not necessarily lead to human-friendly explanations.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.3\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.4\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":370,\"end\":378,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fai.google\\u002Fresearch\\u002Fpeople\\u002F106045\\u002F\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":529,\"end\":540,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1512.00567\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":544,\"end\":555,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fai.google\\u002Fresearch\\u002Fpubs\\u002Fpub43022\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.3\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":592,\"end\":594,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1810.03292\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_35.markups.4\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":595,\"end\":597,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1907.09701\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_36\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_36\",\"name\":\"91eb\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Testing with concept activation vectors (TCAV) quantitatively measures how a \u201cconcept\u201d (defined by a collection of inputs) is learned by a trained model by quantifying sensitivity of a model prediction class along the direction of concept activation vectors (CAVs). CAVs are defined per layer and per concept by training a linear classifier [such as support vector machine (SVM)] over the activation states of a layer of a pre-trained network using a collection of \u201cconcept-defining\u201d inputs vs. random inputs (CAV testing inputs). These CAV testing inputs can be constructed post-hoc and do not need to be part of the training\\u002Fevaluation and target task-specific datasets. TCAV can be used with both black box complex models as well as interpretable models. TCAV is currently publicly available at : https:\\u002F\\u002Fgithub.com\\u002Ftensorflow\\u002Ftcav\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_36.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_36.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc\":{\"id\":\"0*uQKgURRfKe_3puSc\",\"originalHeight\":804,\"originalWidth\":1540,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_36.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":800,\"end\":834,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fgithub.com\\u002Ftensorflow\\u002Ftcav\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_36.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":0,\"end\":47,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_37\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_37\",\"name\":\"8f9e\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Concept-based explainability constructs the explanation based on human-defined concepts rather than a representation of the inputs based on features and internal model (activation) states. To achieve this, the input feature and model internal state and human-defined concept are represented in two vector spaces: (Em) and (Eh), respectively. The functional mapping between these two vector spaces, if it exists, provides a way of extracting human-defined concepts from input features and ML model internal states.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_38\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_38\",\"name\":\"d0c2\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"In her keynote, Kim presented testing with concept activation vector (TCAV), a procedure to quantitatively translate between the human-defined concept space (Eh) and the model internal state (Em)\u00b9\u2079. TCAV requires two main ingredients: (1) concept-containing inputs and negative samples (random inputs), and (2) pretrained ML models on which the concepts are tested. To test how well a trained ML model captured a particular concept, the concept-containing and random inputs are inferenced on subcomponents (layers) of a trained ML model. Then, a linear classifier such as a support vector machine is trained to distinguish the activation of the network due to concept-containing vs. random inputs. A result of this training are concept activation vectors (CAVs). Once CAVs are defined, the directional derivative of the class probability along CAVs can be computed for each instance that belong to a class. Finally, the \u201cconcept importance\u201d for a class is computed as a fraction of the instances in the class that get positively activated by the concept containing inputs vs. random inputs. This approach allows humans to ask whether a model \u201clearns\u201d a particular expressible concept, and how well.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_38.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_38.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":195,\"end\":197,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Farxiv.org\\u002Fabs\\u002F1711.11279\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_39\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_39\",\"name\":\"eea7\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"For example, a human can ask how well a computer vision model \u201cX\u201d learns to associate the concept of \u201cwhite coat\u201d or \u201cstethoscope\u201d in doctor images using TCAV. To do this, human testers can first assemble a collection of images containing white coats and random images, then apply the pretrained \u201cX\u201d on this collection of images to get the predictions, and compute the TCAV scores for the \u201cwhite coat\u201d concept. This TCAV score quantifies how important the concept of \u201cwhite coat\u201d was to a prediction of class \u201cdoctor\u201d in an image classification task. TCAV is an example-driven approach, so it still requires careful selection of the concept data instances as inputs. TCAV also relies on humans to generate concepts to test, and on having the concept be expressible in the concept inputs.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_40\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_40\",\"name\":\"4f3b\",\"type\":\"IMG\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":\"INSET_CENTER\",\"metadata\":{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":false,\"id\":\"ImageMetadata:0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z\",\"typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"text\":\"Example of a realistic use of TCAV to quantify how much the concepts of \u201cwhite coat,\u201d \u201cstethoscope,\u201d and \u201cmale\u201d are important for an image classification model for a positive prediction of the \u201cdoctor\u201d class.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_40.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"ImageMetadata:0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z\":{\"id\":\"0*hBDGy-T7U7U3ng1z\",\"originalHeight\":387,\"originalWidth\":862,\"focusPercentX\":null,\"focusPercentY\":null,\"alt\":null,\"__typename\":\"ImageMetadata\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_40.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"STRONG\",\"start\":30,\"end\":34,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_41\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_41\",\"name\":\"0ea4\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Concept-based interpretability methods like TCAV are a step toward extracting \u201chuman-friendly\u201d ML explanations. It is up to today\u2019s ML practitioners to make responsible and correct judgment calls on whether model predictions are sensible, and whether they align with our positive values. It is up to us to correct the defects in trained black-box ML models, and TCAV can help illuminate where the flaws are.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_42\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_42\",\"name\":\"b0b1\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"What can we do better?\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:c8566e5c313c_43\":{\"id\":\"c8566e5c313c_43\",\"name\":\"4f82\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"As a community of ML practitioners, it\u2019s our responsibility to clearly define what we want Explainable AI to become, and to establish guidelines for generating explanations that take into consideration what piece of information to use, how (in what manner) to construct the explainability in a way that is beneficial (not harmful or abusive), and when (in which situation\\u002Fcontext and to whom) to deliver it. 1.03L10.8 31.4v.4h6.97v-.4L15.3 28.4c-.29-.34-.34-.5-.34-1.03v-8.95l6.13 13.36h.71l5.26-13.36v10.64c0 .3 0 .35-.19.53l-1.85 1.8v.4h9.2v-.4l-1.83-1.8c-.18-.18-.2-.24-.2-.53V15.94c0-.3.02-.35.2-.53l1.82-1.8v-.4h-6.47l-4.62 11.55-5.2-11.54h-6.8v.4l2.15 2.63c.24.3.29.37.29.77v10.35z\">\n              </path>\n             </svg>\n            </div>\n           </a>\n           <div class=\"ba g\">\n            <div class=\"bc\" id=\"lo-post-page-navbar-open-in-app-button\">\n             <div class=\"bd ba bb\">\n              <a class=\"be bf bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bo bp bq br bs bt\" href=\"https://rsci.app.link/?%24canonical_url=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fp%2Fef6ac4175e55&amp;~feature=LoMobileNavBar&amp;source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\">\n               Open in app\n              </a>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"ba al\">\n            <div class=\"bu bv r g\">\n             <svg height=\"29\" width=\"2\">\n              <path d=\"M1 29V1\" fill=\"none\" stroke=\"#D5D5D5\" stroke-linecap=\"round\" stroke-width=\"0.5\">\n              </path>\n             </svg>\n            </div>\n            <div class=\"bc\" id=\"lo-post-page-navbar-topic-copy\">\n             <a href=\"https://medium.com/topic/?source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n              <div class=\"an ao ap aq ar as at au av aw ax ay az\">\n              </div>\n             </a>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"r bw w\">\n          <div class=\"n o\">\n           <div class=\"n g\">\n            <div class=\"bc\" id=\"lo-post-page-navbar-upsell-button\">\n             <div>\n              <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/membership?source=upgrade_membership---nav_full------------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               <span class=\"cd b ce cf cg ch r ci cj\">\n                Become a member\n               </span>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n            <div class=\"bc\" id=\"lo-post-page-navbar-sign-in-link\">\n             <div class=\"bd r\">\n              <span class=\"cd b ce cf cg ch r ci cj\">\n               <a class=\"be bf bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bo bp bq br bs bt\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=login&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40einat_93627%2Funderstand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55&amp;source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                Sign in\n               </a>\n              </span>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n     </div>\n    </nav>\n    <div class=\"ck aj r cl ak\">\n    </div>\n    <article>\n     <section class=\"cm cn co cp ai cq cr n cs\">\n     </section>\n     <span class=\"r\">\n     </span>\n     <div>\n      <div class=\"s u ct cu cv cw\">\n      </div>\n      <section class=\"cx cy cz da db\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dc ah ai\">\n         <div>\n          <div class=\"dd de ap ce df b dg dh di dj dk dl dm dn do dp dq\" id=\"a259\">\n           <h1 class=\"df b dg dr di ds dk dt dm du do dv ap\">\n            Understand Your Black Box Model Using Sensitivity Analysis\u200a\u2014\u200aPractical Guide\n           </h1>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"dw de ci ce cd dx dy dz ea eb ec ed ee ef eg eh ei\" id=\"e7bc\">\n          <h2 class=\"cd dx dy ej ea ek ec el ee em eg en ci\">\n           How each feature affects my model\u2019s predictions\n          </h2>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"eo\">\n          <div class=\"n ep eq er es\">\n           <div class=\"o n\">\n            <div>\n             <a href=\"/@einat_93627?source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n              <img alt=\"Einat Naaman\" class=\"r et eu ev\" height=\"48\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/96/96/1*PDDiE6BS8v5HpieEgKAmMw.jpeg\" width=\"48\"/>\n             </a>\n            </div>\n            <div class=\"ew ai r\">\n             <div class=\"n\">\n              <div style=\"flex:1\">\n               <span class=\"cd b ce cf cg ch r ap q\">\n                <div class=\"ex n o ey\">\n                 <span class=\"cd dx ez cf av fa fb as at au ap\">\n                  <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn fc bq br cb cc\" href=\"/@einat_93627?source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                   Einat Naaman\n                  </a>\n                 </span>\n                 <div class=\"fd r bw h\">\n                  <button class=\"fe ap q ff fg fh fi fj bn cb fk fl fm fn fo fp fq cd b ce fr fs ch ft fu cr fv fw bq\">\n                   Follow\n                  </button>\n                 </div>\n                </div>\n               </span>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n             <span class=\"cd b ce cf cg ch r ci cj\">\n              <span class=\"cd dx ez cf av fa fb as at au ci\">\n               <div>\n                <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn fc bq br cb cc\" href=\"/@einat_93627/understand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55?source=post_page-----ef6ac4175e55----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                 Jan 28, 2019\n                </a>\n                <!-- -->\n                \u00b7\n                <!-- -->\n                <!-- -->\n                6\n                <!-- -->\n                min read\n               </div>\n              </span>\n             </span>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"n fx fy fz ga gb gc gd ge y\">\n            <div class=\"n o\">\n             <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n              <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ef6ac4175e55/share/twitter?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65 2.26c.03 1.6.83 2.99 2.02 3.79a4.3 4.3 0 0 1-2.02-.57v.08a4.55 4.55 0 0 0 3.63 4.44c-.4.08-.8.13-1.21.16l-.81-.08a4.54 4.54 0 0 0 4.2 3.15 9.56 9.56 0 0 1-5.66 1.94l-1.05-.08c2 1.27 4.38 2.02 6.94 2.02 8.3 0 12.86-6.9 12.84-12.85.02-.24 0-.43 0-.65a8.68 8.68 0 0 0 2.26-2.34c-.82.38-1.7.62-2.6.72a4.37 4.37 0 0 0 1.95-2.51c-.84.53-1.81.9-2.83 1.13z\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n              <button class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\" height=\"29\" viewbox=\"0 0 29 29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M5 6.36C5 5.61 5.63 5 6.4 5h16.2c.77 0 1.4.61 1.4 1.36v16.28c0 .75-.63 1.36-1.4 1.36H6.4c-.77 0-1.4-.6-1.4-1.36V6.36z\">\n                </path>\n                <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 1.48h.01zM12.35 20.9h2.87v-4.79c0-.25.02-.5.1-.7.2-.5.67-1.04 1.46-1.04 1.04 0 1.46.8 1.46 1.95v4.59h2.87v-4.92c0-2.64-1.42-3.87-3.3-3.87-1.55 0-2.23.86-2.61 1.45h.02v-1.24h-2.87c.04.8 0 8.58 0 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </button>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n              <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ef6ac4175e55/share/facebook?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n               <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gg r\">\n              <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40einat_93627%2Funderstand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55&amp;source=post_actions_header--------------------------bookmark_header-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n                <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 5.66 4.13a.5.5 0 0 0 .71-.03.5.5 0 0 0 .12-.29H19V6zm-6.84 9.97L7 19.64V6a1 1 0 0 1 1-1h9a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v13.64l-5.16-3.67a.49.49 0 0 0-.68 0z\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                </path>\n               </svg>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"gh r am\">\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"74d1\">\n          Interpretability of models has become an extremely\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"http://arxiv.org/abs/1702.08608\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           popular topic in the recent years\n          </a>\n          and there are many researches in the field. Data scientists today are required not only to create a model with excellent performance, but also to explain certain aspects of the model. Understanding the model is crucial to validate its correctness, detect bias or leakages, and even learn new patterns in the data. This task can be sometimes very complicated, as a complex model is required to get state of the art performance and this usually comes at the price of interpretability.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"gz ha hb hc hd he co cp paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hf hg hh hi ai\">\n           <div class=\"co cp gy\">\n            <div class=\"ho r hh hp\">\n             <div class=\"hq r\">\n              <div class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai av hm hn\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai hr hs ht\" height=\"1279\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg?q=20\" width=\"1920\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai hu\" height=\"1279\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 700w\" width=\"1920\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai\" height=\"1279\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/3840/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*PTOcjuy_TDkSrTZn0PE_dQ.jpeg 700w\" width=\"1920\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"ci ez hv hw hx cq co cp hy hz cd dx\">\n           https://pixabay.com/en/view-eyes-by-looking-woman-frame-1782619/\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"89fd\">\n          Interpretability can be categorized into two: global interpretability which gives explanations about the behavior of the model over the entire population, and local interpretability which gives explanation regarding a specific prediction.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"37ff\">\n          In this post I will present a technique for global interpretability of black box models\u200a\u2014\u200afeature sensitivity. What I love about this method is that it uses only the model\u2019s prediction function, and thus can be used to interpret practically any model. I will explain the technique and how to implement it in production.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ia ib ap ce cd ic dg id di ie if ig ih ii ij ik il\" id=\"d503\">\n          Sensitivity analysis\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy im ea in gn io gp ip gr iq gt cx\" id=\"f8aa\">\n          A simple yet powerful way to understand a machine learning model is by doing sensitivity analysis where we examine what impact each feature has on the model\u2019s prediction. To calculate feature sensitivity we change the feature value or try to ignore it somehow while all the other features stay constant, and see the output of the model. If by changing the feature value the model\u2019s outcome has altered drastically, it means that this feature has a big impact on the prediction.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"e426\">\n          Formally, given a test set\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           X\n          </em>\n          , we would like to measure the sensitivity of feature i. We create a new set\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           X*\n          </em>\n          where we apply a transformation T over feature i. We perform prediction on\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           X\n          </em>\n          and denote the prediction vector as\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           Y\n          </em>\n          . We perform prediction on\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           X*\n          </em>\n          and denote the prediction vector as\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           Y*\n          </em>\n          . To measure the change in the outcome we use our score metric while using\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           Y\n          </em>\n          as the true y. We let\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           S\n          </em>\n          be the original score \u2014 this is the score of the model on\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           X\n          </em>\n          (for accuracy for example, this will be 1) and\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           S*\n          </em>\n          be the new score, the score after changing the feature value. The sensitivity for feature i will then be\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           S-S*\n          </em>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"gz ha hb hc hd he co cp paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hf hg hh hi ai\">\n           <div class=\"co cp is\">\n            <div class=\"ho r hh hp\">\n             <div class=\"it r\">\n              <div class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai av hm hn\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai hr hs ht\" height=\"498\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/freeze/max/60/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif?q=20\" width=\"876\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai hu\" height=\"498\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 700w\" width=\"876\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai\" height=\"498\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/1752/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*qM93TiFH6zQszsBKWNY8jA.gif 700w\" width=\"876\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"ci ez hv hw hx cq co cp hy hz cd dx\">\n           Sensitivity analysis calculation process for feature i\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"69da\">\n          Let us note that there are methods for feature importance such as\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_selection#Correlation_feature_selection\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Correlation Feature Selection\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_information\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Mutual Information\n          </a>\n          that use a mathematical calculation to get the importance of a feature. Those methods can be used to select features before running the model but they don\u2019t use the model itself in their calculation. Other methods to calculate feature importance are applicable for a specific estimator, such as Random Forest Feature Importance. Those methods can\u2019t necessarily be used for black box models.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ia ib ap ce cd ic dg id di ie if ig ih ii ij ik il\" id=\"e1b0\">\n          Which transformation T should I use?\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy im ea in gn io gp ip gr iq gt cx\" id=\"8b09\">\n          We would like to measure the change in the prediction after changing the feature value, however, different transformations result in different changes. I will describe three transformations, while each has it\u2019s own advantages:\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"5903\">\n          Uniform distribution\u200a\u2014\u200areplace the feature value with another one from the possible feature values with uniform probability. Notice that in this case the sensitivity measure is affected by all possible feature values equally. Lets have a look at this example to illustrate an\u00a0issue\u00a0that\u00a0should\u00a0be considered\u00a0when\u00a0using\u00a0this\u00a0transformation: we have a numerical feature, age, where the values range between 0 to 120 but most of the data consists of teenagers ages between 16 to 18, and changing the feature within this range doesn\u2019t affect the prediction\u00a0but\u00a0changing\u00a0it\u00a0to\u00a0be\u00a0outside\u00a0this\u00a0range does affect the prediction. If we use uniform distribution we will get high sensitivity for this feature although most of the time this feature won\u2019t affect the prediction.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"3cba\">\n          Permutation \u2014 permute the feature values. By using permutation we use the real distribution of the feature values in the data. In this approach the sensitivity measure will mostly be affected by values that appear more in the data. The main advantage in doing so is that the result we get consider the population of the data. An issue that may occur here is that a skewed feature will get low sensitivity although changing the feature will actually affect the data.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"cd45\">\n          Missing values\u200a\u2014\u200atry to simulate that the feature doesn\u2019t exist in model. In models such as neural network you can do it by insert zero. Alternatively, you can use the mean for numerical feature, new class for categorical feature, value with the highest probability, or any other way you use to impute your data.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ia ib ap ce cd ic dg id di ie if ig ih ii ij ik il\" id=\"d51a\">\n          Production Considerations\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy im ea in gn io gp ip gr iq gt cx\" id=\"aafd\">\n          Feature sensitivity analysis requires calculation of many predictions. To be exact,\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           n_samples x n_features\n          </em>\n          predictions, were\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           n_samples\n          </em>\n          is the the number of samples in our test set and\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           n_features\n          </em>\n          is the number of features. We can use batches to reduce this number but there still be many predictions to calculate, and many algorithms such as Random Forest require a long time to perform prediction. There are a couple of ways to overcome this issue:\n         </p>\n         <ol class=\"\">\n          <li class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt iu iv iw\" id=\"6bfa\">\n           Subsampling \u2014 using a couple of thousands of samples while using a simple splitting strategy as stratified splitting will mostly be sufficient.\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy ix ea iy gn iz gp ja gr jb gt iu iv iw\" id=\"f7a0\">\n           Parallelization- We can run predictions simultaneously to use multiprocessing to increase the prediction rate. In production, we are often limited by the amount of RAM which can be used. Determining the maximum #processes which can be used can be tricky in such cases. We can initially perform a few batch predictions in a serial manner. These can be used to approximate the memory needed for a prediction, and then use as much threads as possible (without breaking our memory limitation).\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy ix ea iy gn iz gp ja gr jb gt iu iv iw\" id=\"84ed\">\n           Multiple stages\u200a\u2014\u200aFinally, in case we have a lot of features, we can further reduce the amount of predictions by calculating feature sensitivity twice. In the first time we use a small amount of samples (up to a couple of hundreds). This get us a sensitivity measure for all features but it\u2019s relatively inaccurate because we use only a few samples. We then filter the best features and recalculate sensitivity analysis for them over all test set (or the subsampled set). This way we get a reliable sensitivity measure for the most important features, which is what we need.\n          </li>\n         </ol>\n         <h1 class=\"ia ib ap ce cd ic dg id di ie if ig ih ii ij ik il\" id=\"6b52\">\n          Real-world example\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy im ea in gn io gp ip gr iq gt cx\" id=\"6003\">\n          I work as a data scientist at\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://firefly.ai/\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Firefly.ai\n          </a>\n          , were we build automatically models that can consist of ensemble of models, each with its own pipeline of imputation, feature engineering, selection, and estimator which are selected out of hundreds of algorithms. I encountered with\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://www.kaggle.com/c/costa-rican-household-poverty-prediction\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           Costa Rican Household Poverty Level Prediction\n          </a>\n          competition from kaggle, where we would like to predict the income of households in Costa Rica. I run this competition using our automl system and got recall macro score of 0.9. To understand what the model learned lets have a look at the sensitivity analysis graph (created using permutation transformation) of the top-10 features. The sensitivity values are normalized to sum to 100. The graph shows that the two most important features for the model were\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           SQBdependency\n          </em>\n          (working-age population) and\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           meaneduc\n          </em>\n          (average years of education for adults). The importance of those features make sense, but the magnitude of the importance relatively to other features such as number of rooms is very surprising.\n         </p>\n         <figure class=\"gz ha hb hc hd he co cp paragraph-image\">\n          <div class=\"hf hg hh hi ai\">\n           <div class=\"co cp jc\">\n            <div class=\"ho r hh hp\">\n             <div class=\"jd r\">\n              <div class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai av hm hn\">\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai hr hs ht\" height=\"698\" role=\"presentation\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/60/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg?q=20\" width=\"1200\"/>\n              </div>\n              <img class=\"hj hk s t u hl ai hu\" height=\"698\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 700w\" width=\"1200\"/>\n              <noscript>\n               <img class=\"s t u hl ai\" height=\"698\" role=\"presentation\" sizes=\"700px\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/2400/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg\" srcset=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/552/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 276w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1104/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 552w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1280/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 640w, https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1*8oWV4SrAigCUtIVHrXa6mA.jpeg 700w\" width=\"1200\"/>\n              </noscript>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n          <figcaption class=\"ci ez hv hw hx cq co cp hy hz cd dx\">\n           Costa Rican household poverty level sensitivity analysis graph\n          </figcaption>\n         </figure>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"0d25\">\n          Now, I can use the insights from the analysis to get even better model. For example I can remove the features that have very little affect on the model, or I can remove features that affect the model and I think may cause to overfitting. If there is a leakage feature, it will be shown as important feature in the graph so I\u2019ll see it immediately. Also, I can investigate more the patterns that I saw, for example how\n          <em class=\"ir\">\n           SQBdependency\n          </em>\n          affect the model, meaning what are the ranges of working-age population that the model predicts high income, etc.\n         </p>\n         <h1 class=\"ia ib ap ce cd ic dg id di ie if ig ih ii ij ik il\" id=\"52e8\">\n          Last words\n         </h1>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy im ea in gn io gp ip gr iq gt cx\" id=\"0560\">\n          Feature sensitivity is a very easy-to-use and intuitive technique to understand which are the features that affect most the model. There are more advanced methods for global interpretability such as\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1309.6392.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           PDP\n          </a>\n          , which allows finding out trends.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gi gj ap ce gk b dy gl ea gm gn go gp gq gr gs gt cx\" id=\"4d2a\">\n          Other methods of model evaluation deal with local interpretability, namely understanding the prediction of a specific example. Many times there comes the need to explain a particular instance, for example to understand why a model predicts that one shouldn\u2019t get a loan.\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1602.04938v1.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           LIME\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a class=\"bx fw gu gv gw gx\" href=\"http://papers.nips.cc/paper/7062-a-unified-approach-to-interpreting-model-predictions.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           SHAP\n          </a>\n          address this issue.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n    </article>\n    <div class=\"hj cw je jf ai jm jk jn\" data-test-id=\"post-sidebar\">\n     <div class=\"n p\">\n      <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n       <div class=\"jo n cs\">\n        <div class=\"cw\">\n         <div class=\"jp jq jr n\">\n          <div class=\"n o\">\n           <div class=\"js r hh\">\n            <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40einat_93627%2Funderstand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55&amp;source=post_sidebar-----ef6ac4175e55---------------------clap_sidebar-\" 0 0-2.67-.01 1.87 1.87 0 0 0-.5.9c-.76-.75-2-.75-2.7-.04a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66c-.3.12-.61.29-.87.55a1.88 1.88 0 0 0 0 2.66l.62.62a1.88 1.88 0 0 0-.9 3.16l5.01 5.02c1.6 1.6 3.52 2.64 5.4 2.96a7.16        </a>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"kd r\">\n            <div class=\"ke\">\n             <h4 class=\"cd dx ez cf ci\">\n              <button class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bm\">\n          <li class=\"fv ki gg kj\">\n           <a class=\"kk kl fw ci r km kn a b fs\" href=\"/tag/machine-learning\">\n            Machine Learning\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fv ki gg kj\">\n           <a class=\"kk kl fw ci r km kn a b fs\" href=\"/tag/interpretability\">\n            Interpretability\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fv ki gg kj\">\n           <a class=\"kk kl fw ci r km kn a b fs\" href=\"/tag/explainability\">\n            Explainability\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fv ki gg kj\">\n           <a class=\"kk kl fw ci r km kn a b fs\" href=\"/tag/sensitivity-analysis\">\n            Sensitivity Analysis\n           </a>\n          </li>\n          <li class=\"fv ki gg kj\">\n           <a class=\"kk kl fw ci r km kn a b fs\" href=\"/tag/feature-importance\">\n            Feature Importance\n           </a>\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"ko n ep y\">\n         <div class=\"n o\">\n          <div class=\"kp r hh\">\n           <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40einat_93627%2Funderstand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55&amp;source=post_actions_footer-----ef6ac4175e55---------------------clap_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            <div class=\"c kq et n o kr hh ks kt ku kv kw kx ky kz la lb lc ld le lf\">\n             <div class=\"bl jt ju jv jw jx lg jz o hu et n p lh u hl s t ai ka kb kc <div class=\"kd r\">\n           <div class=\"ke\">\n            <h4 class=\"cd dx ez cf ap\">\n             <button class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\">\n              137 claps\n             </button>\n            </h4>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"n o\">\n          <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n           <a class=\"bx by bg    <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65         </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n           <button class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\">\n            <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\" height=\"29\" viewbox=\"0 0 29 29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M5 6.36C5 5.61 5.63 5 6.4 5h16.2c.77 0 1.4.61 1.4 1.36v16.28c0 .75-.63 1.36-1.4 1.36H6.4c-.77 0-1.4-.6-1.4-1.36V6.36z\">\n             </path>\n             <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 1.48h.01zM12.35 20.9h2.87v-4.79c0-.25.02-.5.1-.7.2-.5.67-1.04 1.46-1.04 1.04 0 1.46.8 1.46 1.95v4.59h2.87v-4.92c0-2.64-1.42-3.87-3.3-3.87-1.55 0-2.23.86-2.61 1.45h.02v-1.24h-2.87c.04.8 0 8.58 0 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n             </path>\n            </svg>\n           </button>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"gf r bw\">\n           <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"//medium.com/p/ef6ac4175e55/share/facebook?source=post_actions_footer---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n            <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n             </path>\n            </svg>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"lj r bw\">\n           <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F%40einat_93627%2Funderstand-your-black-box-model-using-sensitivity-analysis-practical-guide-ef6ac4175e55&amp;source=post_actions_footer--------------------------bookmark_footer-\"
