</svg>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"lk ll lm kh r y\">\n         <div class=\"ln lo r hh\">\n          <span class=\"r lp al lq\">\n           <div class=\"r s lr ls\">\n            <a href=\"/@einat_93627?source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n             <img alt=\"Einat Naaman\" class=\"r et lt lu\" height=\"80\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/160/160/1*PDDiE6BS8v5HpieEgKAmMw.jpeg\" width=\"80\"/>\n            </a>\n           </div>\n           <span class=\"r\">\n            <div class=\"lv r lw\">\n             <p class=\"cd dx fs cf ci lx ly\">\n              Written by\n             </p>\n            </div>\n            <div class=\"lv lz n lw\">\n             <div class=\"ai n o ep\">\n              <h2 class=\"cd ic ma mb ap\">\n               <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"/@einat_93627?source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                Einat Naaman\n               </a>\n              </h2>\n              <div class=\"r g\">\n               <button class=\"mc ap q ff fg fh fi fj bn cb fk fl fm fn fo fp fq cd b ce cf cg ch ft fu cr fv fw bq\">\n                Follow\n               </button>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </span>\n          </span>\n          <div class=\"lv md r lw bb\">\n           <div class=\"me r\">\n            <h4 class=\"cd dx mf mg ci\">\n             Machine Learning Researcher @Firefly.ai\n            </h4>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"ba mh bb\">\n            <button class=\"mc ap q ff fg fh fi fj bn cb fk fl fm fn fo fp fq cd b ce cf cg ch ft fu cr fv fw bq\">\n             Follow\n            </button>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"mi ll r y\">\n         <a class=\"bx by bg bh bi bj bk bl bm bn bz ca bq br cb cc\" href=\"https://medium.com/p/ef6ac4175e55/responses/show?source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n          <span class=\"mj mk jw\">\n           <div class=\"ml mm fq r hx bb\">\n            <span class=\"be\">\n             See responses (2)\n            </span>\n of models has become an extremely popular topic in the recent years and there are many researches in the field. this post I will present a technique for global interpretability of black box models\u200a\u2014\u200afeature sensitivity. What I love about this method is that it uses only the model\u2019s prediction function, and thus can be used to interpret practically any model. I will explain the technique and how to implement it in production.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_6\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_6\",\"name\":\"d503\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Sensitivity analysis\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_7\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_7\",\"name\":\"f8aa\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"A simple yet powerful way to understand a machine learning model is by doing sensitivity analysis where we examine what impact each feature has on the model\u2019s prediction. To calculate feature sensitivity we change the feature value or try to ignore it somehow while all the other features stay constant, and see the output of the model. If by changing the feature value the model\u2019s outcome has altered drastically, it means that this feature has a big impact on the prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_8\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_8\",\"name\":\"e426\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Formally, given a test set X, we would like to measure the sensitivity of feature i. We create a new set X* where we apply a transformation T over feature i. We perform prediction on X and denote the prediction vector as Y. We perform prediction on X* and denote the prediction vector as Y*. To measure the change in the outcome we use our score metric while using Y as the true y. We let S be the original score \u2014 this is the score of the model on X (for accuracy for example, this will be 1) and S* be the new score, the score after changing the feature value. The sensitivity for feature i will then be us note that there are methods for feature importance such as Correlation Feature Selection and Mutual Information that use a mathematical calculation to get the importance of a feature. Those methods can be used to select features before running the model but they don\u2019t use the model itself in their calculation. Other methods to calculate feature importance are applicable for a specific estimator, such as Random Forest Feature Importance. Those methods can\u2019t necessarily be used for black box models.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_10.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_10.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_10.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":66,\"end\":95,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\\u002Fwiki\\u002FFeature_selection#Correlation_feature_selection\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_10.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"A\",\"start\":100,\"end\":118,\"href\":\"https:\\u002F\\u002Fen.wikipedia.org\\u002Fwiki\\u002FMutual_information\",\"anchorType\":\"LINK\",\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_11\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_11\",\"name\":\"e1b0\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Which transformation T should I use?\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_12\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_12\",\"name\":\"8b09\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"We would like to measure the change in the prediction after changing the feature value, however, different transformations result in different changes. I will describe three transformations, while each has it\u2019s own advantages:\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_13\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_13\",\"name\":\"5903\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Uniform distribution\u200a\u2014\u200areplace the feature value with another one from the possible feature values with uniform probability. Notice that in this case the sensitivity measure is affected by all possible feature values equally. Lets have a look at this example to illustrate an\u00a0issue\u00a0that\u00a0should\u00a0be considered\u00a0when\u00a0using\u00a0this\u00a0transformation: we have a numerical feature, age, where the values range between 0 to 120 but most of the data consists of teenagers ages between 16 to 18, and changing the feature within this range doesn\u2019t affect the prediction\u00a0but\u00a0changing\u00a0it\u00a0to\u00a0be\u00a0outside\u00a0this\u00a0range does affect the prediction. If we use uniform distribution we will get high sensitivity for this feature although most of the time this feature won\u2019t affect the prediction.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_14\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_14\",\"name\":\"3cba\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Permutation \u2014 permute the feature values. By using permutation we use the real distribution of the feature values in the data. In this approach the sensitivity measure will mostly be affected by values that appear more in the data. The main advantage in doing so is that the result we get consider the population of the data. An issue that may occur here is that a skewed feature will get low sensitivity although changing the feature will actually affect the data.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_15\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_15\",\"name\":\"cd45\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Missing values\u200a\u2014\u200atry to simulate that the feature doesn\u2019t exist in model. In models such as neural network you can do it by insert zero. Alternatively, you can use the mean for numerical feature, new class for categorical feature, value with the highest probability, or any other way you use to impute your data.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_16\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_16\",\"name\":\"d51a\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Production Considerations\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_17\",\"name\":\"aafd\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Feature sensitivity analysis requires calculation of many predictions. To be exact, n_samples x n_features predictions, were n_samples is the the number of samples in our test set and n_features is the number of features. We can use batches to reduce this number but there still be many predictions to calculate, and many algorithms such as Random Forest require a long time to perform prediction. There are a couple of ways to overcome this issue:\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.2\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":84,\"end\":106,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":125,\"end\":134,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_17.markups.2\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":184,\"end\":194,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_18\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_18\",\"name\":\"6bfa\",\"type\":\"OLI\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Subsampling \u2014 using a couple of thousands of samples while using a simple splitting strategy as stratified splitting will mostly be sufficient.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_19\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_19\",\"name\":\"f7a0\",\"type\":\"OLI\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Parallelization- We can run predictions simultaneously to use multiprocessing to increase the prediction rate. In production, we are often limited by the amount of RAM which can be used. Determining the maximum #processes which can be used can be tricky in such cases. We can initially perform a few batch predictions in a serial manner. These can be used to approximate the memory needed for a prediction, and then use as much threads as possible (without breaking our memory limitation).\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_20\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_20\",\"name\":\"84ed\",\"type\":\"OLI\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Multiple stages\u200a\u2014\u200aFinally, in case we have a lot of features, we can further reduce the amount of predictions by calculating feature sensitivity twice. In the first time we use a small amount of samples (up to a couple of hundreds). This get us a sensitivity measure for all features but it\u2019s relatively inaccurate because we use only a few samples. We then filter the best features and recalculate sensitivity analysis for them over all test set (or the subsampled set). This way we get a reliable sensitivity measure for the most important features, which is what we need.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_21\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_21\",\"name\":\"6b52\",\"type\":\"H3\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"Real-world example\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:d7fd4ce9d32b_22\":{\"id\":\"d7fd4ce9d32b_22\",\"name\":\"6003\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"I work as a data scientist at Firefly.ai, were we build automatically models that can consist of ensemble of models, each with its own pipeline of imputation, feature engineering, selection, and estimator which are selected out of hundreds of algorithms. I encountered with Costa Rican Household Poverty Level Prediction competition from kaggle, where we would like to predict the income of households in Costa Rica. I run this competition using our automl system and got recall macro score of 0.9. To understand what the model learned lets have a look at the sensitivity analysis graph (created using permutation transformation) of the top-10 features. The sensitivity values are normalized to sum to 100. The graph shows that the two most important features for the model were SQBdependency (working-age population) and meaneduc (average years of education for adults). The importance of those features make sense, but the magnitude of the importance relatively to other features such as number of rooms is very </svg>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"r an w\">\n           <div class=\"n o\">\n            <div class=\"n g\">\n             <div class=\"ao\" id=\"lo-post-page-navbar-sign-in-link\">\n              <div class=\"ap r\">\n               <span class=\"aq b ar as at au r av aw\">\n                <a class=\"ax ay az ba bb bc bd be bf bg bh bi bj bk bl bm\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=login&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fattention-and-explainability-in-rnns-7fd114bb4f1f&amp;source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                 Sign in\n                </a>\n               </span>\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"bn r bo bp\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n         <div class=\"bq br n o\">\n          <div class=\"bs r an\">\n           <a href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n            <div class=\"bt bu r\">\n             <img alt=\"Towards Data Science\" class=\"\" height=\"36\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/max/200/1*mG6i4Bh_LgixUYXJgQpYsg@2x.png\" width=\"100\"/>\n            </div>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"bv r bw\">\n           <ul class=\"bx bf by bz ca n cb g cc cd ce\">\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/data-science/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Data Science\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/machine-learning/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Machine Learning\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/programming/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Programming\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/data-visualization/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Visualization\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/artificial-intelligence/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               AI\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/video/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Video\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/about-us/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               About\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n            <span class=\"cf cj ck\">\n            </span>\n            <li class=\"n o cf cg ch ci\">\n             <span class=\"aq cl cm as cn co cp\">\n              <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg cs ct bj bk cu cv\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/contribute/home?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               Contribute\n              </a>\n             </span>\n            </li>\n           </ul>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n     </div>\n    </nav>\n    <div class=\"cw cx r cy cz\">\n    </div>\n    <article>\n     <section class=\"da db dc dd ai de df n dg\">\n     </section>\n     <span class=\"r\">\n     </span>\n     <div>\n      <div class=\"s u dh di dj dk\">\n      </div>\n      <section class=\"dl dm dn do dp\">\n       <div class=\"n p\">\n        <div class=\"z ab ac ae af dq ah ai\">\n         <div>\n          <div class=\"dr ds dt ar du b dv dw dx dy dz ea eb ec ed ee ef\" id=\"a7a1\">\n           <h1 class=\"du b dv eg dx eh dz ei eb ej ed ek dt\">\n            Attention and \u201cExplainability\u201d in RNNs\n           </h1>\n          </div>\n          <div class=\"el\">\n           <div class=\"n em en eo ep\">\n            <div class=\"o n\">\n             <div>\n              <a href=\"/@oaklandthinktank?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n               <img alt=\"Anthony Repetto\" class=\"r eq er es\" height=\"48\" src=\"https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/96/96/1*7dXLqIFrBN7IgSvsN3UTBw.jpeg\" width=\"48\"/>\n              </a>\n             </div>\n             <div class=\"et ai r\">\n              <div class=\"n\">\n               <div style=\"flex:1\">\n                <span class=\"aq b ar as at au r dt q\">\n                 <div class=\"eu n o ev\">\n                  <span class=\"aq cl ew as br ex ey ez fa fb dt\">\n                   <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg fc bj bk fd fe\" href=\"/@oaklandthinktank?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                    Anthony Repetto\n                   </a>\n                  </span>\n                  <div class=\"ff r an h\">\n                   <a class=\"fg dt q fh fi fj fk fl bg fd fm fn fo fp fq fr fs aq b ar ft cm au fu fv df fw fx bj\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fattention-and-explainability-in-rnns-7fd114bb4f1f&amp;source=-6374f82a1f5c-------------------------follow_byline-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                    Follow\n                   </a>\n                  </div>\n                 </div>\n                </span>\n               </div>\n              </div>\n              <span class=\"aq b ar as at au r av aw\">\n               <span class=\"aq cl ew as br ex ey ez fa fb av\">\n                <div>\n                 <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg fc bj bk fd fe\" href=\"/attention-and-explainability-in-rnns-7fd114bb4f1f?source=post_page-----7fd114bb4f1f----------------------\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                  Apr 20, 2017\n                 </a>\n                 <!-- -->\n                 \u00b7\n                 <!-- -->\n                 <!-- -->\n                 5\n                 <!-- -->\n                 min read\n                </div>\n               </span>\n              </span>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n            <div class=\"n fy fz ga gb gc gd ge gf y\">\n             <div class=\"n o\">\n              <div class=\"gg r an\">\n               <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"//medium.com/p/7fd114bb4f1f/share/twitter?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n                <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                 <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65 2.26c.03 1.6.83 2.99 2.02 3.79a4.3 4.3 0 0 1-2.02-.57v.08a4.55 4.55 0 0 0 3.63 4.44c-.4.08-.8.13-1.21.16l-.81-.08a4.54 4.54 0 0 0 4.2 3.15 9.56 9.56 0 0 1-5.66 1.94l-1.05-.08c2 1.27 4.38 2.02 6.94 2.02 8.3 0 12.86-6.9 12.84-12.85.02-.24 0-.43 0-.65a8.68 8.68 0 0 0 2.26-2.34c-.82.38-1.7.62-2.6.72a4.37 4.37 0 0 0 1.95-2.51c-.84.53-1.81.9-2.83 1.13z\">\n                 </path>\n                </svg>\n               </a>\n              </div>\n              <div class=\"gg r an\">\n               <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\">\n                <svg class=\"q\" fill=\"none\" height=\"29\" viewbox=\"0 0 29 29\" width=\"29\">\n                 <path d=\"M5 6.36C5 5.61 5.63 5 6.4 5h16.2c.77 0 1.4.61 1.4 1.36v16.28c0 .75-.63 1.36-1.4 1.36H6.4c-.77 0-1.4-.6-1.4-1.36V6.36z\">\n                 </path>\n                 <path clip-rule=\"evenodd\" d=\"M10.76 20.9v-8.57H7.89v8.58h2.87zm-1.44-9.75c1 0 1.63-.65 1.63-1.48-.02-.84-.62-1.48-1.6-1.48-.99 0-1.63.64-1.63 1.48 0 .83.62 1.48 1.59 1.48h.01zM12.35 20.9h2.87v-4.79c0-.25.02-.5.1-.7.2-.5.67-1.04 1.46-1.04 1.04 0 1.46.8 1.46 1.95v4.59h2.87v-4.92c0-2.64-1.42-3.87-3.3-3.87-1.55 0-2.23.86-2.61 1.45h.02v-1.24h-2.87c.04.8 0 8.58 0 8.58z\" fill=\"#fff\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                 </path>\n                </svg>\n               </button>\n              </div>\n              <div class=\"gg r an\">\n               <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"//medium.com/p/7fd114bb4f1f/share/facebook?source=post_actions_header---------------------------\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n                <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n                 <path d=\"M23.2 5H5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8.8V23.2c0 .44.35.8.8.8h9.3v-7.13h-2.38V13.9h2.38v-2.38c0-2.45 1.55-3.66 3.74-3.66 1.05 0 1.95.08 2.2.11v2.57h-1.5c-1.2 0-1.48.57-1.48 1.4v1.96h2.97l-.6 2.97h-2.37l.05 7.12h5.1a.8.8 0 0 0 .79-.8V5.8a.8.8 0 0 0-.8-.79\">\n                 </path>\n                </svg>\n               </a>\n              </div>\n              <div class=\"gj r\">\n               <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fattention-and-explainability-in-rnns-7fd114bb4f1f&amp;source=post_actions_header--------------------------bookmark_header-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n                <svg height=\"25\" viewbox=\"0 0 25 25\" width=\"25\">\n                 <path d=\"M19 6a2 2 0 0 0-2-2H8a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v14.66h.01c.01.1.05.2.12.28a.5.5 0 0 0 .7.03l5.67-4.12 5.66 4.13a.5.5 0 0 0 .71-.03.5.5 0 0 0 .12-.29H19V6zm-6.84 9.97L7 19.64V6a1 1 0 0 1 1-1h9a1 1 0 0 1 1 1v13.64l-5.16-3.67a.49.49 0 0 0-.68 0z\" fill-rule=\"evenodd\">\n                 </path>\n                </svg>\n               </a>\n              </div>\n              <div class=\"gk r am\">\n              </div>\n             </div>\n            </div>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"8fb8\">\n          I am exited by the movement among NN engineers (should we call them \u201cNN\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           Breeders\n          </em>\n          \u201d?) toward architectures with a \u2018dialogue\u2019 between multiple neural networks, as demonstrated by NIVIDIA\u2019s self-driving car\n          <a class=\"cq fx ha hb hc hd\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=URmxzxYlmtg\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           architecture\n          </a>\n          and Google\u2019s\n          <a class=\"cq fx ha hb hc hd\" href=\"https://papers.nips.cc/paper/5346-sequence-to-sequence-learning-with-neural-networks.pdf\" rel=\"noopener nofollow\" target=\"_blank\">\n           seq2seq\n          </a>\n          translator. Yet, there is something missing\u2026\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"9cbe\">\n          Two concerns, only partially addressed by these implementations, are\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           attention\n          </strong>\n          and\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           explainability\n          </strong>\n          . I\u2019ll explain a little about both, then I\u2019ll examine the missing piece that ties them together.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"a8bc\">\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           Attention\n          </strong>\n          :\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"3982\">\n          I\u2019ll stick to a sentence-parsing example, here. When given a long sentence, neural networks usually struggle to pay attention to relevant information. A word at the\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           beginning\n          </em>\n          of the sentence may determine the conjugation of a word near the\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           end\n          </em>\n          of the sentence, but the neural network \u2018forgot about it\u2019. Researchers tried asking networks to \u2018remember the whole thing\u2019 (by converting the entire sentence to a fixed-length vector) but that only works on sentences as elaborate as those in their training.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"6b2f\">\n          For example, \u201cJim loves parties with his friends, the foods they make together, and their decorations.\u201d A parser must link the pronouns \u2018his\u2019, \u2018they\u2019, and \u2018their\u2019 to their referents: \u2018Jim\u2019, \u2018friends\u2019, and \u2018parties\u2019. A simple LSTM architecture would reach the word \u2018their\u2019, and remember its state from the prior word: \u2018and\u2019. Hopefully, researchers argued, that state would still include some knowledge of the earlier word, \u2018parties\u2019! For short sentences, the network does remember\u2014 the network state is not disrupted much. When given longer sentences, the network tends to pick\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           recent\n          </em>\n          words, not words that make\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           sense\n          </strong>\n          . (An LSTM may decide that \u2018\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           their\n          </em>\n          decorations\u2019 meant \u2018\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           the foods\u2019\n          </em>\n          decorations\u2019\u2026)\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"8724\">\n          To overcome this problem, the seq2seq approach generates a\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           context\n          </strong>\n          vector. When a new word is encountered by the\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           encoder\n          </em>\n          network, part of the network looks around for other words in the sentence which may be relevant. The words deemed relevant are given to the\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           decoder\n          </em>\n          network. The context vector, in essence,\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           <em class=\"gz\">\n            highlights\n           </em>\n          </strong>\n          parts of the sentence and sends only those parts. It focuses the network\u2019s\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           attention\n          </strong>\n          . With this, a decoder network can receive relevant information from farther back (or forward, for Bidirectional RNN). Sentence length matters less, because only a few words are considered relevant. And, a truly general attention could \u2018hop about\u2019, picking words from a sentence of\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           any\n          </em>\n          length. (We\u2019re coming for you, Proust!)\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"8ae7\">\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           Explainability\n          </strong>\n          :\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"c26e\">\n          Neural networks are getting bigger, and more mysterious. When they make a decision, we would like to know\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           what information guided\n          </em>\n          that decision. NVIDIA\u2019s solution is to\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           display\n          </strong>\n          what the network is \u2018imagining\u2019, so that the driver can\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           see what the car thinks\n          </em>\n          about its environment. If their Driveworks neural network only shows\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           two\n          </em>\n          cars in the lanes beside you, while you can see\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           three\n          </em>\n          cars outside your window, you know something is wrong.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"5f70\">\n          In general, the ability to display what the network thinks is a powerful tool. Translations equipped with explanation would say\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           to you\n          </strong>\n          : \u201cuse \u2018la\u2019 here, because the next word is feminine.\u201d Explanations show us when the network is making decisions using reasonable generalizations, instead of memorizing a few pixels.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"c6f3\">\n          So, the industry is making progress in both of these areas. What\u2019s missing?\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"1009\">\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           Coherence\n          </strong>\n          :\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"8975\">\n          In both cases, we hope to find coherence. \u201cWhen my RNN parses a sentence, is it\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           looking where I would\n          </em>\n          , to find information? When it finds information, is it making decisions the way I would?\u201d\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"a472\">\n          The core intuition, here, comes from our own experience:\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"9bd6\">\n          What happens to your attention, and the explainability of your thoughts, as you move from \u201cI don\u2019t get what this word refers to\u2026\u201d into \u201cah, it refers to this other word, here\u201d? In general, you meet two criteria when you are making sense of things:\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"ad93\">\n          You move your attention around, until you find information that helps to make\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           sense\n          </em>\n          .\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"5ae8\">\n          When you have made sense of something, you are able to\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           explain\n          </em>\n          why it makes sense.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"6652\">\n          These statements, though simplistic, are still enough to guide design. A decoder network should be\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           hard to please\n          </em>\n          \u2014 it wants to receive a\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           particular set of words\n          </em>\n          as the\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           correct\n          </strong>\n          context. If the context vector brings words that \u201ckinda make sense,\u201d the decoder network should\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           <em class=\"gz\">\n            prefer to keep looking\n           </em>\n          </strong>\n          . (Vague description of \u2018how to keep looking\u2019 in a moment\u2026)\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"c4d3\">\n          When the decoder network decides that \u201c\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           this\n          </strong>\n          word is made coherent by\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           these other words\n          </strong>\n          , in particular,\u201d that should be\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           available for us to see\n          </em>\n          . Example: an encoder-context-decoder architecture, reading \u201cJohn gave Susan a cookie,\u201d would look at \u2018cookie\u2019 and tell us: \u2018cookie\u2019 is the indirect object of \u2018gave\u2019. This allows us to check what the network is thinking, and see if it has reasonably good judgment!\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"d01a\">\n          Let\u2019s combine these two criteria, and look at a multi-sentence example: \u201cIt wasn\u2019t going to stop any time soon. Alice didn\u2019t like it, and begrudgingly put on her shoes and grabbed an umbrella. The rain made her commute that much worse.\u201d Here, \u2018it\u2019 is the rain. And, to discover that \u2018it\u2019 means \u2018rain\u2019, a network would need to ignore most of the words in the sentences, using a context vector (scoring most words as \u20180\u2019, while the nouns \u2018Alice\u2019, \u2018shoes\u2019, \u2018umbrella\u2019, \u2018commute\u2019, and \u2018rain\u2019 have some non-zero value).\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"fe59\">\n          Suppose that the network\u2019s context vector initially preferred \u2018shoes\u2019 as the referent of \u2018it\u2019, because those words are close to each other. Passing this vector to the decoder network, however, outputs \u2018incoherent!\u2019 To follow our criteria above, the network would\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           then drop \u2018shoes\u2019 from its context vector\n          </em>\n          , and look again. On it\u2019s second try, the strongest signal is coming from \u2018umbrella\u2019 (again, because of proximity). Our picky decoder network still responds with \u2018incoherent!\u2019 So, the umbrella is dropped from the context vector, and the decoder looks again. Finally, \u2018rain\u2019 is a coherent choice \u2014 unlike umbrellas and shoes, rain \u2018wasn\u2019t going to stop\u2019. Besides, \u2018shoes\u2019 is plural.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"014f\">\n          Most importantly, in the above example, the first instance of \u2018It\u2019 is\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           ambiguous\n          </strong>\n          for a while. The decoder needs to have a tantrum, when a sentence starts with \u2018it\u2019 \u2014 there is no referent! And, when more information is available, the decoder needs to\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           update\n          </strong>\n          its assessment of \u2018it\u2019. The word \u2018it\u2019 would, in a first pass of the sentence, be terribly ambiguous. The network parses as much as it can, and then goes back for a\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           second\n          </em>\n          pass, expanding its search for a coherent interpretation of \u2018it\u2019. Some things are permanently ambiguous! (&lt;-example) The network should be able to tell you which words are ambiguous, in what ways.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"a1c6\">\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           Pulling Attention and Explainability Together\n          </strong>\n          :\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"827f\">\n          We need to see the reasons for our networks\u2019 decisions, to check their thoughts\u2019 coherence. Later generations may consider explainability as fundamental as writing debugging tests.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"0883\">\n          And, a network should move its attention around the data, so that it can observe an input of any size (e.g., huge images, long sentences, involved games).\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"d919\">\n          A neural network could provide us with both of these goals, by\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           <em class=\"gz\">\n            moving its attention until it finds information that increases coherence\n           </em>\n          </strong>\n          . The coherence-test may be another \u2018module\u2019 among a cluster of neural networks in conversation. A simplistic architecture might look like this: the coherence module takes the context vector and the decoder\u2019s output, perhaps, and outputs either \u2018coherent\u2019 or \u2018incoherent\u2019. If it returns \u2018coherent\u2019, then use the decoder\u2019s output. Otherwise, \u2018incoherent\u2019 triggers suppression of some active features in the context vector. In effect, the network\u2019s attention is shifted toward less-salient words.\n         </p>\n         <p class=\"gl gm dt ar gn b go gp gq gr gs gt gu gv gw gx gy dl\" id=\"06c2\">\n          There are certainly better ways to build a coherence-check into neural networks than my simplistic description, above. As researchers tackle more complex tasks in machine learning, the architecture connecting network\n          <strong class=\"gn he\">\n           modules\n          </strong>\n          may become more important than the architecture of each cell. \u201cLSTM vs GRU\u201d is a small disagreement, while vast differences may arise from the ways in which multiple NNs are\n          <em class=\"gz\">\n           joined\n          </em>\n          . With that complexity, some guarantee of coherent thought is essential; at least one of those modules will be tasked with checking for coherence, and altering the salience of inputs.\n         </p>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </section>\n     </div>\n    </article>\n    <div class=\"hf dk hg hh ai ho hm hp\" data-test-id=\"post-sidebar\">\n     <div class=\"n p\">\n      <div class=\"z ab ac ae af ag ah ai\">\n       <div class=\"hq n dg\">\n        <div class=\"dk\">\n         <div class=\"hr hs r\">\n          <a class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\" href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=post_sidebar--------------------------post_sidebar-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n           <h2 class=\"aq ht hu as dt\">\n            Towards Data Science\n           </h2>\n          </a>\n          <div class=\"hv hw r\">\n           <h4 class=\"aq cl ew as br hx ey ez hy fb av\">\n            A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas, and codes.\n <div class=\"ip r\">\n           <div class=\"iq\">\n            <h4 class=\"aq cl ew as dt\">\n             <button class=\"cq cr az ba bb bc bd be bf bg gh gi bj bk fd fe\">\n              72 claps\n             </button>\n            </h4>\n           </div>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n         <div class=\"n o\">\n          <div class=\"gg r an\">\n           <a class=\"cq cr az    <svg class=\"q\" height=\"29\" width=\"29\">\n             <path d=\"M22.05 7.54a4.47 4.47 0 0 0-3.3-1.46 4.53 4.53 0 0 0-4.53 4.53c0 .35.04.7.08 1.05A12.9 12.9 0 0 1 5 6.89a5.1 5.1 0 0 0-.65 </svg>\n           </a>\n          </div>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"jx jy jz iu r y\">\n         <div class=\"ka kb r ig\">\n          <span class=\"r kc al kd\">\n           <div class=\"r s ke kf\">\n            <a href=\"/@oaklandthinktank?source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\" rel=\"noopener\">\n             <img alt=\"Anthony Repetto\"       <span class=\"r kc al kd\">\n           <div class=\"r s ke kf\">\n            <a href=\"https://towardsdatascience.com/?source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\"  </a>\n           </div>\n           <span class=\"r\">\n            <div class=\"kh kk n ki\">\n             <div class=\"ai n o em\">\n              <h2 class=\"aq ht kl km dt\">\n               <a <div class=\"kh ks r ki bp\">\n           <div class=\"ko r\">\n            <h4 class=\"aq cl hu kp av\">\n             A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas, and codes.\n            </h4>\n           </div>\n           <div class=\"kq kr bp\">\n            <div aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"fw\">\n             <a class=\"hz fh ax ay ia bh bi ib bg fs aq b ar as at au fu fv df fw fx bj\" href=\"https://medium.com/m/signin?operation=register&amp;redirect=https%3A%2F%2Ftowardsdatascience.com%2Fattention-and-explainability-in-rnns-7fd114bb4f1f&amp;source=follow_footer--------------------------follow_footer-\" When given a long sentence, neural networks usually struggle to pay attention to relevant information. A word at the beginning of the sentence may determine the conjugation of a word near the end of the sentence, but the neural network \u2018forgot about it\u2019. Researchers tried asking networks to \u2018remember the whole thing\u2019 (by converting the entire sentence to a fixed-length vector) but that only works on sentences as elaborate as those in their training.\",\"hasDropCap\":null,\"dropCapImage\":null,\"markups\":[{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:81a9aa67617a_4.markups.0\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"},{\"type\":\"id\",\"generated\":true,\"id\":\"Paragraph:81a9aa67617a_4.markups.1\",\"typename\":\"Markup\"}],\"__typename\":\"Paragraph\",\"iframe\":null,\"mixtapeMetadata\":null},\"Paragraph:81a9aa67617a_4.markups.0\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":165,\"end\":174,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:81a9aa67617a_4.markups.1\":{\"type\":\"EM\",\"start\":240,\"end\":243,\"href\":null,\"anchorType\":null,\"userId\":null,\"linkMetadata\":null,\"__typename\":\"Markup\"},\"Paragraph:81a9aa67617a_5\":{\"id\":\"81a9aa67617a_5\",\"name\":\"6b2f\",\"type\":\"P\",\"href\":null,\"layout\":null,\"metadata\":null,\"text\":\"For example, \u201cJim loves parties with his friends, the foods they make together, and their decorations.\u201d A parser must link the pronouns \u2018his\u2019, \u2018they\u2019, and \u2018their\u2019 to their referents: \u2018Jim\u2019, \u2018friends\u2019, and \u2018parties\u2019. A simple LSTM architecture would reach the word \u2018their\u2019, and remember its state from the prior word: \u2018and\u2019. Hopefully, researchers argued, that state would still include some knowledge of the earlier word, \u2018parties\u2019! For short sentences, the network does remember\u2014 the network state is not disrupted much. When given longer sentences, the network tends to pick recent words, not words that make sense. When a new word is encountered by the encoder network, part of the network looks around for other words in the sentence which may be relevant. The words deemed relevant are given to the decoder network. The context vector, in essence, highlights parts of the sentence and sends only those parts. It focuses the network\u2019s attention. With this, a decoder network can receive relevant information from farther back (or forward, for Bidirectional RNN). Sentence length matters less, because only a few words are considered relevant. The coherence-test may be another \u2018module\u2019 among a cluster of neural networks in conversation. A simplistic architecture might look like this: the coherence module takes the context vector and the decoder\u2019s output, perhaps, and outputs either \u2018coherent\u2019 or \u2018incoherent\u2019. If it returns \u2018coherent\u2019, then use the decoder\u2019s output. Otherwise, \u2018incoherent\u2019 triggers suppression of some active features in the context vector. As researchers tackle more complex tasks in machine learning, the architecture connecting network modules may become more important than the architecture of each cell. \u201cLSTM vs GRU\u201d is a small disagreement, while vast differences may arise from the ways in which multiple NNs are joined. With that complexity, some guarantee of coherent thought is essential; at least one of those modules will be tasked with checking for coherence, and altering the salience of
